TITLE.XREF: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT (FOREIGN INCOME MEASURES) BILL 1997

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 29 September, on motion by Senator Ian Campbell:
That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —The Taxation Laws Amendment (Foreign Income Measures) Bill 1997 is not contentious in principle, and it is one that the opposition supports. The general thrust of the legislation is to protect the Australian tax base by tightening up the rules governing certain types of foreign source income earned by Australian residents. Of course, it also gives me an opportunity to recount to the Australian people some of the hypocrisy of the coalition on the issue of international tax avoidance.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me turn to a few points of background. The current regime for taxing foreign source income was introduced by Labor to ensure that Australians were properly taxed on income earned outside Australia. Prior to these major structural reforms, the payment of tax on overseas investments made by Australian residents was, in practice, largely optional.

In 1975, the Asprey committee recommended the introduction of a comprehensive system of foreign tax credits, under which the foreign source income of Australian residents would be subject to Australian tax and a credit given for the foreign tax actually paid on that income. This was one of the many taxation issues that Mr Howard, when he was Treasurer, did not tackle. Equitable tax reform in this area of foreign income was not introduced by the Fraser government; it had to be introduced after 1983 by the Hawke government.

BREAK.PARA: After stalling on the issue for years, the Fraser government announced in 1978 that, on both equity and efficiency grounds, it would be following the Asprey committee recommendations. However, in typical fashion, it abandoned the proposal in the face of opposition from the business community in both Australia and overseas. So this blatantly unfair situation continued for a further decade until a decent government, the Labor government, had the courage and the conviction to reform and modernise the tax system, especially the international aspects of that system.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you are back‐pedalling on it already.
—There were three factors contributing to this precious—to this previous totally unsatisfactory situation.
—`Precious'!
—Read that again!

—I might just acknowledge some interjections and say that I am talking about the period of the Fraser government, when the current leader of Australia, the Prime Minister, was the Treasurer. If I were sitting on the government benches, I would not raise a peep about any of this, because it was during this period that he presided over a massive haemorrhaging of the Australian taxation system and the discovery of the bottom‐of‐the‐harbour tax avoidance structure. This meant that tax payments for the wealthy in Australia were entirely optional. It depended on the Australian Labor Party coming to power to sweep away that massive haemorrhaging of the Australian tax system. So, if I were part of the coalition, at this stage I would sit quiet and take my medicine on the inattention to proper tax reform which occurred in this country when they were last in government.

BREAK.PARA: I will proceed. As I said, there were three contributing factors to this previous totally unsatisfactory situation. First, there was a deficient legal regime. Until 1987, paragraph 23Q of the Income Tax Assessment Act governed whether or not foreign source income, except for dividends, was subject to Australian tax. This provision granted an exemption for foreign source income which had borne any foreign tax, including withholding tax. Indeed, income was exempt in Australia under this provision, even if it did not bear foreign tax but was not exempt from foreign tax.

So, in practice, foreign investments were often structured to ensure some low level of foreign tax was paid so that no Australian tax was payable. This regime made no distinction between the offshore source of the income; all investments were treated equally, whether sourced in a high-taxed OECD nation or through the most notorious tax haven. Of course, the distinction for dividends was largely academic because, if an Australian company received a dividend, it would be tax free anyway because of the dividend rebate regime.

Second, the actual legal regime that applied generally applied only to income which was remitted back to Australia. So investment income could accumulate offshore outside the tax net quite legitimately for those with significant means. Meanwhile, honest PAYE taxpayers, who worked for their income, had to contribute their tax week in and week out.

The third aspect of this system was the lack of information to enable Australian tax authorities to ensure that offshore investments were complying with Australian tax law, weak as it was at the time. There were only a small number of double tax conventions entered into by Australia relative to the current situation and there was a generally poor level of international cooperation by taxation authorities relative to the current situation.

So tax was an option for those wealthy enough to be able to invest offshore. This anomalous situation was noted in the draft white paper on taxation reform issued by the government in 1985. At page 230 that report noted how unfair the prevailing system was and stated:

Revenue consequences aside, these exemptions are inequitable where the foreign income tax is lower than the Australian income tax that would otherwise be payable. It can result in markedly different tax levels as between two resident taxpayers with the same amount of income, in the one case derived from Australian sources, and in the other from foreign. The exemption runs counter to neutrality objectives, providing a tax induced incentive for investment abroad rather than in Australia. At the same time the exemption affords an incentive to avoid tax by arranging to give income an artificial source overseas.

The system introduced by Labor to address these anomalies was comprehensive. It comprised, firstly, the foreign tax credit system, referred to as the FTCS. As I mentioned before, this was a minimum reform to ensure some justice, which the Fraser government could not achieve, even though it knew this should have been done. When this legislation came before the Senate, the then opposition voted against the proposals—that is, the now government voted against it. The coalition yet again sided with those who were not paying their fair share of income tax.

Secondly, there were the controlled foreign company, or CFC, measures. The CFC measures tax Australian shareholders on their pro rata share of a CFC's tainted income, the passive income—for example, interest, royalties, et cetera—or related party sales income, whether or not that income is remitted back to the Australian shareholder. This is an important measure to ensure that moneys invested in foreign businesses cannot be accumulated in tax havens outside of the Australian tax net. It acts in addition to the foreign tax credit system.

Thirdly, there are the foreign investment fund, or FIF, measures. The FIF measures apply to Australian shareholders who have an interest but not a controlling interest in a foreign entity—a company or a trust—that is not caught by the CFC or transferor trust measures. These rules ensure that passive offshore investment—say, in an international share trust—cannot escape taxation where equivalent investment behaviour—say, in the Australian share market through a domestic share trust—would be subject to Australian tax.

Finally, Labor changed the law to introduce the transferor trust measures and other measures to ensure that the taxation of interests in non-resident trusts is fair. The transferor trust measures attribute the income of a non-resident trust to an Australian resident who has transferred some value to the trust, and that is a broad parallel to the CFC measures or systems concerning companies.

So Labor has a proud record of cleaning up rorts in this area of international tax avoidance and the coalition has, typically, a disgraceful record—and the voting record in Hansard demonstrates that. Given this background, I have to say that the opposition were pleasantly surprised when we saw the discussion paper released in December of last year on this issue and the final decisions announced in the 1997 budget.

Finally the coalition appear to have accepted these reforms made by Labor. Whilst I condemn their previous obstructive actions, I welcome this change of direction. The process of keeping the tax system fair is an ongoing one. Bills such as the one before us today are part of the day-to-day work necessary to keep the tax net as free from holes as possible while still encouraging investment.

The aspects of the current arrangements that will be reformed by this bill include alterations to the current listing arrangements for comparable tax countries. Currently, the CFC and transferor trust regimes and the FTCS use the same list of comparable tax countries which provide too lenient treatment for the CFCs. The list for the CFC and transferor trust regimes will be reduced from approximately 50 nations to seven—this is to be known as the broad exemption list—to reflect the fact that there are many countries on the current list that do not consistently levy tax on a truly comparable basis to Australia. These countries will be known as limited exemption listed countries. The FTCS will be available on both broad exemption listed countries and limited exemption listed countries.

Secondly, there are measures which purportedly will reduce compliance costs. Various measures are being implemented which the government claims will simplify the rules concerning calculation of income from interests in CFCs, thereby hopefully reducing compliance costs. Of course, the goal of reducing compliance costs in all areas of regulation is shared by the opposition so long as existing standards are maintained.

I note various comments reported in the media about the actual effect of this legislation from some of the industry experts who will have to implement it. For example, Mr Ian Farmer, a Coopers and Lybrand tax partner, is reported in the Financial Review of 11 July last to have said:
The changes will require companies to conduct more detailed annual reviews of their overseas subsidiaries and will increase compliance costs.

In addition, a tax partner with Deloitte Touche Tohmatsu, Mr Duncan Baxter, is also reported as saying, `You've got to be joking,' when asked if the measures would reduce compliance costs. So just like the failure of the government to deliver on its commitment to halve the compliance costs and red tape on small business, there is certainly some doubt whether this legislation will actually reduce the compliance costs of Australian firms investing overseas.

The third element of this legislation concerns changes to the treatment of branch income of Australian companies operating overseas. Branches of Australian firms in a limited exemption listed country will face tougher rules for exemption of certain types of income. The taxation of branch income of Australian financial institutions will generally be brought more into line with the treatment of Australian financial institutions under the CFC regime.

In addition, there are various consequential changes and transitional rules in the bill which are supported by the opposition. For example, taxpayers will have the option to treat states emerging from the dissolution of listed countries—examples being the former Czechoslovakia, Union of Soviet Socialist Republics or Yugoslavia—as listed countries. Finally, there are changes to the foreign investment funds, or FIF, rules. Additional stock exchanges—Bogota, Colombo, Zimbabwe and Bratislava—are to be added to the list of approved stock exchanges and the existing exemption for approved country funds is to be repealed.

The estimated revenue flowing from the above measures combined is $125 million in the 1998-99 year and $100 million in subsequent years. The opposition has received representations on many of the matters about which I have spoken today. I will not detain the Senate by running through them in detail because many of them relate to technical problems which the business community is concerned about with the legislation.

Might I say though that I appear before the Senate at the moment representing the shadow Treasurer in addressing this bill. If I can for a moment don my hat as the shadow trade minister, there appears to me to be some issue for questioning the government about the impact of this bill on the trade relationship between developing countries where the financial markets are not as deregulated as they would be in developed countries. Perhaps I had best pursue that matter when we come to the committee stage of the bill.

I note for the record that one of the things which, in the last two weeks of what has been a tumultuous recess for this Senate, has perhaps attracted less attention than it might otherwise have done—had it not been forced out by the most distracting events of a frontbench reshuffle and all that followed since we last rose—was a comment by the trade minister that the Labor Party regarded trade with Asia as trade only with Asia and that we put all of our eggs in that basket, whereas the coalition regards Asia as first but puts its eggs in many other baskets. While I do not accept that the trade minister has accurately described our position—he has adopted a convenient set of words to suit the way in which he wants to present our position—nonetheless, what the government has said is that it wants to spread its trade market more widely.

It may be there are elements in this legislation that would require the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade to look at the impact of Australian investment in developing countries where there is a more highly regulated regime about foreign investment, but I will take those matters up in the committee stage. I conclude my remarks by repeating what I said at the beginning of my comments today: this bill is not a contentious one in principle, and it is one that we support. We will be voting that way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —The Taxation Laws Amend ment (Foreign Income Measures) Bill 1997 we are debating proposes to address some of the tax loopholes that allow foreign sourced income to escape full taxation in Australia. The bill will modify the list of countries which are acceptable as fully comparable to Australia in the taxation of business income.

SPEECH.PARA: Currently, under our international tax treaty arrangements, companies and trusts from over 50 countries receive not just exemptions on profits under the foreign tax credit system, but they are also exempt from accruals taxation under controlled foreign company and transferor trust measures. The double use of this bill has been found by the Taxation Office to be inappropriate as not all countries have comparable tax systems for both dividend tax credit and accruals. This bill will establish a second list for providing exemptions for accrual taxation under the controlled foreign company and transferor trust measures of those countries with clearly comparable tax systems. The list will comprise seven countries—all OECD countries—that make up the bulk of our foreign investors.

By denying exemptions on accruals taxation to countries with not strictly comparable tax systems, the Treasury will be able to prevent about $125 million of revenue a year from being lost. The Australian Democrats welcome these measures as absolutely essential, and I advise the Senate that we will be supporting the bill. We do not, however, think that they go far enough.

The Treasurer (Mr Costello) first proposed these measures in a discussion paper released on the somewhat inappropriate day of Christmas Eve last year. We responded to the Treasurer's discussion paper with our own submission in March welcoming the measures, but urging the government to do more to prevent tax revenue being lost due to certain tax advantages held by foreign corporations. In our submission we urged the government to adopt an active stance in reviewing the current set of bilateral tax treaties which in our view discriminate against a major importer of capital such as Australia.

The current tax treaty arrangements largely follow a formula set by the Bretton Woods agreements after World War II. Typically, these treaties provide for withholding taxes of 10 per cent on interest and 15 per cent on dividends earned in Australia but paid to a foreign company. So, in the case of, say, dividends, Australia gets 15 per cent, and the investor's home country gets 21 per cent. These treaties in our view overwhelmingly favour the countries and the treasuries of the foreign investors' home country. That is not surprising because the big foreign investing countries were the ones, after all, that drew up the Bretton Woods formulae.

But, as foreign investment levels in Australia have risen, we have to be aware that with it the ability of Australia to get a fair share of tax on income earned in this country is being affected. At the end of 1997, net foreign debt has risen to over $200 billion, or nearly 40 per cent of GDP; foreign investment equity had risen to over $110 billion or nearly 21 per cent of GDP; and, combined, over 60 per cent of GDP is now either owned or effectively mortgaged to foreign investors. That is up from 45 per cent a decade ago, and 20 per cent a decade before that. To put that in perspective, 15 per cent of the Australian economy, worth about $77 billion, has moved from Australian ownership to effective foreign control in the last decade. And most of that last decade was under Labor management.

With that has gone control of a very large income stream. Since 1986, interest payments on net foreign debt have risen from $7.2 billion to $11.1 billion, despite markedly lower interest rates. Dividends on foreign investment have risen from $900 million to over $8.1 billion, a ninefold increase. And with all of that has gone tax revenue. About $6.3 billion is now taxed at the concessional withholding tax arrangements rather than at resident tax rates, a situation made even worse by the decision in 1986 to extend the benefits of dividend imputation to non‐resident shareholders with a total exemption from withholding tax. This is despite the fact that only four other countries—New Zealand, Finland, Greece and Norway—have followed Australia down the fiscally disastrous route of full dividend imputation. The cost of extending full dividend imputation to non‐resident shareholders alone is calculated at $600 million a year.

So clearly Australia has a long way to go before it comes to terms with the tax problems raised by increasing dependence on foreign capital and by globalisation. The tax office has been grappling with the tax losses, especially through such measures as transfer pricing within multinational corporations, but, frankly, without a lot of success.

The previous government did not respond, and now this government is yet to fully respond to the 1991 recommendations of the Martin parliamentary inquiry into withholding tax arrangements. That inquiry's report was titled Follow the yellow brick road. It estimated that there were tax losses of up to $800 million a year through withholding tax.

Australia like other major financial centres, has failed to come to terms with the tax problems caused by the increasingly globalised financial markets. Nobel Prize winning economist James Tobin has proposed a modest tax on foreign exchange transactions to act as a small disincentive to arbitrage dealing which has had the effect of unnecessarily destabilising financial markets throughout the world. His proposal had the objective of improving the efficiency of financial markets in allocating resources by discouraging short‐term capital flows and also by restoring some of the monetary and fiscal authority governments used to have prior to financial deregulation and submission to financial world markets.

Let us remember that in 1995, as I am advised, global turnover in equities was worth $21 billion but global turnover in foreign exchange was worth a phenomenal $450 trillion. Such a tax would probably need to be implemented multilaterally and would involve a range of technical problems such as who gets the revenue and how it is to be divvyed up. But I think we need to give careful consideration to whether such a measure is appropriate for Australia. A recent major publication by a range of very senior economists from around the world found that such a tax could help to reduce market instability, as well as raise about $148 billion levied at a 0.1 per cent rate, or $290 billion at the higher 0.25 per cent rate globally.

This could provide an independent funding base for the United Nations, the World Bank and even the IMF, thereby reducing fiscal pressure on national governments who currently fund these bodies. Australia currently contributes about $433 million to the United Nations, international financial organisations and their activities. We pay nearly half a billion dollars for those institutions. So there is a big benefit there for us as well: a fiscal benefit, and the benefit that Australia, like all nations, will be a little less controlled by the erratic and often irrational sentiments of the fickle gamblers—and many of them are gamblers—on world financial markets.

I will be moving a second reading amendment urging Treasury to have a close look at all of these sorts of issues and to report back to parliament within six months. I think it is essential that the tax reform debate look not just at domestic taxation but at the equally important taxes issues raised by Australia's position in the global economy, the global market and the global financial market. I hope that the Senate will support my second reading amendment, and that the government will give serious consideration to the issues presented to the Treasurer in our March paper. I move:
At the end of the motion, add "but calls on the Government to:
(a) investigate further measures to ensure that Australia gets its fair share of revenue earned in the growing sector of the Australian economy owned by foreign corporations;
(b) investigate the feasibility of introducing a tax on international financial transactions as recommended by James Tobin either unilaterally or multi-laterally; and
(c) report back to the Parliament on the results of these investigations within six months."

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator IAN CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Murray and Senator Cook for their contributions to the debate. I will quickly summarise the merits of the changes that are to be made in the Taxation Laws Amendment (Foreign Income Measures) Bill 1997 . The government believes that the changes will improve the effectiveness of the rules for the accruals taxation of foreign source income, thereby helping to ensure that investments offshore are not favoured over similar investments in Australia for purely taxation reasons.

SPEECH.PARA: Improving the effectiveness of the rules will also help to stem the erosion of the Australian tax base that could otherwise occur through payments from Australian profits to foreign subsidiaries. In this regard, the changes are expected to result in revenue gains of about $125 million in 1998‐99 and $100 million in the outyears.

The creation of a shorter list of countries for providing exemptions from accruals taxation could, however, result in some increase in overall compliance costs for companies and trusts in limited exemption listed countries. These costs are considered necessary to protect the revenue. It is also relevant to note that most of the additional compliance burden will be borne by the Australian controllers of foreign companies that derive significant amounts of tainted income. These companies are the legitimate target of the controlled foreign companies measures. Compliance costs will not increase for all foreign companies controlled by Australian residents. The changes being made to help reduce compliance costs under the controlled foreign company measures are likely to result in an overall reduction in compliance costs for most companies in the broad exemption list of countries.

The government will not be supporting Senator Murray's second reading amendment. As a government, we are committed to ensuring that Australia receives its fair share of revenue. When we debate the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1997 , with the thin capitalisation measures, in the Senate later this week, we will certainly be addressing the concern that is raised in part (a) of Senator Murray's amendment.

As far as the tax on international financial transactions is concerned—which Senator Murray referred to as the Tobin proposal—the government is actively involved in looking at the tax treatment of financial transactions. From my point of view, I do not regard short‐term movements in financial transactions as being against the interests of international trade and the world economy. I think they serve a very important purpose and we have to be very careful to ensure that we do not put unnecessary constraints on those. Both the fair share of revenue and the continuing treatment of tax on international financial transactions are very much ongoing processes and the Senate, by passing this amendment, would not achieve anything. I commend the bill to the Senate.
Amendment agreed to.
Original question, as amended, agreed to.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —I foreshadowed, firstly informally before we started and then in my speech during the second reading stage, that I had a question relating to Chile and the impact of this legislation which comes under schedule 2, foreign investment funds. For the information of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator Ian Campbell), I have a letter from a management fund, Genesis Management Australia Ltd, which, from the tone of it, although it does not say explicitly, would be in the possession of the government because it is a letter related to the information paper released in December last year by the Treasurer, Mr Peter Costello, on the subject of proposed changes to the taxation of foreign source income.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not propose to read the letter—it is quite a long letter and has attached to it a fairly thick submission—but I do think it raises a relevant point which gives rise to a series of appropriate questions. In this letter, the authors say that they submit that the FIF exemption of their fund, the Genesis Chile Fund Ltd, should not be withdrawn, but should be granted in an alternative form. They go on to say that:

The submission notes that in the case of Chile the proposed change would be revenue neutral in that existing investors in Chile via Genesis Chile Fund Limited would be obliged to withdraw their investments. The removal of the exemption would only close to Australian investors a currently legitimate commercial activity with no evident compensating benefits either to the commercial sector or the Government.

They go on in the letter to refer to a report by Langton Clarke y Cia Ltda, which, I understand, is a major Chilean chartered accountant firm based in Santiago and an associate of Coopers & Lybrand internationally. They say that the report demonstrates that there has been no investment liberalisation in Chile; and a series of points are made—I will read them but they are (a) to (f)—all of which point to what the lack of investment liberalisation in Chile is and what the requirements are of foreign investors. I have identified this letter and the accompanying submission because I believe it would be in the government's possession. Let me quote from the concluding paragraph of this letter where the author, Mr G.C. Harrison, who is the Director of Genesis, says:

We believe that we have demonstrated in this material that the investment conditions in Chile under which FIF exemption was granted to Genesis Chile Fund Limited have not changed, and that accordingly Section 513 and Schedule 11 of the Income Tax Regulations should not be repealed in respect of Genesis Chile Fund Limited.

I ask Senator Campbell: firstly, to his knowledge, has the trade minister or the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade been alerted to the impact these measures would have on investment in Chile; secondly, what is the government's response to the submissions made by Genesis Management Australia Ltd in their submission; thirdly, do they concur with the conclusions that Genesis Management Australia Ltd draw on the impact of this legislation on their Chilean investments?

TALKER.NAME: Senator IAN CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —The short answer is that we would disagree with that assessment by Genesis. The Treasury's assessment is that the current regulatory regime in Chile is such that direct investment is possible and therefore that Genesis's interpretation of the situation is not correct. The Treasury is standing by our position in relation to that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Campbell, in their letter, Genesis cite this report of Langton Clarke y Cia Ltda—
—Compania.
—Thank you very much, Senator O'Chee. Limitada?
—Si.
—I do not know if there is a rule against speaking in a foreign language in an Australian Senate. There probably is.
—I am told there is, Senator.
—There is? Well, we are unparliamentary.
—We should grant an exemption to a foreign source.

—It is pretty hard to discuss some foreign events without reverting to proper names. But, in their report, this chartered accountancy firm, which is an associate of Coopers and Lybrand, I understand, made these following points:

SPEECH.PARA: a. Foreign portfolio investment has been controlled by the Chilean government since 1990. The policy has not changed, and has been reinforced by problems in neighbouring countries.
b. Investment capital is subject to foreign exchange control, and must remain in Chile for a minimum of one year.
c. A deposit of 30% of investment capital must be lodged interest free with the Central Bank, or a payment equivalent to the interest on such a deposit paid.

d. Taxation is 35% on income and capital gains where the investment is not made through a 18,657 fund such as Genesis Chile Fund. Where the 18,567 requirements are met the tax rate reduces to 10%, payable only as a withholding tax. This is a major advantage for Australian shareholders of 18,567 funds, at no cost to Australian taxation revenue.

e. Foreign investors must enter into a contract with the Chilean Government at a substantial initial cost and significant regular compliance costs. A large fund such as Genesis Chile Fund can spread these costs to minimise their impact on individual investors.
f. The Chilean Government is unlikely to change its policy on international investment in the foreseeable future.

They are the salient features of what inhibits foreign investment in Chile, as I understand from this letter. My question is: is that a correct presentation of the regulatory framework in Chile; and, if it is, what element of that causes Treasury to hold the view that has just been expressed by you, Parliamentary Secretary?

TALKER.NAME: Senator IAN CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I would add that Senator Cook sought information as to whether DFAT had been consulted on this. They were indeed, as one would assume. Secondly, in answer to your latest question, Senator Cook, the government's position is that there remain concerns that country funds are being utilised to obtain the kinds of deferral benefits that the FIF measures were designed to counter. Furthermore, the proposal will not prohibit investments to Chile but rather ensure that such investments are not favoured over domestic investments for purely tax reasons.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —Given the time constraints here, I can sympathise with the fact that you might not be able to provide me with a slightly more detailed response. But I was questioning whether the issues set out here in this correspondence, which I have now read into the Hansard , accurately reflect the true position. If they do, why does the government believe that the then contention which flows from that is not a sound one? Senator Campbell, I do not expect you to be able to produce this off the top of your head, but I would appreciate an answer to that question.

SPEECH.PARA: I conclude on this point. I presume that in the normal course the government will answer the letter and the submission of Genesis Management Australia Ltd. When they do, could the opposition, if there is no objection from Genesis, have a copy of the answer?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator IAN CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —We have had a good look at the assertions that have been made and have come down on the side of saying that a lot of that sort of activity is tax driven. That is why Treasury has come down with the advice that they have come down with, and that is why the government has picked that advice up. But, in terms of the detail that you raised in your penultimate question, we will provide a more detailed response to you in writing.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Senator Ian Campbell) read a third time.

TITLE.XREF: VOCATIONAL EDUCATION AND TRAINING FUNDING AMENDMENT BILL 1997

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 23 September, on motion by Senator Brownhill:
That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr, Sen Kim

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At the end of the motion, add but the Senate:
(a) is of the opinion that Technical and Further Education (TAFE) has a vital role to play in providing employment skills and opportunities for lifelong learning; and
(b) calls on the Government:

PARA.TAB: (i) to uphold the promises it made before the 1996 election and properly support and resource TAFE in this important role,
(ii) to meet its responsibility under the ANTA Agreement to fund vocational education and training growth on a continuing basis,
(iii) not to cut funding to vocational education and training at a time when demand already cannot be met, and
(iv) not to impose savage and unreasonable cost cutting on the TAFE sector in the name of efficiency".

SPEECH.PARA: In speaking to the Vocational Education and Training Funding Amendment Bill 1997 , I draw to the Senate's attention that TAFE is very much in crisis in this country. This bill is at the heart of that crisis. It provides no growth funding whatsoever for TAFE. Of course, this is very much in line with the government's decisions. The Howard government is abandoning the commitment that the Commonwealth made under Labor's ANTA agreement—an agreement which is still in place—and that is that the Commonwealth would `provide growth funding on a continuing basis'. There is no doubt that funding for growth is required, but this government has ignored that fact.

The Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Dr Kemp) admits that some 60,000 people missed out on TAFE places last year. Yet, last month Dr Kemp bludgeoned and blackmailed the states and territories into agreeing to a funding arrangement for TAFE which requires all future growth to be funded from so‐called efficiencies; this after three months of overblown rhetoric by Dr Kemp that some $300 million in efficiencies can be made annually if only the states and territories would get their houses in order. The facts are very simple. Dr Kemp has now retreated somewhat from that claim. No doubt the new Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Senator Ellison)—I congratulate him on his appointment—will have to deal with that backdown by Dr Kemp. He has left you with a very dirty mess to clean up, Minister.

It is no wonder that Dr Kemp has been forced to back down from his campaign against the states and against TAFE colleges. A recent briefing paper prepared by the Australian National Training Authority says of the $300 million claim:

If growth in VET is to be funded by efficiencies alone, reductions in average recurrent expenditure per annum hour curriculum of between 3.8 per cent and 7.9 per cent would be required. The capacity of the states and territories to deliver efficiency gains of this order within a single calendar year is problematic. Analysis based on the assumption that all states and territories would deliver training at the cost of the most efficient state—
that is, Victoria—

suggest that there is considerable scope for efficiency savings. However, the rate at which these efficiencies can be realised and the extent to which efficiency gains are restricted by cost drivers will in practice substantially reduce the potential efficiencies identified.
The paper pulled the rug out from under Dr Kemp and this government's entire argument when it said:
A reliable estimate of real efficiency possibilities as opposed to notional possibilities requires access to detailed information on a state and territory's budget system that is not available.

In other words, ANTA does not know whether the scope really exists for efficiency savings it has theoretically identified. The minister does not know. I challenge the new minister to tell this Senate whether he in fact knows now.

Moreover the benchmark—the so‐called low cost state; the model which is the gospel, according to Dr Kemp, that all states and territories have to emulate in order to make these theoretical savings—is, of course, Victoria. How is it that Victoria became the cost model? It became the cost model largely by adopting a ruthless approach to vocational education expenditure very similar to the approach it has followed in schools. TAFE colleges—which provide a valuable service to their local communities as a point of access to continuing education and training—which did not meet the Kennett definition of efficiency were closed or `amalgamated'—which, of course, is another Kennett term—all over regional Victoria.

The assault is still going on in Victoria. The Victorian government is currently considering a proposal to merge Melbourne's 14 TAFE institutes into eight and possibly five in a move which the Victorian training minister admits is related to cost cutting. It is directly related to cost cutting. This whole approach to vocational educational and training, like the Howard government's approach to higher education, is essentially input focused.

Dr Kemp talks about the need to improve quality, yet the benchmarking measures he is forcing on the states are entirely focused on costs. I ask this new minister whether this is his approach as well. Nothing demonstrates this better than the results of the national employer satisfaction survey conducted in late 1995 and early 1996 by AGB McNair and funded by ANTA. It is extremely interesting to note how well Dr Kemp's star state system performed. When it came to the question of the quality and relevance of an emasculated TAFE system, it was judged by employers that Victoria performed worse than any other state in the Commonwealth. On the 21 criteria, Victoria ranked worse than the average 12 or 57 per cent.

BREAK.PARA: For example, on the question of supervisor satisfaction about the extent to which the course fitted in with work commitments, there was an Australia‐wide level of 74 per cent, yet Victoria rated at 65 per cent. The benchmark state ranked second lowest in the country when supervisors were asked about the relevance of the skills to the current needs of organisations and second lowest on the issue of job readiness of graduates. Both employers and supervisors ranked Victoria far below the national average on the question of the cost-effectiveness of the training provided, and that is really the key of this whole issue. There is a direct relationship between cost cutting and the cutting of quality in our TAFE system, but this government's actions have fundamentally undermined the quality of TAFE provisions in this country.

It is difficult then to escape the conclusion about all of this cost cutting. It has produced, as I said, the very disturbing proposition that this government's real agenda is the privatisation of the education system at all levels—driven essentially by an ideological obsession, that has no basis, based on the provision of quality education services for all Australians. It is an obsession about reducing the quality of education, which is a direct consequence of its policy of cost cutting.

If we turn to the negotiations of 25 September, what do we see in terms of the Commonwealth's cutback program? Its funding guarantee of five years has been reduced to a funding guarantee of only three years. This is hardly a big concession. It is not putting in 1c of its own money for any growth in the system. We have not seen that the Commonwealth has given ground, which is what Dr Kemp's media releases would have us believe.

What we are seeing is that Dr Kemp is now dropping his demand for 500,000 additional places over five years. He has actually given himself less room to grandstand and to make political capital as a consequence. You might say that the minister for headlines has, in these circumstances, made a major concession. What the states have done is put the finger right on Dr Kemp. They have identified clearly what he is. When talking about the federal minister, Dr Phil Honeywood said:
The States and Territories have just given up, basically. Kemp, just to get headlines, goes out after each Minister's meeting . . . and hits us with another bombshell that we haven't agreed upon.
And another Liberal state minister—in fact from Dr Kemp's home state—has accused the federal minister of engaging in cynical, political stunts, motivated by attention‐grabbing self-promotion.

Where does all this leave our TAFE system and the people who use it? It leaves TAFE in crisis and, as I said earlier, it leaves a government committed to undermining and white‐anting the training facilities in this country.

We should make no mistake about the consequences of this action. The government is talking about a fundamental change to one of the most important educational infrastructure facilities that it ought to have a responsibility to provide. There were 1.3 million Australians involved in vocational education and training courses last year, and a further 400,000 were undertaking non-accredited courses. TAFE accounts for some 94 per cent of the student contact hours in vocational education and training, according to information provided by the National Schools Statistics Collection which monitors these areas. People with TAFE qualifications outnumber those with a university qualification by more than two to one and TAFE graduates have a higher rate of employment.
What you have got is a system that meets very high levels of social equity in terms of the targeting of its arrangements. One witness told the Senate inquiry into the bill:

Of the graduates of TAFE in 1995, 55 per cent were female, 27 per cent of them came from a non‐English speaking background, six per cent had a disability and 1.6 per cent were Aboriginal. That is a pretty impressive little bundle of statistics to demonstrate the importance of TAFE in the community . . . Anything that is going to impact on TAFE resources will impact immediately on those target groups, many or most of whom will have nowhere else to go—

According to the ABS survey of TAFE graduate outcomes for 1994, the average age of TAFE graduates was 29 years, with 11 per cent of graduates being over the age of 44. The survey also highlighted the increasing significance of TAFE in providing particular skills to people who had previously completed a university education, with some five per cent of graduates having completed a bachelor or higher degree before the commencement of their TAFE programs. By inadequately resourcing TAFE, the Howard government is effectively abandoning one of the most important roles it can play in Australia's current and future interests—that is, ensuring the appropriate provision of quality education and training for all our citizens.

We hear a lot from this government about competition. Government schools must compete with non-government counterparts. TAFE must compete with private providers. Putting aside the important issue of whether education can work effectively as an open market—which I say it cannot—what you do not hear from this government is how it is stacking the deck against public providers. While state governments are closing public schools which they say have too few students, the federal government is funding private schools with far fewer enrolments. TAFEs are being expected, on a similar basis, with reduced funding, to continue their traditional role of providing broad access to adult education, while at the same time competing with private providers to meet the needs of employers. As the Pro‐Vice‐Chancellor, Vocational Education and Training at the RMIT told the Senate inquiry on 5 August:

There has been a substantial decrease in capital funds for VET. That is a concern to us because of the old stock that we have . . . if we are going to go into a competitive trading market, we are competing with other providers that may be up to date with buildings, facilities and equipment, whereas we have been left with a fairly run‐down situation.

This government's privatisation agenda is clearly recognised by the states. The Victorian training minister, Dr Honeywood, was reported in the Age on 13 June as questioning whether the Commonwealth's aim was to `dismantle the TAFE system by squeezing it to produce impossible efficiencies while encouraging private providers to take over training'. Dr Honeywood has also given us his views about Dr Kemp's approach to nego tiations, and I quote from the Age of 29 August:
Minister Kemp is a total centralist. He reminds me very much of the former prime minister Billy Hughes. When he didn't want to hear something he turned his hearing aid off.

Even Jeff Kennett—my old sparring partner—weighed in. It is strange that he and I agree on anything, but what we do see is that Dr Kemp's behaviour has been identified as being childish and stupid. Such behaviour has now been rewarded with Dr Kemp being elevated to the position of a senior portfolio minister. In other words, bullying, arrogance, distorting the truth, cutting funds and re-announcing old initiatives are the hallmarks of achievement in the Howard government. Senator Ellison, let this be a lesson to you. Emulate your senior minister and you too will be rewarded for backstabbing your colleagues.

We should remember that the most vehement criticisms of Dr Kemp have not come from ALP ministers or from Labor premiers but from political colleagues from his home state. It is almost as if they know him best. The states and territories with conservative governments were in a state of near rebellion in their dealings with the federal Labor government, but it is interesting that the then federal Labor government was prepared to properly invest in education and training and to back up its policy directions with sufficient resources. This government came into office having promised to—and I quote directly from its policy platform:

. . . continue to support a strong and effective TAFE sector, that is, the publicly funded network of TAFE institutions . . . and to ensure that the network of TAFE institutions, especially in rural and regional centres, will not be undermined and that TAFE will continue its traditional role as a provider of further education and second chance educational opportunity, particularly for disadvantaged groups.

Those were the promises, but what we have seen over the last two budgets bears no relation to that. We have seen reductions in funding to TAFE of over $240 million. We have seen $1.6 million cut from the financial assistance grants to the states, further reducing the states' capacities to fund their TAFE systems. The states and territories traditionally spend around 3.5 per cent of their FAGs on TAFE. So the $1.6 million cut announced last June equates to some $56 million less for public provision of vocational education and training—on top of the other budgetary cuts.

There is no doubt that TAFE is in fact facing a crisis. It is under assault from this Howard government, a government which refuses to accept or acknowledge its responsibility to invest sufficient resources in educating and training young Australians. Under this government, the entire VET sector is being pushed towards low cost, short‐term approaches which will damage our skills base as well as reduce educational opportunities for all Australians.

I urge the Senate to support the opposition's second reading amendment, which calls on the government to erode the key planks of our future prosperity by narrow‐minded and short‐term cost funding. The amendment states:
At the end of the motion, add:
"But the Senate:
(1) is of the opinion that TAFE has a vital role to play in providing employment skills and opportunities for lifelong learning; and
(2) calls on the Government:

PARA.TAB: (a) to uphold the promises it made before the 1996 election and properly support and resource TAFE in this important role;
(b) to meet its responsibility under the ANTA Agreement to fund vocational education and training growth on a continuing basis;
(c) not to cut funding to vocational education and training at a time when demand already cannot be met; and
(d) not to impose savage and unreasonable cost cutting on the TAFE sector in the name of efficiency".

BREAK.PARA: Might I just say in conclusion that this is an important bill which goes to the very heart of the problems faced by TAFE in this country. It might appear on the surface to be just a mechanical means by which we provide some $890 million, but what it does do is go to the issue of the ideological debate that is occurring within education and the ideological obsessions of this government to actually undermine the TAFE sector, to privatise the TAFE sector and, as a consequence, to undermine the quality of education and training provided at our TAFE institutes across this country. This is an extremely important measure. I trust the Senate will support the opposition's second reading amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: —Just for the benefit of Senator Carr and the opposition, the Australian Democrats will be supporting the second reading amendment before us today. I would also like to congratulate the new minister on his appointment. The Vocational Education and Training Funding Amendment Bill , which is before us today, provides base funding for a new ANTA agreement and the funding basis, of course, for the Commonwealth's contribution to TAFE. We know that approximately $3 billion a year is spent on this area with a Commonwealth component of around $1 billion. TAFE, of course, makes up around 95 per cent of the total funds that are provided to the vocational education sector.

SPEECH.PARA: Unfortunately, to date, this government has reduced vocational education and training grants to the states and territories and it has abolished the five per cent real growth that was available for TAFE. The government has also cut ANTA's operating expenses by around $12 million in its first budget and followed this in the most recent budget with the $72 million benchmarking efficiencies. Vocational education and training funding has been cut by 2.2 per cent in real terms between 1996 and 2001. This is already on top of a government's projected and implemented cuts to the labour market programs of around $1.8 billion over four years.

As Senator Carr referred, the committee inquiry into this bill revealed that the funding levels proposed will not meet the level of demand for the sector. The federal government is proposing that growth should be funded by the states through so-called efficiencies, despite the findings of the KPMG consultancy report undertaken by ANTA which showed that the level of underfunding is already quite substantial.

By agreement with the states and the Commonwealth, the ANTA Act was implemented in 1992. The Democrats played a role in that too. In fact, we were keen to ensure that that bill was passed, provided there was appropriate scrutiny of that particular legislation and of ANTA's role. ANTA provides obligations on both the states and the territories and on the Commonwealth itself for the provision of funding for vocational education and training.

The act does provide an obligation on the states to maintain their 1992 funding effort for the provision of vocational education and training in this country. It also provides for the Commonwealth to provide growth funds on a continuing basis. Now the Kemp plan commits the Commonwealth to a guaranteed level of funding of around $900 million annually for the next five years on the condition that the states and territories increase student places by around 500,000, but this is not accompanied by growth funds from the Commonwealth.

According to Minister Kemp, all this growth must be funded from the states and territories through the so‐called efficiency gains. The Democrats believe Minister Kemp's ultimatum contravenes the spirit of the original ANTA agreement. In fact, it is simply a threat to the states and territories. But the schedule to the Australian National Training Authority Act actually states:
The Commonwealth will provide growth funding on a continuing basis.
On 5 August this year, in evidence presented to the Senate committee considering the bill, the Australian Education Union stated:
. . . certainly there seems to have been a moral breach in relation to the obligations of the Commonwealth government to provide those growth funds.
The union president, Ms Sharon Burrow, went on:

When you look at . . . the cuts to TAFE over the budget, the labour market program cuts and the effect on TAFE in particular and the VET sector more broadly, the efficiency demand from the federal government of some $300 million, and you contrast that . . . with the unmet demand of 65,000 places from last year, the 100,000 additional places demanded by ANTA in terms of the current agreement round and the additional unknown demand driven by the youth training allowance and the changes to the dole, you see that we have a breakdown in the Commonwealth‐state partnership. We have states who say they are simply unable to meet those expectations and we have a Common wealth that is driving those expectations, and the government is not prepared to fund the public policy base.

The Australian Democrats, as I mentioned, supported the implementation of ANTA and we expected the Commonwealth to work hand in hand with the states and territories and, of course, the TAFE networks. We were pleased at that time, in 1992, the former government recognised and acknowledged its responsibilities in relation to the TAFE sector. However, we were concerned that ANTA should not simply be another level of government bureaucracy. We were keen to ensure that ANTA was open and accountable, and of course available for parliamentary scrutiny.

Like the Australian Education Union, the Democrats know there is no point in the government urging people to get further education and training, and in particular further and technical education, if the government does not provide the necessary resources, that is, if the necessary resources are not there to ensure that these additional numbers are trained or educated.

The Democrats express grave concern when it comes to the full ramifications of this bill. We believe they have not been examined adequately by the government—specifically, the impact, for example, of the government's common youth allowance policy. What kind of an impact will the CYA have on demand for the TAFE and other education sectors? What are the implications of the common youth allowance on young people and of course their families?

Approximately 60,000 people missed out on TAFE places this year. The National Centre for Vocational Education Research stated that there has been unmet demand of around 8.3 per cent for this sector in recent years. This compares with the higher education sector which has had an unmet demand of around 3.1 per cent over the last few years but, according to the National Centre for Vocational Education Research, 9.2 per cent of the 15‐ to 19‐year‐old age group were unable to get a place in the TAFE system over the past year.

With the Commonwealth's common youth allowance potentially abolishing financial support for those young people—certainly those between 16 and 18 not in education, employment or training—they are not being offered any real solutions; especially if these young people are not going to have access to TAFE or other education and training places. This is a concern not only of the Democrats, but of the National Tertiary Education Union, the National Union of Students, the AEU, and it has been echoed by Minister Kemp's state and territory counterparts.

As Senator Carr said, the Victorian state minister for training, Phil Honeywood, claims there could be another 15,000 students in Victoria alone who cannot be accepted into the TAFE and vocational education sector. They will not be able to be catered for—15,000 are going to miss out. But he also remarks that it is estimated that around 40,000 young people could qualify for the Commonwealth's common youth allowance, if they enrol in TAFE, and that would cost the state of Victoria an additional $70 million per year. We are concerned that the federal government is not prepared for this.

I am yet to see any evidence from the government that they have considered the impact of the common youth allowance on young people and their families generally, let alone the TAFE sector in particular and the higher education sector. So, apart from the proposals that this government has put forward that basically sweep young people under the carpet—whether it is a year 13 idea, or botching and fiddling the figures so that we have hidden unemployment or underemployment—I have yet to see any realistic policies from this government that look after that increased and unmet demand.

In fact the federal government is holding the states and the territories to ransom on this issue, demanding that the states pick up the shortfall, and abrogating its own Commonwealth responsibilities as laid out in the various acts. It is already clear that these responsibilities will not be picked up by anyone. To expect young people to be further supported by their families, specifically in relation to income support, is absolutely outrageous. It is anachronistic and, of course, it is quite callous.

BREAK.PARA: Dr Kemp's plan was viewed quite rightly by the states as a way of forcing them to deliver up to 40 per cent more TAFE places; there are roughly about 1.2 million currently. This is with no extra funds from the Commonwealth and on top of the funding cuts that the states have already had to sustain of around $72 million over the next four years. While Dr Kemp has insisted that the states do not reject his federal plan I think it is pretty obvious from the joint resolution in June from the state training ministers that they quite clearly doubt that they could produce the 500,000 new places that they are expected to produce over the next five years. Dr Kemp has maintained his estimate that around $300 million can be saved through efficiencies, but I have to state that the Democrats agree with the state ministers that this money cannot necessarily be found through the so‐called efficiencies.

The major cost in the vocational education and training system is labour, of course. On average, about 80 per cent of the TAFE operating costs are salary costs, so it is a great concern that the states are compared with the lowest common denominator, that is, with the state of Victoria, when it comes to setting the lowest benchmark. All these states are compared against Victoria. Isn't it worrying that that is the one that has been chosen to compare against? In that state there has been an offer of around a 10 per cent salary increase for teaching and non‐teaching staff. Average costs in the benchmark state are, therefore, set to rise between eight and 12 per cent. According to the evidence presented to the committee by Mr Des Fooks:

Not only does this create a negative capacity to fund growth in Victoria, it destroys the arithmetic for savings in all other states and territories. Clearly savings through efficiency gains will neither reach the required volume nor be released quickly enough to satisfy the resource requirements of the level of growth in student numbers being demanded by Kemp. In some states they will not even be sufficient to meet unavoidable cost increases.

The federal government is deliberately ignoring the significant effort that TAFE has already made in the name of efficiency. The evidence presented by the National Tertiary Education Union, specifically by Jane Nic holls, showed that over the period 1991 to 1994 there was a percentage growth in contact hours in the VET system of 21 per cent nation wide.

In a similar period, enrolments increased by 16 per cent. However, teaching staff in the VET system as a whole increased by only 8.4 per cent and non‐teaching staff increased more rapidly. It appears that these so-called efficiencies have already been obtained. So, as Mr Fooks has cautioned, we must be careful that we do not start placing efficiencies before quality—and I suspect that that is already happening.

The AEU raised concerns, which the Democrats share, regarding the high casualisation of the teaching and non‐teaching staff in the TAFE sector. In New South Wales alone more than half of the total teaching staff is casual. I do not think we can really attempt to try to trim fat from bone. I think most of the efficiencies have already been gained.

Ignoring this concern, on 5 September Minister Kemp gave the states until the end of that month to respond to his funding offer. He is petulantly threatening the states that he will withdraw this offer after that time. On the Sunday program Jeff Kennett, when obviously commenting on the ministerial reshuffle, had a few things to say about the new minister Dr David Kemp. Perhaps I will leave it to Senator Carr to comment on Jeff Kennett.

TALK.START.PARA: —Come on. Be brave.

—Let us just say that he said that the new minister, Senator Ellison, will have to do better than this. Senator Ellison, we have faith in you that you will do better than your predecessor, Dr David Kemp, because he seriously underestimated the needs of the education sector per se. I will get stuck into Dr David Kemp over higher education. I think I will wait until then. Rex Hewett, the AEU's federal TAFE secretary, said:

BREAK.PARA: . . . in just one week Dr Kemp has managed to destroy cooperation between the Federal and State Ministers that has been built up over the last five years.
Senator Ellison, we assume you can only do better and wish you luck in perhaps rebuild ing some of the Commonwealth and state and territory relations.
Mr Des Fooks, the former head of DEETYA's vocational education and training division, told the Senate inquiry:
Of the graduates of TAFE in 1995—
I recognise that Senator Carr also referred to these statistics, but they are incredible—

55 per cent were female, 27 per cent of them came from a non-English speaking background, six per cent had a disability and 1.6 per cent were Aboriginal . . . Anything that is going to impact on TAFE resources will impact immediately on those target groups, many or most of whom will have nowhere else to go . . .

Isn't it true of this government that, instead of recognising education and training as the great equaliser, as the one opportunity to empower those groups that have been traditionally under‐represented, unrepresented or locked out of those education and training opportunities, instead of giving them the opportunities, they are placing barriers in their path—whether it is in the form of fees and charges or cuts to operating grants in the higher education sector or cuts and slashes to TAFE in the form of efficiencies, or even expecting the states and territories to increase the number of places available for young people hoping to undertake some form of education and training, yet providing no additional funds through which the states and territories can actually meet these particular challenges.

This government has poured millions of dollars into failed private companies like South Pacific Cruise Lines, held the TAFE sector to ransom, cut operating grants for the higher education sector and forced universities to introduce up-front and full cost fees. I note that RMIT's council is due to make its final decision on the issue of up-front and full cost fees today. I hope they see the light and pay attention to the referendum results over the last two weeks.

Certainly, this government has a long way to go when it comes to adequate funding for education and training generally. I urge the new minister, in particular, to recognise the great power and benefit of education and training and to stop locking out all Austral ians, particularly those from disadvantaged backgrounds, from the opportunity of pursuing education and training.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian National Training Authority was enacted in 1992 as an agreement on funding levels between the states and the Commonwealth. The states were to maintain 1992 funding levels and the Commonwealth was to provide growth funding on a continuous basis. The government has decided to hold funding at around $900 million for the next three years and, at the same time, call for the states and territories, and in particular TAFE, to increase places by 100,000 a year with no growth funding.

SPEECH.PARA: Both the committee inquiry into this Vocational Education and Training Funding Amendment Bill and the consultancy report commissioned by ANTA found that current funding levels are already inadequate for the projected level of demand in this sector. Let us not forget that the government already cut ANTA operating expenses by $12 million in the 1996 budget.

The government is violating both the spirit and the substance of the ANTA agreement by withholding growth funds, despite the fact that there was unmet demand of 60,000 places last year. What sort of cruel joke are the Prime Minister, Mr Howard, the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Senator Kemp, and the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training, Senator Ellison, attempting to play on people by encouraging them to undertake TAFE studies and adult education while refusing to provide the resources to enable the provision of quality education. Dr Kemp, the minister who introduced this bill, had claimed that $300 million in efficiency savings would help fund up to 100,000 extra places a year over the next five years. He calls that $300 million of fat.

It has been mentioned by Senator Stott Despoja that there is already a high level of casualisation within the TAFE sector. What does this mean in terms of education outcomes and student outcomes? This is what we should be asking. What does it mean in terms of the basic conditions of work for those people who are under those conditions? It means that more and more people are being employed on an hourly basis to only provide the lecture.

They do not get paid extra hours to prepare. They do not get extra hours necessarily to provide student contact hours, although there might be others in the more permanent staff who provide this. They do not necessarily get paid for ongoing development. You have a situation where this cannot possibly be good for quality education and training outcomes. It cannot possibly be good for the level of morale of those people whose job is to provide quality education and training outcomes.

If what you do is try to plug in on a needs basis lecture by lecture, there is obviously going to be a real problem of continuity, a real problem of commitment for people who do not know what their next contract will be, and a real problem with course development—people continually having to reinvent the same wheels. The fact is that the great majority of costs in the TAFE sector are, as was mentioned, labour costs. With both teaching and non-teaching staff already deserving wage rises, states will be hard‐pressed to meet cost increases, let alone fund increased places.

We have heard that the common youth allowance is going to create its own demand. In relation to this the government said, `These kids are not unemployed. They are either at school or they do not exist.' That is effectively what they are saying. And where are these kids going to go? Where are our young people going to go if at the same time the government is, in effect, trying to make the TAFE sector do a lot more with less? It is ridiculous to assume that you can bring in something like a common youth allowance and then not provide for the education and training outcomes that will obviously be required.

There have also been significant efficiencies made already in both contact hours and enrolments in the vocational education and training sector since 1991. How much further does Dr Kemp expect he can push overworked staff before quality of education starts to unavoidably decline or decline even fur ther? The WA State School Teachers Union President, Mr Brian Lindberg, has informed us that in my state of Western Australia the government's proposal, which amounts to providing an extra 22,000 places in TAFE without funding, would cripple TAFE provision in WA from next year.

Another issue of major concern with regard to the reduction in funding contained in this bill is that there is still, to this government's shame, a long way to go before the recommendations of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody and the ongoing requests of the Aboriginal community are implemented in relation to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander education and vocational training. In particular, the recognition of the legitimate and important role which the commission identified for independent Aboriginal community controlled forms of education and training continues to receive insufficient attention or support in policies and funding priorities. Without sufficient growth funding, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander community controlled systems of adult education and training will once again miss out on desperately needed funding.

This makes economic sense in the medium and long term. Of course it does because providing that support base is a lot cheaper than looking at the social outcomes of not providing that support base. Otherwise, this government, by shutting its ears to community concerns, is going to lurch from crisis to crisis and say, `We didn't know.' Remember this is the government that stopped community groups from speaking out. This is the government that more and more is threatening the funding of a large number of sectors across the community if they speak out or even give feedback to the government's policies.

In addition, we have had conversations and briefs from groups such as Tranby College in Redfern and the Institute for Aboriginal Development which indicate that capital works funds are of critical need for these innovative and essential service providers. These groups are very fearful that reductions in funding contained in this bill will make it near impossible for capital works funds to be made available, especially now that they have to compete with a TAFE sector which is going to be extremely cash strapped. Once again, this government has slashed funding without any consideration for the effects on the most disadvantaged people in our country.

Item 2 of this bill allocates a maximum of $21.5 million for off‐the‐job training. Yet these off‐the‐job programs are for conditional apprenticeships where the training provider is chosen by the employer and must be in areas of enterprising industries where economic growth exists. Clearly, job creation schemes should not be restricted to enterprising industries. Long‐term skills and socially useful employment are also found in community services, public sector employment, landcare and environment programs, tourism, accommodation and cultural industries and the expansion of plantation forests for the timber industry's long-term viability and the protection of old-growth forests.

With the current cost of apprenticeships we are going to end up with a situation in the not too distant future where skilled trades people will have reached the age of retirement and suddenly there will be debates in this chamber about the cost to industry of skilled trades people. We will have this debate about getting people into the country who can provide cheap trades and cheap skills for industry. We are walking into this with our eyes open, but it seems that the government is walking into this with its eyes closed. It is time for a change. I indicate that I will be supporting the opposition's second reading amendment. It is a very reasonable amendment, and I do believe the Senate should support it.
Debate interrupted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I inform the Senate that there have been some changes in the Howard ministry since we last met. I will table a full copy of the ministry, which includes details of representations in this place. I would like to take this occasion to make special mention of Senator Minchin, joining us as Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister. He will also represent the Minister for Sport and Tourism and the Minister for Finance in Administration in this place.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Vanstone is Minister for Justice. Senator Ellison is Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training; Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs; and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service. I congratulate Senator Troeth, who is parliamentary secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Senator Parer will represent the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology in this place.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Herron, the Minister representing the Minister for Family Services. Minister, do you acknowledge that two years ago the people of Australia paid tribute during the Australia Remembers celebrations to older Australians who made enormous sacrifices for this nation in times of great conflict? In light of this, can you understand the furore that has been caused by your government's changes to nursing home accommodation, which are universally seen to be grossly unfair and which penalise these same people? Minister, do you accept that the up-front accommodation bonds are grossly unfair?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is interesting for Senator Faulkner to bring this to the attention of the Australian people, because those very same Australian people were probably not aware of what was occurring under Labor's administration. Under the Labor Party, the capital expenditure on nursing homes decreased from $45 million to $10.7 million in the three-year period—a 75 per cent reduction.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Faulkner, to answer your question, no, I do not consider it inequitable, because something has to be done. As I have told you repeatedly, there is a time bomb occurring in this country in relation to health care, which you have ignored. It is a reality that the people over the age of 65 will grow by 48 per cent over the next 20 years. Senator Faulkner, I hope you are among them, because it is a problem that needs to be addressed for the Australian community overall.

When you were in government, Senator Faulkner, you just absolutely ignored it as if it were not happening. I know that with the constant replacement of senators on the other side a number of younger people are coming on. Senator Faulkner, you have been pensioning off your senators over there—all the older ones that were coming on—so that it looks as if they do not exist. But the reality is that there is a time bomb occurring in relation to the ageing of the population in this country, which you never addressed in government at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Herron, would you address your remarks to the chair.

—I apologise, Madam President. It was not addressed by the previous administration at all. As they did with Aboriginal affairs, they swept it under the carpet as if it were not happening. They have done it in health care and they did it in aged care because they knew they were going to face the dump. They knew what was going to happen. They took no constructive action in this regard. So something has to be done. We are basing it on fairness. We are basing it on capacity to contribute. We are basing access on needs, not means. This has to be done because we have to spend money on nursing homes in this country.

ANSWER.PARA: You are probably not aware, Madam President—as I was not until recently—that 40 per cent of people in nursing homes are in bedrooms with four or more people. That is what the previous government did. Forty per cent share their bedrooms with four or more people, with curtains between them. I was unaware of that, and I think it is to their shame that that occurred under their administration. Thirteen per cent of homes do not meet fire regulations, and 11 per cent of homes do not meet health regulations. Is that what you want to continue, Senator Faulkner? Is that what the Labor Party wants to continue in this nation?

I think the older people of this country deserve better. Under our administration, the government continues to be fully committed to supporting elderly Australians. This finan cial year the government will spend $3.7 billion on aged care, and that does not include pension payments made to our senior citizens. Labor failed older Australians when it ignored the care for the aged. We are determined that our reforms will provide an aged care sector which all Australians can be proud of for generations to come. Something has to be done, and we are doing it through these aged care reforms.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, I was disappointed that you did not acknowledge the sacrifices of older Australians that were remembered in the Australia Remembers celebrations. I would like to ask you, Minister, will you now listen to the Australian community, admit that on this issue the critics are right and resolve this nursing home issue by rolling John Howard in your party room meeting tomorrow?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
