ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Now we are really scraping the bottom of the barrel. They have no credible alternative. What does the Labor Party suggest be done about this problem? I would suggest that it is what they did about it before; that is, ignore it. Senator Faulkner could do a lot better than that but, then again, I do not think he could if that is the best that he can come up with.
—I doubt it.

—I agree with Senator Macdonald. I doubt it too, Senator Macdonald. I think it is highly unlikely that he could come up with any better suggestion than that because on their side they have another putative leader—the former Senator Kernot, who is showing her leadership credentials. You have to look only at the polls at the weekend. Why doesn't Senator Faulkner consult former Senator Kernot for advice on this matter? She had definite views on it. She is going to be the leader of the Labor Party anyway, according to the polls at the weekend. So I think he should consult the lady that he is seducing. (Time expired)

—My question is to the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training. I refer to the announcement last week that more than 10,000 Australians will have the opportunity to participate in work for the dole projects. Will you outline to the Senate the kinds of projects which young Australians will have the opportunity to participate in, and the benefit that they will receive?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator McGauran for his very good question. This government is proud to support projects which will assist young unemployed Australians. Work for the dole is a landmark scheme which will promote a work ethic and give young people an opportunity to engage in the community rather than being isolated from it. It has the strong support of the Australian community. Australians across the nation have embraced it. They want to support young unemployed people.

ANSWER.PARA: More than 10,000 places will be available to participants. The initiative is based on mutual obligation. It is fair and just that people receiving unemployment benefits from the community be asked to make a contribution to the community in return. The federal government provided $21.6 million for work for the dole. The number of projects has more than doubled from the originally planned 70 to 178. This is due to the overwhelming number of applications, which numbered 630. I am particularly pleased that 19 projects have been approved in my home state of Western Australia and that 834 unemployed people will be assisted by the scheme.

The range of projects in the west will include a City of Bunbury enhancement project, which will assist with environmental protection and local tourism; the Kununurra Botanic Gardens work experience project, which will involve the planting of native trees, landscaping, fencing and general beautification of the area; and improving the quality of life for residents of the Amaroo Cottages for Senior Citizens, including conducting activities for aged people, gardening and maintenance and administrative services.

Some sponsors have indicated that they are able to start their projects immediately and will be able to recruit participants in the next few weeks. Other projects will start over the next few months. Participants must have been unemployed for at least six months and not be in training or employment assistance programs. Those who are aged between 18 and 20 will work two six-hour days each week. Those aged 21 or more will work 2½ days each week. Each participant will receive their newstart allowance plus an extra $10 a week for any minor costs, including travel expenses.

In their submission, project bidders had to demonstrate their experience and credentials in working with young people, their ability to foster links with local community organisations, and also how their project will not risk local paid jobs. They also had to indicate how they would continue to support participants after the project had finished. Projects must provide participants with a variety of tasks, challenges and responsibility, and also opportunities to work in teams and mix with people.

A person may be required to participate in a work for the dole project only if he or she is in receipt of the full unemployment allowance and there is no risk to personal health or any contravention of occupational health and safety laws. Both the participants and the community will benefit from a work for the dole project.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you put this out as a press release?

—Participants will receive a formal statement of their involvement and achievement on the project, which can form part of their resume for work experience and assist in their job search efforts, Senator Schacht. Communities will gain lasting benefits, be it through the construction of civic facilitates, the restoration of valued heritage features, improvement in the environment and, importantly, social services which will help forge links with the community. I urge young unemployed Australians to call Centrelink on 132 850 or to contact their local Centrelink office to get involved in this exciting development.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Family Services. I refer to the statement by the Minister for Family Services on the ABC last Thursday when he said that it is a myth that you have to sell your home to get a bed in a nursing home. Minister, will you give a guarantee to elderly Australians who need nursing home care that they will not have to sell their homes?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Neal for the question. No, they will not be forced to sell their homes. Even before these changes, more than half the people going into nursing homes sold their homes; under Labor's policy, more than half sold their homes. This is the usual scare campaign—not based on fact but based on rhetoric—that has been frightening old people in this country. It is true that an old person does not want to be concerned with forms and regulations. When people become aged, they and their relatives have a real concern, and the disinformation that the opposition has been putting forth has frightened everybody in this country.

ANSWER.PARA: It is not true that people will be forced to sell their homes. Older people can choose to sell their homes and pay part of the money for an accommodation bond. This can be a sensible choice—and one that they have already been making—as the nursing home is their new home and most residents will stay there for two to three years. People who sell their home can use some of the money to pay an accommodation bond, knowing that most of it will be returned to them or to their estate later. They can invest the rest of the money to provide extra comforts and security.

Contrary to Labor's scaremongering, Social Security data shows overwhelmingly that older people who do sell their home do not lose their pensions and actually have more money to live on. Selling the home is one choice but by no means the only one. Like all financial decisions people make throughout their lives, it is important to consider which option suits them best.

People can fund a bond from other assets, and most residents who can be asked to pay a bond have other assets in addition to their home. In fact, most older people have other assets above the minimum asset level for accommodation bonds of $22,500. Most older people who can be asked to pay a bond also have income on top of their pension. They can choose to pay a bond as a higher weekly or monthly figure, or as a combination of lump sum and higher fee.

Different options will suit people in different circumstances, and it is important that they have flexibility. For instance, a typical older person who has a home will have some other assets and some other income. It might suit them to pay a small lump sum and then to make a modest periodic payment from renting their home or from their other income. The government is also looking at products such as reverse mortgages, which would enable older people to use the equity in their home to fund the bond without having to sell their home. We have already had some discussions with financial institutions about what might be possible.

It is back to the scare campaign and back to the disinformation, because that is all those opposite have to go on. They are ignoring the rapid ageing of the population just as they have ignored everything when they were in government. That is their answer to the rapidly ageing population and the crisis that is occurring in nursing homes in this country, which we inherited when we came into government 18 months ago. That is what we inherited. We are taking action which will be in the long-term interests of the whole of the population of this country; we are not just doing it for expeditious means. We have an answer to the problem. We are being constructive. We are looking to the future of this country and to the future of the nursing home industry which was run down under the previous Labor administration.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. What options does a person needing to go into a nursing home really have if they have to pay a $90,000 entry fee and their only asset is their home? How can a person pay that bond without selling their home?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a simple answer to that question: when the then Labor Party government brought in charges for hostels they set no upper limit on the charge, and we are merely following the same principles that occurred when the Labor Party brought in changes into hostels. So there is no upper limit. On the other hand, of the bonds that have already been paid, the average amount is $23,000. Senator Neal is not aware that that is the average. It is the typical scaremongering again: she comes up with a hypothetical question on a figure that is four times what is occurring at the moment.

ANSWER.PARA: There was no cap whatsover put on by the Labor Party when they brought in the hostel charges. Now they are trying to put before us these hypothetical statements which do not exist in fact. Nobody to date has paid that sort of sum. For Senator Neal to even suggest that is another classic example of disinformation. She is putting forward proposals that have not occurred and that are entirely hypothetical. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts and it relates to the government's recent decision on CD prices. How will this decision result in a better deal for long‐suffering music consumers? Will it reduce the level of copyright protection for Australian recording artists? And, most importantly, how does the government's approach compare with that of the opposition?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Synon for a very important question which throws into stark relief the opposition's policy on the issue and that of the government. The fact is it will benefit consumers very considerably because the Prices Surveillance Authority and its successor, the ACCC, have said that the price differential between Australia and the US on top selling CDs after tax is about $7. The bureau of communications has said that we could expect price reductions of between $1.60 and $3.

ANSWER.PARA: That has to be in the best interests of the consumers. It stands to reason: if you open up the market, if you destroy a cosy cartel, if you actually allow people to import what they want to import and not have to go through the record companies who stall them, then what you will find is that prices will find their own level. Indeed, what is more likely to happen is that lower prices will mean that there will be a greater sales volume and, as a result, there will be much better news for not only consumers but also retail stores and jobs generally.

Just as an example of the current price differential, my office last week identified a top selling CD by the award winning band Savage Garden—remember they were the band that was not picked up by any of the major record companies in this country and had to go offshore, which is a bit like silverchair who had to rely on Triple J to actually get promotion. That top selling CD by Savage Garden retailed for $30 in Canberra but on the same day was purchased in New Zealand for $18.90, in Los Angeles for $23 and on the Internet for $17. So there could not be a starker contrast between the price of CDs in this country and the price of one of our nearest neighbours, New Zealand.

What does all this say about the opposition? It tells you that once again they are gutless. They are not interested in the right policy outcomes. They are not interested in putting consumers first. The Sydney Morning Herald got it right today on Mr Beazley's performance, in saying he would oppose the government's changes, when it said:
This is the politics of the photo opportunity, unfortunately. It is not a serious response to a worthwhile micro-economic reform . . .
There are lot of people out there who support us, not least of those is someone who has been rather quiet this time around but, back in 1991, this is what he had to say:

ARIA has been conducting what I could only call a wicked campaign of misinformation about what would happen if changes to parallel imports were allowed in the record industry which, in my view, has been putting forward some demonstrably false claims.

Well, Senator Schacht was dead right then and he is dead right now. I wish him all the very best, if he can hang in in shadow cabinet together with Mr Crean, Mr Ferguson, Mr Latham—all of those who know what the right policy outcome is.

The tragedy of Mr Beazley's leadership on this and a whole range of other issues is that he simply is not capable of inspiring anyone or of setting an example. You do not have to take my word for it; just look at the front-page of Sydney Morning Herald last Saturday and there are the words of former Senator Kernot where she is quoted as saying, `Kim has got to believe a bit more than other people believe he can do it.' Have you ever seen a greater stab in the back after a couple of days of defection than that? But it did not stop there, there is more. She was talking about the ability to inspire and when she was asked if Beazley is a man to inspire, after a long and pregnant pause she said, `I think he is a man who is a decent person.'

Again, you could not have a less enthusiastic endorsement of leadership. It is quite clear that former Senator Kernot sees an overwhelming vacuum. She knows Mr Beazley is not interested in standing up for what even Mr Keating was prepared to contemplate at some stage until he was got at. The fact is that Senator Kernot no doubt understands that Mr Beazley is simply waiting there to be blown whichever way the breeze takes him. We will not do that. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, my question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Family Services. Is the minister aware that the Prime Minister has suggested that older Australians should consider renting as an alternative to selling their homes if they need nursing home care? Is it true that to pay the equivalent of a $100,000 up‐front entry fee people will have to get $450 a week for renting their home? Is it true that a person who adopts the Prime Minister's suggestion will have to pay tax on this income and will also pay capital gains tax when they eventually sell their home?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, it has now gone up from $90,000 to $100,000. Once more the rhetoric is not based on fact. It was Labor Party policy to introduce bonds in hostels and, when they introduced bonds in hostels, in fact only two per cent of bonds were over $80,000. Suddenly the norm on bonds now is $100,000.

ANSWER.PARA: This is fatuous nonsense. It is a scare campaign designed to terrify older people and their relatives; that is what it is about. It is not based on fact. In fact, the policy that we in government introduced in relation to nursing homes is no more nor less than the policy the Labor Party introduced in relation to hostels, and the bonds policy is the same. Under Labor Party policy there was no capping, but now in opposition they are suddenly finding that there is something wrong with this system.

The principle is the same; there is no difference in principle. Now, in opposition, they are pretending that it is appalling, that it is terrible. But they did it when in government. The principle is exactly the same, but now they trot out hypothetical examples when they, in government, produced no caps. Now they say that there should be caps and, if there are not, then inequities will occur.

Obviously, the bonds that are charged by nursing homes are agreed between the residents who are going in and the nursing homes themselves. It is up to the marketplace to decide what should occur. That is as it exists today and that is what existed under the Labor Party when they were in government. And now they throw their hands up in shock and horror.

I think this is a good question to ask of the Democrats because they agreed with that principle. Former Senator Kernot, now the leading light of the Labor Party, agreed that this legislation was fair and equitable when it went through. I think Senator Gibbs should go and ask the new member of the Labor Party what she thinks about this because she is the putative leader. According to the polls, she will displace Mr Beazley when she gets into parliament. So I think Senator Gibbs should go to former Senator Kernot with this question and ask what her attitude is. It will be an interesting question to ask the new member of the Labor Party should she ever get into parliament.

These are hypothetical examples designed to scare older people. It is a shame that the Labor Party is carrying on with this disinformation campaign because the principle is one they introduced in the first place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, the minister did not answer my question. Minister, I want to know whether it is true that a person who adopts the Prime Minister's suggestion will have to pay tax on this income and will also have to pay a capital gains tax when they eventually sell their home. And, while you are at it, could you also let me know what effect will the Prime Minister's renting option have on a person's eligibility for a pension? Can you confirm that they will lose their pension completely, and also their concession card, if they have rental income of $450 a week?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, here we go again. As to a rental income of $450 a week, and whether this will affect pensions, Madam President, there are about six or seven different questions in that statement. I do not know the validity of what Senator Gibbs is saying.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —No more will I trust Senator Gibbs than I will you, Senator Faulkner. So the putative statements put to me—

—Senator Macdonald asked me to withdraw on your behalf, Senator Faulkner and Senator Gibbs. I am happy to do so. Madam President, of course I will produce the detail of that answer for Senator Gibbs. Obviously I cannot answer six or seven questions in the minute that is allotted to me. I will come back with a definitive answer to all those questions that were asked in the supplementary.

—Madam President, my question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Minister, today's Sydney Morning Herald carries a report showing that more than 3.3 million Australian workers have been retrenched over the last decade under, firstly, the policies of the then Labor government and now under the coalition government. The average full‐time job loss figure during the Labor front bench's last four years in power was 275,000 full‐time jobs per year. Minister, I ask: are you aware that you have succeeded not in reducing that figure but in maintaining it—in other words, that it continues on under your government at 275,000 full‐time jobs a year? Is it not true, Minister, that in relation to job losses, you and the former government are as bad as one another? What is your government planning to do to at least reduce the rate of job shedding?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —As I stated earlier, Senator Lees, the work for the dole scheme is a good start in relation to the young unemployed. Those 10,000 positions will go a long way towards helping those young people get employment.

ANSWER.PARA: You might also have seen figures recently which show a slight drop in unemployment, which was most encouraging. In fact, economic growth over the year to the June quarter 1997 was 3.2 per cent, and I might say that budget forecasts for 1997‐98 are for economic growth of 3.75 per cent, and this augurs well for employment. Employment is forecast to rise by 2.25 per cent from the June quarter of 1997 to the June quarter of 1998. The employment growth we are beginning to see will help achieve this through‐the‐year forecast.

So I say to you, Senator Lees—through you, Madam President—that there are some encouraging signs in relation to the employment markets. I believe that the initiatives taken by this government in relation to work for the dole and various training initiatives—vocational education and training initiatives in secondary schooling—will lead to young people being more employable and a reduction in youth unemployment.

The Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs leading indicator rose in August and has been rising since November 1996. The Westpac Melbourne Institute leading index of economic activity continued to rise in July 1997 and has increased by 6.1 per cent over the first six months. The outlook for unemployment is an encouraging one. Unemployment is an important issue and is something that this government is committed to fighting. Senator Lees, you cannot compare this government with the previous one, which had a shocking record in relation to unemployment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, with due respect, while you are very keen on your work for the dole opportunities and while education and training are important, they have nothing to do with job shedding. We are looking at 275,000 full‐time jobs being lost in this country every year. If we can reduce that by just 20 per cent, that would make a significant difference to the unemployment rate. What is the point in continuing to train people for jobs which are no longer there? Minister, what are your plans to reduce job shedding?

—I thought I had mentioned in relation to economic growth—which is where you are going to get more jobs, Senator Lees—that this has been on the increase. As I said, budget forecasts are for an economic growth of 3.75 per cent. We have been seeing an increasing level of growth, and that is where you are going to get employment.

—My question is addressed to Senator Herron representing the Minister for Family Services and relates to the Prime Minister's suggestion that moneys could be paid as periodic payments for a nursing home bed. Minister, can you tell the Senate whether the periodic payment would be paid into a prudential fund and would be protected; or, can you confirm that the money would be retained by nursing home owners and used in any way they see fit?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Denman for the question because, unlike the previous questions, it is a very serious one. It is a problem that needs to be addressed because it is a very important issue which goes to the important aspects of the government's response in its reforms in aged care. This government strongly believes that older Australians are fully entitled to dignity, privacy and comfort. They certainly should not need to give these up just because they enter residential care, but all too often that is what is happening.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There is too much noise in the chamber.

—Madam President, the Labor Party hate to hear this because they left the nursing home industry in this country in a crisis. They walked away from it. Labor had an inquiry into this and appointed Professor Gregory to report on it. What did he report? In essence he said that Labor's response was a failure. They had cut funding on capital expenditure while not allowing nursing home providers to charge a bond. In 1992‐93, $45 million was available for nursing home capital purposes, but by 1995‐96 this had dropped to $10.7 million. That is a 75 per cent reduction in that short time. They wonder now, and they scoff that there is a crisis. Even worse, only $2.7 million of that was for upgrading old and substandard services; the rest was for building new services.
—Sit down if you can't answer!
—As I mentioned previously to Senator Cook, who probably was not listening, 40 per cent of residents were in rooms with four or more people.

—On a point of order, Madam President: when this question was asked, Senator Herron acknowledged that it is a very good question. It is a question that deserves an answer. Senator Herron was asked whether the periodic payment would be paid into a prudential fund and protected or whether the money would be retained by nursing home owners and used in any way they saw fit. As he said it is a good question, I think you could direct him, Madam President, to answer it.
—There are two minutes remaining, Senator, for you to apply yourself to the question.

—Madam President, I am only launching into the preamble to the answer. Senator Faulkner is suffering from relevance deprivation syndrome. It will not be long before he will be replaced as Leader of the Opposition in the Senate. It is obvious that he is not firing too well today.
—Senator, I remind you of the question.

—Thank you, Madam President. There is a crisis in aged care accommodation in this country and, as I said to Senator Gibbs—and to the opposition, because they do not seem to have got the message yet—that crisis is being constructively addressed by this government. There are many different factors that need to be considered in relation to the funding of nursing homes and I would happy to supply an answer to the points which Senator Denman brought forward.
—Why are you taking it on notice?

—Because I think the time must be spent to bring home to the opposition that they left us with this crisis. There is a dramatic increase in the number of aged people in this country. We have to be fair to the taxpayers of this country because we do not believe, as the Labor Party believes, that money grows on trees. It actually comes from taxpayers and taxpayers have to fund promises that are made. Ultimately, we are responsible to the Australian taxpayer who provides those funds. Labor spent money as if it were fashionable and could be plucked out of the air. We actually have to find the funds to address the nursing home crisis in this country, and it is a crisis. They are coming up with various mechanisms of hypothetical situations. I will be happy to provide Senator Denman with the detail which she has asked for. And I shall do so. Of course, I have not got it at my fingertips, nor should I be expected to have it.

BREAK.PARA: Senator Robert Ray interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Even Senator Robert Ray would acknowledge that one cannot walk in with the detail of answers like that. (Time expired)

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, are you aware of any nursing home proprietors seeking periodic payment in preference to up‐front fees as a means of avoiding paying into a protected fund?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Nursing home proprietors are very responsible members of this community who provide a very good service. But because of the neglect of the previous government there is now a crisis in this country in relation to nursing homes. If Senator Denman is aware of anybody that is taking advantage of this situation, I would appreciate it if she would forward the information to us so that that can be looked at.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Denman, we want to produce a response that is equitable, that produces dignity for the older people of the country and that respects their ability to pay, but also one whereby those who can pay should contribute to the development of more desperately needed nursing home beds in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for the Environment. I refer the minister to the recent article by Lenore Taylor in the Australian Financial Review in relation to environmental conditions for the proposed Jabiluka Uranium Mine within Kakadu National Park. For example, Ms Taylor referred to the fact that your condition that `ERA must ensure that the Jabiluka proposal does not have any adverse impact on the world heritage values of Kakadu National Park' has been watered down to the extent that the condition now is that it must be `reasonably practicable'. Is it true that of the 77 recommendations you made with regard to environmental protection in the mine proposal the vast majority have been watered down to such an extent that they are now virtually meaningless and their implementation will largely be determined by economic factors associated with the project?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —No, that is not correct. As the honourable senator said, I made in excess of 70 separate recommendations to my colleague Senator Parer, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, in relation to the Jabiluka proposal. As I understand it—and I certainly heard him say so on the radio—he has accepted all of them. I understand that he has confirmed that in writing to me.

ANSWER.PARA: This is an important investment for this country. It is expected to produce revenue in excess of $12 billion, with 87 per cent of it remaining in Australia. The estimate of the national economic benefit is therefore something in the vicinity of $3 billion. It is going to produce some 380 direct jobs, including 110 new jobs at Jabiluka. A sum of $210 million in royalty is to go to the Aboriginal peoples of the region. So it is a development with very major economic benefits to Australia and particularly to those living within the region. It is also a development that can be conducted—

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I raise a point of order. I specifically asked about conditions being watered down. I hope the minister is getting to the point about whether `watered down' equals `accepted'.

—I was saying that it is also a development that can be and is to be conducted according to the highest environmental standards. It has been approved on the basis that there will be no detrimental effect to nearby world heritage values. That is the basis on which I made my recommendations to Senator Parer. As Senator Margetts knows, it is my responsibility under both the convention and the legislation to ensure that that is the case. I have powers to ensure that that is the case.

ANSWER.PARA: The experience of the nearby Ranger mine is that uranium mining and processing can take place in that region in a way that does not cause environmental damage beyond the mine site. We have had 15 years of monitoring by the Office of the Supervising Scientist to give us confidence in that fact. In fact, this is probably the most closely monitored mining region of the world in relation to uranium mines. So the Australian people can have great confidence that this mining will be carried out without environmental damage.

In conclusion, I simply remind the senator that there is not a separate processing plant attached to this new ore source. Jabiluka will simply be providing an ore source that will be processed in the existing Ranger facility. Therefore, there is not the need for further plant of that type or for a further tailings dam, which in many ways makes it—I think that Senator Margetts would even agree—a much better environmental prospect than having to address a whole new plant, tailings dam and the like. I also should mention that because of the way it is being designed the envelope of the mine will actually be very small—something like only one-tenth of the size of the existing Ranger project.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. So it does seem that the minister is saying that `no detrimental effect' does equal `to the extent reasonably practicable' and that the current situation at Ranger where they cannot yet guarantee no release of radioactive material because they are still experimenting with artificial wetlands to try to leach out radioactivity is acceptable. Given that Senator Parer has specifically promised the Australian mining industry lower environmental compliance costs and in light of the changes made by Senator Parer to the environmental conditions associated with the Jabiluka project, how can the Australian community have any faith in the assurances given by you and your government, Minister, in relation to the protection of Kakadu National Park?

—Regrettably, that seems to be a set‐piece supplementary. The honourable senator obviously did not listen to my answer, because I said that we have every reason to be confident that there will be no detrimental environmental effect beyond the mine site. It is on the basis of that confidence—confidence that we have from all the best engineering and other advice that has come through the EIS—that it was ultimately approved. So I say to Senator Margetts that she should also have that confidence, because the Howard government is determined to maintain the strongest environmental standards. Mining proposals that go ahead have to get over a very high high‐jump bar. We do not apologise for that, because basically the mining industry of Australia has changed. It wants to grow and develop, and we want it to do so. But we want it to do so according to high environmental standards, and they are standards they are prepared to meet.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Family Services. How does the minister justify the circumstances that are causing so much concern around Australia where, for example, a daughter who has lived with a frail aged parent and cared for that parent for a number of years, but not five years, and managed to hold down a job at the same time must face homelessness if the parent has to go into a nursing home?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator West is the one who should be asked to justify the statement that she has just made because again it is part of the disinformation that the opposition are going on with. I think we should ask Senator West what their Labor finance minister, Ralph Willis, said on 8 November 1990.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Faulkner interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —That was this question. Senator Faulkner may not like it, but it is part of the answer to this question.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Cook interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is, Senator Cook, with respect. I will read what Ralph Willis, the then Labor finance minister, said:

ANSWER.PARA: New funding arrangements were introduced in January 1989 which enable hostels to charge residents entry contributions and ongoing fees according to their ability to pay. Under these new arrangements hostels can receive higher fees from non‐financially disadvantaged residents who are better placed to contribute to the costs of their care.
A range of protections are in place to ensure that all residents retain a set amount of their assets—

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Madam President. Madam President, you would be aware that Senator West has directed a question to Senator Herron in relation to the nursing home issues. She has asked a question about a specific example. I really do think that Senator Herron's attempt to read some quote from a former Labor finance minister, however interesting that might be, has no relevance to the specific question that was directed to Senator Herron by Senator West. I would ask you, Madam President, to ensure either that Senator Herron answers the question he has been asked or you sit him down if he is unable to do so.
—At this stage Senator Herron is leading to the answer to the question.

—On the point of order, Madam President, the relevance is that the principle is the same. The Labor Party does not know anything about principle; they have not got a clue when it comes to principle. Senator Faulkner cannot see the—
—Senator, you have strayed from the point of order. I think the minister is getting towards answering the question, setting the basis for it. He would need to be aware of the question as he proceeds.

—The point that I was making when reading out what Ralph Willis said is that the principle is the same. Senator Faulkner objects to that being read out because he does not want to hear it, but I will finish reading that out because it is relevant to the answer to the question. I quote again:

ANSWER.PARA: A range of protections are in place to ensure that all residents retain a set amount of their assets and level of disposable income. These measures are intended to ensure that individuals are protected from any form of financial exploitation. . . . The abolition of the subsidy to those not financially disadvantaged will enable Commonwealth funds to be targeted to financially disadvantaged persons needing hostel care and on those needing a higher level of personal care.
In relation to the question, it must be accepted that the principle that we are espousing is the same as that espoused by Ralph Willis when he brought in the legislation in relation to hostel care.

TALK.START.PARA: —That has nothing to do with the question.

—No matter how much Senator Murphy cries out across the chamber, the principle is the same. But, as I said previously, the Labor Party would not know what principle was. They would not know the difference, because they are running on expediency now. They are running on a fear campaign; a campaign to try to disturb not only the elderly of this country but also their relatives. The hypothetical examples that are being trotted out are part of the fear campaign that they are trying to bring into the community.

ANSWER.PARA: We have accepted the principle that those who can afford to do so should pay for nursing home beds, and we will not be resiling from that. There needs to be something done in this regard because of the rapid ageing of the population. The Labor Party accepted the fact that 40 per cent of those people in nursing homes were either in four‐ or more bed accommodation, often without the privacy and the dignity to which they are entitled; that 11 per cent of nursing homes had facilities that did not meet fire standards; and that 15 per cent—

TALK.START.PARA: —You've already given those figures.

—Senator Faulkner said we have already given those figures. That is true, but I have to repeat them because they do not seem to sink in with those opposite. They are thick. They deny that these things existed under their administration.

ANSWER.PARA: We are going to do something about them. We are not going to do so by printing money. We are addressing the problem by asking those people who go into nursing homes to contribute something to their own accommodation. That is fair and equitable. There will be protection against the hypothetical examples that are being put to me this afternoon. There is protection for those people when they need protection. We will provide that protection. They can keep asking about hypothetical examples—by all means do so. They will be addressed in the detail that I will be happy to give Senator West when we get the chance to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. The question I was trying to get the minister to answer was: what is going to be the impact upon often middle‐aged children if they move into their parents' home to care for a frail aged parent? They may well continue to work and hold down a full‐time job, but they will still be able to keep their frail aged parent out of a nursing home for a number of years, but less than five years. I wanted the minister to look at the impact on those middle‐aged children. Has the government chosen the time period of five years deliberately because it has evidence that most carers who do this crucial work do it for less than this time period before their parents become too fail for them to stay at home?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —We are happy to look at that and, as I said, I will come back to Senator West. I would be interested to know what proportion of the population is affected by those hypothetical statements. Senator West was not aware that, when the Labor Party introduced their hostel bonds, only two per cent got over that high limit, and there was no cap put on it. Undoubtedly, as for everything in life, there is a bell curve—there will be people at both ends of the spectrum, particularly the upper end of the spectrum. But it will be interesting to see what percentage it is. Senator West, I will get back to you with those figures that you have requested, and I will let you know the outcome of that in due course.

—My question is to the Special Minister of State. Will the minister please advise the Senate of progress in the government's arrangements for the election of delegates to the constitutional convention?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to report to the Senate that preparations for the election of delegates to the convention—and indeed for the convention itself—are proceeding according to plan. This represents the fulfilment of a very important coalition election promise, a promise which the Labor Party and the Democrats tried to prevent us fulfilling.

ANSWER.PARA: Nominations for the election of delegates to the convention closed on 8 October. I am delighted to confirm that 609 Australians were prepared to put up the $500 nomination fee and seek election for one of the 76 seats that will be up for election. This compares more than favourably with the recent Senate elections. In 1993 and 1996, there were an average of six candidates for every Senate vacancy; in this election, we have an average of eight candidates for every seat available at the convention. I think that demonstrates a very real interest in the constitutional convention, despite the Labor Party's attempts to pillory it. The number of candidates ranges from 174 for the 20 seats in New South Wales to the minimum of 23 for the six seats in Tasmania.

BREAK.PARA: There was a lot of talk from the Labor Party about how we would have an impossibly big ballot paper in New South Wales given the nature of this election. I am also pleased to report that, even with 174 candidates, the ballot paper in New South Wales will actually be smaller than the New South Wales ballot paper at the last Senate election. A manageable—

TALK.START.PARA: —They just won't be able to read it.

—They will certainly be able to read it. I would also like to say—and I think the government can also say this—that I am very pleased with the diversity and the quality of candidates for this convention election. With due deference to my Senate colleagues, I think they are at least the equal of candidates for the previous Senate election. We had a very important quality control measure in place.

BREAK.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —We said that no current federal, state or territory politicians would be allowed to nominate for this election. Australians should relish this election, an election without serving politicians running. It is the case that there are at least 12 former federal, state or territory MPs nominating. They may be suffering the relevance deprivation syndrome that Mr Evans spoke of, but I am pleased that former members of this parliament are running.

BREAK.PARA: The ballot paper packages for the election will be sent out on 3 November. Each package will contain a ballot paper, a booklet which explains in detail to voters how to vote and contains a statement submitted by the candidates, a ballot paper envelope and a return envelope that is reply paid and addressed to the AEC. All voters will get one sent to them in the mail. They will have three weeks to consider it and until 9 December to send it back to the Electoral Commission. On 8 and 9 November, the government will be publishing in all major newspapers around Australia a special insert describing the current constitutional arrangements, setting out the arguments for and against a republic and publishing statements by the chief pro tagonists—the ACM and the ARM—which I think all voters will find extremely useful.

I just conclude my remarks by saying that I am most concerned by newspaper reports about threats to certain candidates—in particular, the racist threats to a candidate in Queensland. The government is appalled by that and condemns it. There is absolutely no place for racism in this election. It will, like most elections in this country, be a robust election, but we utterly condemn any racist attacks on any candidates. I am delighted that Ms Nguyen in Queensland is running. I think Australians of all ethnic origins have every right to be and should be involved in this very important debate and in the election of delegates to the convention.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Family Services. Do you agree with Mr Doug Moran, Australia's biggest nursing home proprietor, when he said in reference to older Australians who will be forced to sell their homes to get a nursing home bed that `these people have to meet their dues'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the senator for his question. You will be pleased to know that Minister Smith is aware of the article in the Sunday Age which quoted Mr Moran. Warwick Smith today announced that there will be a review, chaired by Dr Sandy Cuthbertson of the Centre for International Economics in Canberra, in relation to the resident classification scale.

ANSWER.PARA: Back in June this year when the legislation was before the parliament, the government gave several undertakings in respect of monitoring the implementation of the substantial and positive reforms for aged care. Consistent with that commitment, and following consultation with the aged care industry and consumers, Warwick Smith today announced a review of the instrument used to classify relative care needs and allocate funding for residents, the resident classification scale. This review will ensure that the relative care needs of residents are being accurately assessed and that providers are receiving the proper amount of funding to which they are entitled. Dr Cuthbertson, who will be chairing the review, has tremendous experience in this regard. The review includes a detailed review of the Australian Government Health Service and an Australia‐wide review of hearing services in 1996.

The government's reforms address the unacceptably poor condition of too many nursing home buildings and provide adequate funding for dementia and credible quality assurance mechanisms. This review will ensure that the reforms are achieving the government's goal of a unified aged care sector—one of which all Australians can be proud.

In developing our policies for reform, the previous family services minister listened to what a very wide range of groups had told her was wrong with the system. Thirteen years of your government produced the neglect that we are now aware of. We have listened—unlike the Labor Party, who did not listen to anything. They did not listen to anything. Who was their Prime Minister? Does anybody remember his name? It was Mr Keating, Captain Wacky. He did not listen to anybody.

So we have inherited this terrible dilemma. This terrible problem has occurred. To do something about it, we listened to everybody. We listened to everybody who had some suggestions to make. But we will protect people. We will protect people when others try to exploit them.

I would certainly take notice of what Mr Moran says. I have met with Mr Moran. He heads up a very good nursing home. We listen to everybody who has a constructive suggestion in this regard because it is in the interests of the aged population of this country that we do so. We also have a responsibility to the taxpayer to produce an equitable system that respects the dignity of aged people in this country, that recognises the absolute explosion that is occurring with people over the age of 65 who will need to be catered for within the population as the aged care system comes under increasing demand, which it inevitably will.

There is increasing demand in the aged care system that must be addressed in this country. We are addressing it in an equitable fashion, in a fashion with which people will be able to cope, to cope with the numbers that are occurring in the population, which were ignored by the opposition when they were in government. We are doing something about it, and we are doing something about it constructively. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, is your refusal to condemn Mr Moran a result of his cosy relationship with the Liberal Party, which was exposed in Saturday's Financial Review ?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Moran—and he pronounces it `more‐an'; the senator cannot even pronounce the name correctly—and his wife have contributed a great portrait prize to this country. They have done a lot of great things for this country.

ANSWER.PARA: As I mentioned in the previous answer, we certainly listen to suggestions from anybody who has a constructive suggestion. It does not mean that we agree with everything they say, but we certainly listen to somebody who has a large sector of the nursing homes in this country, who has a very high standard of nursing home care, who has a very high standard within his nursing homes. We have a responsibility to listen to people like that because that is their right. I would welcome the suggestions that Mr Moran has to give to us because we must listen to any suggestions. I would listen to anything from the other side as well. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —At question time on 2 October 1997, Senator Faulkner asked me a question about changes to the procedures for certain travel allowance claims. I table an answer to the question and letters sent to all senators in relation to this matter. With the concurrence of the Senate, the answer will be incorporated in Hansard .

SPEECH.PARA: The answer read as follows—

BREAK.PARA: Senator Faulkner asked me to confirm that I had altered procedural rules affecting travelling allowance claims for senators staying overnight at a capital city having travelled from Perth.
I did not make a procedural rule under Remuneration Tribunal Determination No. 21 of 1995.

I wrote to all senators on 13 June 1997 pointing out that when claiming T/A for an overnight stay that broke a direct journey to or from Canberra, Western Australia and Northern Territory senators needed to establish that expenditure had been incurred because of that overnight-stay.
In the past, the department had accepted that a claim, duly signed by a senator, was in itself sufficient to establish that such expenditure must have occurred and claims were paid.

However, on 18 April 1997, the Senate department advised me that it would be more prudent for the department to require actual evidence of expenditure, such as accommodation invoices or receipts, to support the claims.
My letter of 13 June 1997 to senators indicated that I had accepted this advice and that from 14 June 1997 these particular claims must be supported by evidence of expenditure.

Senator Faulkner also asked if I was aware of a senator who broke his journey from Perth to Canberra by sleeping in the Melbourne airport and claiming T/A for an overnight stay. I am not aware of this. I am advised that it has not occurred since 14 June 1997.

I am advised that to the best of departmental recollection, such a practice was not reported to my predecessors. There is no departmental recollection of any written record of such an incident being reported to me or my predecessor. Some years ago a departmental officer drew to the attention of a senator that it was not appropriate to pay travelling allowance in such circumstances.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neal, Sen Belinda

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Senator Herron), to questions without notice asked by opposition senators today, relating to nursing homes.

This is an issue that is creating a great deal of concern and fear within the elderly population of the Australian community. It may well be that this government would like to paint the picture that they have done everything they can to provide a proper nursing home facility for those elderly people, but the situation is very much different.

BREAK.PARA: At the last election, this government did not add further funding to aged care, did not provide further funding to nursing homes, but, in 1996, took away the sum of $577 million from nursing home care in Australia. That is a pretty poor situation when we had Senator Herron getting up and stating over and over again what a poor situation nursing homes were in and what great need there was to provide further capital in those homes.

There is a real fear in the community. There is a very real fear by elderly people that, in a situation where they are elderly, frail and in many cases spending the last few months of their lives with intensive medical care in a nursing home, they will not only have to deal with all the problems, the difficulties and the stresses of that change, that very difficult situation, but also have to in many cases sell their sole asset—that is, their home, which for many people is the only asset they have been able to acquire throughout their lives—to get into that nursing home.

I find it interesting that, after all the discussion that has occurred and all the evidence that was taken by the community affairs committee, Senator Herron is stating that the average fee payable will be $26,000. I have to say that Senator Herron has a very, very poor memory. I remember when this proposition was first debated in this chamber and the opposition put forward the view that the fees would be about $26,000. We were screamed down by members of the government who said that it was a wild exaggeration and was certainly not what would occur.

It is quite extraordinary that some time down the track we have Senator Herron coming in here and claiming as a defence that, in fact, the fees will be, on average, $26,000. I do not know how many times we have to go over it, but obviously it has to be many times for the members of this government. Certainly, the average fees that are going to be charged are well in excess of $26,000.

In fact we were told by Mr Brotherhood, the Chief Executive Officer of the National Association of Nursing Homes and Private Hospitals—a group that I would not say had a particular brief for the opposition—that they thought that the average entry fee would be $50,000, and that would be for a single room. We also received evidence at that community affairs hearing that some fees would be as high as $90,000 and in some cases even more than that.

The figures that are being put forward by the opposition are not scare tactics. They are not untrue. They are a proper assessment of the effect of this government's policies on the elderly, the frail aged, who are trying to get into nursing homes—not because they choose to, not because it is a holiday camp, but because they have to because of their frailty and their state of health.

The other problem of course is that as well as this entry fee there are other changes that this government has wrought—other punishments that this government has inflicted—on elderly people, because at the same time there is now an additional daily fee payable of up to $37 for those people in nursing homes. I suppose that a lot of people would think that $37 a day was unfair for those frail, sick and elderly people. But the worst thing about this $37 is that, in fact, it does not provide additional funds so that those elderly people can enjoy a higher quality of care. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles, Sen Susan

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot believe that this is on the agenda again. It seems to be the same thing that keeps coming up time and time and time again. The opposition keeps on lying about what is happening in terms of aged care. Today, it has gone one step further: to try to imply that the prudential arrangements are somehow not going to work satisfactorily for both the occupants of nursing homes and those running the nursing homes.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to recap one thing that I have recapped every time the opposition have had the gall to bring this subject up. It needs to be emphasised because no matter how many times it is mentioned you cannot get it through their thick skulls. It is that when the opposition were in government they ran down the expenditure on nursing homes. They ran down the amount that was put into nursing homes and aged care by 75 per cent. In 1992‐93 a total of $45 million was spent on capital stock, but by 1993‐94 it had declined to $26.5 million. By 1995‐96 it was down to $10.7 million. That is a decline of 70 per cent in funding. It is absolutely and utterly appalling in terms of what is going on in the debate today.

The debate today bears absolutely no relevance to reality and I want to come to the main features of the prudential arrangements because I think part of the biggest problem that the opposition has now created, other than fear among the aged, is this fear among the beneficiaries of the aged who somehow see their entitlement to their inheritance being whittled away. The opposition clearly does not tell the truth on the way in which the prudential arrangements are going to be implemented.

The key features of the prudential arrangements are as follows: an industry wide fund at arm's length from government will be established as a trustee regulated fund with participating providers registering and maintaining an account; the full amount of all lump sum accommodation will be paid into and held by the trust for the duration of a resident's stay in any facility; and the size and strength of the trust will allow it to support borrowing by facilities in combination with the income stream from retention and interest which will flow to them. Each resident who pays a bond will receive a certificate from the guarantee fund acknowledging its receipt and undertaking to repay within the prescribed period if the resident leaves the facility at any time. The guarantee fund will be responsible for repaying bonds owing to residents who leave a facility. This is the part that the opposition are misrepresenting time and time and time again. They are saying that money will go in, never to be seen again. They know that to be wrong. They know that to be totally and utterly untruthful, but it does not stop them repeating it.

Providers will be entitled to draw down from the guarantee fund the monthly retention amount which equals, in a per annum rate, up to $2,600 for five years and they will receive interest on bonds held in the fund, net of all scheme administration costs. All the funds are taking out is $2,600 per year as a maximum amount. That is not what the opposition is saying.

Before making a decision to enter a facility, prospective residents and their families will be able to seek information from the fund on the compliance of individual providers with the prudential requirements. Bonds on deposit with the guarantee fund will be invested in accordance with agreed guidelines which will ensure fund liquidity and a matching of bonds with secure assets. Bonds paid as periodic amounts will not be covered by the scheme as there is no refundable component and entry contributions received by hostels before 1 October will also not be covered. Hostels for which the requirement to deposit all new bonds in the guarantee fund would cause cash flow difficulties will be assisted by transitional arrangements.

In closing I want not only to make clear on the record but also to restate the case that that is the policy for hostels that the Labor opposition put in place when they were in government. Why do they now misrepresent it so badly in opposition?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Knowles has once again reiterated this line that what this government is doing is merely an extension of what the Labor government did with respect to hostels. That is a lie that is being perpetrated time and time again by spokespersons for this government. So that it is clear to Senator Knowles and clear to Senator Herron, the absent minister representing the Minister for Family Services, who floundered around through question time today and never once addressed the problems in this sector: there is a major difference between hostel accommodation and nursing home accommodation.

SPEECH.PARA: The difference is that people choose to go into hostel accommodation. If they feel that they have reached a point in their life where whilst they are still able to care for themselves they would rather do it in hostel accommodation where services are provided they can choose to do that. It is a lifestyle choice for elderly people—just as they could choose to stay at home and have a member of the family look after them or stay at home and maybe have the home care service, domiciliary nursing and so on come in and assist them—to go into a hostel.

It is not a lifestyle choice when people enter nursing homes. They go into nursing homes because they are no longer capable of caring for themselves adequately and in many cases their family members are no longer capable of carrying on that task no matter how committed they are to that. It is an absolute distortion of the truth for this government to stand up and say that imposing bonds, which may amount to $100,000 or more, on people to get a bed in a nursing home is somehow simply an extension of what occurs for hostels. The fundamental reason our government did not implement this system for nursing homes was that nursing home care is essentially acute care which is not provided in a hospital. It is provided in a nursing home facility.

If you are going to run this line then you may as well say that if you are going to have bonds for hostels and bonds for nursing homes then you may as well have bonds for people who may end up in public hospitals because they cannot get a bed in a nursing home. Let us put a stop to all of this lying that is going on about this being an extension of what happens in hostels.

This is not scaremongering by the opposition. Everybody in this country knows that when the government introduced this system on 1 October we warned it would create chaos, confusion, uncertainty and anxiety. That is precisely what has occurred. Every day now you pick up a newspaper and read stories about elderly people and their families who are having difficulty understanding this system and who are being told they have to sell their homes to get a bed in a nursing home. If you pick up today's Sydney Morning Herald you can read an article by Francis Sullivan, the Executive Director of the Australian Catholic Health Care Association, who says:

. . . the Government should acknowledge its diminishing commitment to the elderly. Rather than bemoaning the parlous state of some aged care facilities and reducing funding of the sector at the same time, Mr Smith should rethink his approach to a sustainable and fair aged care service.

Francis Sullivan heads up the organisation that in the end accepted this government's proposed aged care system but recognised all along that there were inherent problems in it—problems associated with the bonds and problems associated with the significant increases in daily fees. It was the opposition that constantly said that this legislation should not have been introduced on 1 October. In fact, it should not have been introduced at all. The whole scheme should be scrapped.

If the government are finally going to listen to what people out there are saying then the best thing they could do for the elderly in the community is suspend this scheme, go back to the drawing board and fix it up. It is full of problems and it is causing mass confusion and anxiety out there in the community. Do not go around trying to suggest that it is some sort of Labor Party scare tactic. It is a fact that you are destroying the aged care sector. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eggleston, Sen Alan

TALK.START.PARA: —I am going to say that it is a Labor Party scare tactic. This is a fairly simple and straightforward scheme and most of the concern which exists out there in the community relates to the fact that the opposition is going around scaremongering and putting fear into the hearts of elderly people about whether or not they will have adequate care in a nursing home under these new arrangements.

SPEECH.PARA: The truth of the matter is that their care in a nursing home is not under threat at all. Furthermore, under the government's proposal, the standard of care they will receive in nursing homes will increasingly be better. The truth of the matter is that Australian nursing homes are in a very bad state and the ALP knows that. In the past hostels were in a bad state. Ten years ago, when the ALP were in government, they introduced a scheme very similar to this where people paid up-front accommodation bonds to enter hostels. As a result, over the last 10 years the standard of hostel accommodation—that is, the stage before nursing homes—in this country has increased dramatically. Hostels are now very clean, nice, pleasant places for people to live.

BREAK.PARA: Nursing homes, by contrast, are of very poor quality on average. For example, 40 per cent of nursing home residents share their bedroom with four or more people. If anybody in the Senate has ever been into a nursing home—and I have been into a lot of them—you would have found the beds crammed together often with less than a metre between them. Thirteen per cent of nursing homes do not meet fire regulations. That is a frightening thing. Eleven per cent of nursing homes do not meet basic health regulations. I think that is appalling. The government thinks it is appalling as well and that is why this plan has been introduced. The major purpose of the accommodation bond is to improve the standard of nursing homes. Unless nursing homes meet basic minimum standards they will lose their accreditation and they will not be able to carry on business.

A lot has been said about the fact that people may have to sell their homes to raise the bond to go into nursing homes, but of course that is not true. It is only after six months that the issue of a bond arises at all. As has been said before in the Senate, some 43 per cent of people who enter nursing homes do not survive six months. So, in fact, the question of a bond only arises for the residual 57 per cent. They do not have to sell their homes if they have a dependent relative at home—that is, a partner or a child.

For the remaining people, it is true that in the assessment of their assets for a bond their home is taken into consideration. If their home is sold, the money goes into a trust, as has been said. As Senator Knowles explained, only $2,600 per year can be drawn down from that trust over a maximum period of five years, which adds up to $13,000 over that five‐year period. The rest of the money is kept in the trust. The nursing home uses the funds to improve the quality of the accommodation and when a person dies, as Senator Herron alluded to in his answer today—and most people survive for only three to four years in a nursing home—the funds are returned to the estate and the relatives benefit.
Senator Quirke quoted some very dramatic comments from somebody whose name I cannot quite recall—

TALK.START.PARA: —Moran.

—Moran, who is a major owner of nursing homes in Australia. I would like to quote a few other people who are involved in this business. Firstly, Mr Jim Purcell from the ACT Council on the Ageing, on ABC radio in Canberra on 11 February, said:

BREAK.PARA: At the present time with the two systems, hostels and nursing homes you have . . . two different bureaucratic structures to look after them and two different sets of rules which have been very confusing. Under this new system a person can go into a residential care facility and with reasonable confidence will be able to stay there all their life with a high level of care they then need and progressively more complex level of care as their age or as their need increases. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibbs, Sen Brenda

TALK.START.PARA: —I find it incredible that Senator Knowles rose to her feet here today to say in an exasperated manner that we had the audacity to bring this issue to the floor of the Senate once again. If this is such a non-issue then why is it constantly in the media? Why is it constantly in the newspapers and on television? This whole issue is such an important issue to not only the elderly people of Australia but also their children and grandchildren. People out there are scared. We are not the ones who are launching a scaremongering tactic; this government has scared elderly people. Elderly people are absolutely terrified of what is going to happen to them.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Herron waffled on in question time today and he would not answer my questions. When I asked about the up-front entry fee being as high as $100,000, he denied this and said that the fees would not be that high. But there is no ceiling on the entry fee, no ceiling whatsoever. People who have assets worth more than $22,500 are the ones who must pay this entry fee.

The amount of $22,500 worth of assets is an extraordinarily piddling amount of assets. Most people have a home and the average, ordinary worker's home these days is valued between $100,000 and $150,000. That is quite in excess of $22,500. So of course all of these people will have to pay the entry fee. To be left with $22,500 they will be paying enormous entry fees into nursing homes.

BREAK.PARA: The government is saying that people can go into hostels, and hostels have been charging bonds. But you choose to go into a hostel. If you go into a nursing home it is because you need acute care. You usually go into a nursing home at a time when you are extremely sick and the family is distressed. A lot of people at that stage cannot make decisions for themselves and the family has to make the decision. If these people do not have a family and they are on their own then they are even more distressed, and who is going to make these decisions for them? They are going to be whacked into a nursing home and their homes will be sold.

It is often the case, particularly with older people on their own, that once older people lose their home, once they have nowhere to go back to, even if their illness has improved, they have no security. I have seen so many cases where this has happened, particularly to older women who have survived their husbands. They go into these places and if their health improves they have nowhere to go. Their security is gone—everything. They lose everything because if an older person does not have their home they have nothing.

Senator Herron did not know the answers to any questions today, and the advice of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) to people to rent their home instead of selling it is absolutely ludicrous. How can the average home bring in a rental of $450 a week? That is what the new Minister for Family Services (Mr Warwick Smith) said people would have to earn to pay for most of the accommodation. Maybe in Sydney you can rent a home for that—I do not know about rentals in Sydney. But to bring in a rental of $450 a week in Brisbane you would have to have a mansion. So the whole thing is absolutely ludicrous.

For this government to say that we are scaremongering is absolutely atrocious because they are the ones who are denying elderly Australians who have paid taxes all their lives, who have gone to war for this country, who have lived and survived through depression and brought up their families. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Synon, Sen Karen

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Gibbs, we agree that the aged care sector is in crisis. It is a group of people that we care about very much. This is why this government has been the one that has had the courage to make the major reforms that are needed to ensure that these people are cared for well into the future. We care—we care very much. We simply cannot understand how for 13 years you neglected this key sector of Australian society.

SPEECH.PARA: It is this government that has convened the Conference for Older Australians, which will be looking specifically at the needs of our ageing population and it is gross hypocrisy on the part of the ALP to suggest that this government does not care. The ALP is capable of saying one thing and doing another—it was the ALP which introduced accommodation bonds in hostels.

Because you neglected this critical area—despite dire warnings to the contrary—we have had to pick up the bundle. You turned your backs on the very people who have given and invested so much in this society over many years. How dare you have the hypocrisy to not only come into this chamber but go out into the community—which, I would suggest, is far worse—scaremongering amongst elderly people. Your disgusting neglect is the mess that we are cleaning up, and I think it is worth revisiting some of the legacy of the ALP.

The ALP reduced capital funding to nursing homes by 75 per cent between 1992-1993 and 1995-1996. It is worth having that figure on the record again. The ALP cut funding by 75 per cent, and you have the audacity to come in here and ask, `Who cares?' You deliberately ran down the nursing home sector. In 1985, Bob Gregory warned you, the then government, that $125 million per year was needed to upgrade nursing homes. Your response—zilch. At the last election, the ALP's policy on aged care ran to 200 words—half a page. This is how much the ALP, the then government, cared about the older people in our community. You should be ashamed of yourselves.

When we came into government, we found nursing homes that do not meet fire standards. Some 11 per cent of nursing homes do not meet fire standards, and 15 per cent do not meet state health standards. In 40 per cent of nursing homes, patients share a room with four or more. The ALP's record is appalling, but it is typical of those who sit on the other side and cloak their words with compassion and integrity but do nothing. The Australian public knows that to be a compassionate government you must at times take tough decisions—tough decisions that will see the sector strong into the years ahead.

I will cite a couple of facts that are often neglected in discussion of this issue. Under our reforms, 27 per cent of nursing home beds will be guaranteed for the financially disadvantaged. The number of people over 65 will grow by 48 per cent over the next 20 years. We just cannot afford to turn our backs on the perilous condition of nursing homes in this country. This year we will spend $3.7 billion on aged care, on supporting our older people, and this does not include their pensions. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.
