PETITION.TITLE: Uranium
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned strongly opposes any attempts by the Australian government to mine uranium at the Jabiluka and Koongara sites in the World Heritage Listed Area of the Kakadu National Park or any other proposed or current operating site.
Your petitioners ask that the Senate oppose any intentions by the Australian government to support the nuclear industry via any mining, enrichment and sale of uranium.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: Brown, Sen Bob; Calvert, Sen Paul; Lees, Sen Meg; Murray, Sen Andrew
PETITION.TITLE: Logging and Woodchipping
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
For permanent protection of old‐growth forests and all other areas of high conservation value, and for the implementation of tree plantation strategies.

This petition from the undersigned respectfully points out that: there is an increasing and urgent demand from the people, to protect all remaining high conservation value forests which support flora and fauna unique to Australia, thus complying with the United Nations Biodiversity Convention to which Australia is a signatory. We have a responsibility to future and present generations, and the necessary reasons, knowledge and technology to act now on the following achievable solutions.
Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate legislate to:

PARA.TAB: immediately stop all logging and woodchipping activities in high conservation value native forests;

ensure intergenerational equity by planning for the rights of future generations, and protecting in perpetuity all biologically diverse old‐growth forests, wilderness, rainforests and critical habitats of endangered species;

facilitate rapid transition of the timber industry from harvesting high conservation value native forests, to establishing mixed‐species farm forestry on existing cleared and degraded lands, using non‐toxic methods to protect ecological sustainability;

maximise use of readily‐available plantation timber for industry needs, using appropriate forestry techniques and progressive minimal‐waste processing methods, such as radial sawing, and wherever possible, reuse and recycle wood and paper products;

support incentives for nationwide employment in composting, soil remineralisation programs, and the planting programs of trees and annual fibre crops, inter‐grown with appropriate fruit and nut trees and medicinal plants;

encourage sensitively‐managed, environmental education tourism in appropriate forest areas, with full respect for natural ecosystems, Aboriginal cultural heritage, sacred sites and other sites of significance; and

progressively utilise technological expertise and resources transferred from the military sector, to help implement these tree planting solutions; and to motivate the international community to follow this example.

PETITION.PARA: And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Brown(from 216 citizens), Senator Calvert(from 29 citizens), Senator Lees(from 200 citizens)and Senator Murray(from 429 citizens)

PETITION.TITLE: Industrial Relations Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

The Petition of the undersigned shows strong opposition to the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill 1996, which aims to amend the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation Act and the Occupational, Health and Safety Act.
This Bill is opposed because:
1. Outlawing claims arising from `reasonable management action' is a direct assault on the long held principle of no fault workers compensation.
2. The Bill's definition of `significant contribution of work' is the toughest of any compensation legislation in Australia, and will see many workers' otherwise valid claims rejected.
3. Requiring Comcare to investigate the private life of every worker who makes a claim is a gross attack on civil liberties and will discourage people in genuine need from applying.
4. The Bill's provisions will in no way assist in the reduction or prevention of illness or injury in the workplace.
5. The wording of the Bill allows for wide interpretation, which makes it bad law.
6. There are no adequate financial reasons to tighten the Comcare compensation scheme to the detriment of all workers.
Your Petitioners therefore request that the Senate oppose the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill 1996 in its entirety.

PETITION.TITLE: Children
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament Assembled
The humble petition of the Citizens of Australia respectfully showeth
That we:

PARA.TAB: affirm the pre‐eminence of parents' rights to give wise guidance and direction to their children
affirm the primary and inalienable right of parents to nurture, educate, control and discipline their children

oppose the autonomous rights given to children by Articles 12 to 16 of the Convention, which may allow them access to morally harmful material and people (with no adequate protection) and which undermine parental rights and disrupt proper family life.

PETITION.PARA: Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate advise the Government to withdraw their support for the Convention on the Rights of the Child by denouncing the Convention and by indicating that the Government will not enact any laws which invade the primary and inalienable rights of parents in Australia.
And your petitioners as duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also table statements of reasons justifying the need for these bills to be considered during these sittings. I seek leave to have the statements incorporated in Hansard .

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statements read as follows—

PARA.EMPHASIS: NATIONAL ROAD TRANSPORT COMMISSION AMENDMENT BILL

SPEECH.PARA: The Amendment Bill will extend the operation of the National Road Transport Commission Act 1991, and consequently the Commonwealth Road Transport Reform Legislation, for twelve months beyond the sunset date of 14 January 1998, providing for the continuation of the National Road Transport Commission (NRTC) for that time. The proposal also allows the current Commissioners to be reappointed, and ensures that a review will not have to be undertaken within this twelve month extension .

The extension will allow time for a substantial Bill and supporting inter-government agreements, implementing the results of the Review of National Road Transport Legislation, to be settled between all Heads of Government.

The existing NRTC Act ceases on 14 January 1998. Unless an amendment is made to the Act, the NRTC will cease to exist along with the Road Transport Legislation it has produced: the Road Transport Reform (Vehicles and Traffic Act) 1993, the Road Transport Reform (Dangerous Goods) Act 1995, and the Road Transport Reform (Heavy Vehicles Registration) Act 1997.

The proposed substantial legislation implementing the results of the Review is a government priority. However, consultation on its form with the States and Territories has been protracted, and although most issues have been satisfactorily settled, Heads of Government have now been asked for their final agreement on all issues. Thus it has not proved feasible to introduce the amendment Bill in time to allow for it to be passed in the Spring sittings, even though a draft Bill has been prepared. It is expected that the substantial Bill will be brought forward as soon as Heads of Government agree to it, for passage prior to the end of the extension.
Introduction and passage of the National Road Transport Commission Amendment Bill in the 1997 Spring sitting is essential to allow for the legislation to be extended before the critical sunset date.

Effective observance of national road transport reform is a criterion for National Competition Policy payments for the States and Territories, and they are committed to the continuation of the NRTC Act and the national road transport reform process to progress this.
(Circulated by authority of the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, the Hon John Anderson, MP)
Telecommunications Legislation Amendment Bill 1997
To amend the Telecommunications Act 1997:
. to apply new arrangements to procedures for establishing an interception capability for telecommunications services in Australia, and the funding of this interception capability.
. to require the ACA, if requested by the Minister, to monitor and report on specified matters relating to the performance of telecommunications carriers and carriage service providers;
. to require intermediaries who arrange for the supply of a carriage service enabling access to the Internet to enter into the Telecommunications Industry Ombudsman scheme;

. to make it clear that the requirement for carriers and carriage service providers to provide pre-selection in favour of carriage service providers does not include a requirement to provide multi-basket pre-selection;
. to allow the labelling requirements for telecommunications equipment or cabling to be imposed on the agents of manufacturers or importers of that equipment or cabling;

. to require carriers to have a current industry development plan at all times, require variations to industry development plans to be approved by the Industry Minister and require the Industry Minister to notify carriers and applications for carrier licences of government policies he wishes them to take into account in preparing their industry development plans;

. to remove the need for carriers to notify land owners and public authorities of their intention to inspect land, engage in maintenance activities or install telecommunications facilities in certain emergency situations;

. to remove the need for carriers to notify land owners and public authorities of their intention to inspect land in connection with the installation of a temporary defence facility, or of its intention to install or maintain such a facility where it is impracticable to do so;
. to make it clear that the ACA can issue a telecommunications facility installation permit in a situation where a landowner consents to the proposed installation but a local council does not; and
. to correct typographical and cross-referencing errors.
To amend the Telecommunications (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Act 1997:
. to insert an inadvertently omitted definition of `eligible service' in subsection 40(4) in the same terms as the definition of that term in subsection 39(15); and
. To correct a typographical error.

To correct typographical and cross-referencing errors in Parts XIB and XIC of the Trade Practices Act 1974, dealing with anti-competitive conduct in the telecommunications industry and the telecommunications access regime.

It is highly desirable that the Bill be passed at the earliest opportunity to ensure that the new interception funding arrangements are put in place and the cost to the (budget funded) agencies is reduced.
(Circulated by authority of Senator the Hon. Richard Alston, Minister for Communications and the Arts)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator IAN CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I table a statement by the Prime Minister on his visit to the 28th South Pacific Forum held at Rarotonga, Cook Islands, from 17 to 19 September 1997. I seek leave to incorporate the statement in Hansard .

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows—
Mr Speaker, I seek leave to report to the House on the 28th South Pacific Forum, held in Rarotonga, the Cook Islands, from 17 to 19 September 1997.

The annual South Pacific Forum brings together the leaders of the region's island countries, Australia and New Zealand. It is a good opportunity for informal and frank discussions which are valuable in maintaining a strong sense of community and common interests in the region.

Australia's membership of the Forum is an expression of commitment to our partnership with the countries of the region. Australia is part of the region—not just because geography makes us neighbours, but also because we have shared interests in the region's stability and well‐being of its people. There are close links between Australians and the people of the South Pacific, through business, tourism in both directions, family ties and the many thousands of island people who have been educated in Australia.

Australia recognises that there are harsher dimensions to life in the South Pacific than the idyllic beaches and clear water that tourists enjoy in the island paradises. The other realities for island countries are their isolation, smallness, dependence on the ocean and vulnerability to nature. Australia has always been there to help in times of difficulty, as we are now for example in helping Papua New Guinea cope with severe drought.

My government is committed to strengthening that partnership. We have maintained aid levels to the Pacific, despite cuts in the overall aid budget. About 40 per cent of our total bilateral aid goes to the South Pacific. We are committed to helping island countries achieve their goals.

Our strong partnership with the countries of the region does not mean we will not sometimes have differences of approach and perspective. But we have common interests in working them through and reaching, if not full agreement, then at least understanding of each other's position.
A significant outcome of this year's Forum was leaders' endorsement of the Action Plan for economic reform drawn up by Forum economic ministers in their meeting in Cairns in July.

Many of the regional countries—including the Forum's host country, the Cook Islands—have made good progress in reforming their economies over the past few years. The Action Plan provides a sound and flexible framework for promoting economic development and will help the region respond to the challenges of a fast‐changing world.
The Action Plan requires countries to
. develop comprehensive economic reform strategies
. invite the private sector to recommend to governments measures to improve competitiveness
. adopt a set of best‐practice principles for public accountability and transparency of government finances and economic management
. pursue open investment policies consistent with APEC principles
. work towards a common goal of open and free trade, with each country deciding its own timetable
. rationalise and progressively reduce tariffs, while recognising the special circumstances of some smaller island economies.

Australia has been an active supporter of economic reform and sustainable development of the region's resources. We think the future stability and viability of the region's countries depends on them taking the necessary action now.

Australia has not foisted these reforms on the region. The island countries themselves have control of the scope and pace of reform. They will make their own decisions, taking into account their own circumstances and the nature of their societies and cultures. Australia is investing considerable resources in aid programmes to back up their efforts.

A second significant outcome from the Forum was the leaders' retreat statement on climate change. My objective in discussions on this topic was to promote and protect Australia's national interest. Some opposite have criticised me for this. I am not going to be apologetic about standing up for my country's interests.
Australia's negotiating position at the forthcoming climate change meeting at Kyoto has been fully protected. This was my responsibility as Australia's leader at the meeting.

The outcome was therefore good for Australia. But it was also good for the other participants. It was a fair outcome that reflected a consensus of views, not one on which particular views were subjugated to others. Despite the claims of some, no threats regarding aid were made or even hinted at.

As the statement emphasises, all Forum members share concerns about the impact of climate change. A visit to the region makes one conscious of the sense of vulnerability that the very small island states feel to the potential impact of climate change and rising sea levels. It is not, however, just the small island states who face problems. Changing weather patterns would affect us all, including Australia with our long coastline and vast rural areas.
Australia shares with the island countries a strong common interest in an effective international regime for a net reduction in global greenhouse gas emissions.

Australia's position is that any regime will be effective only if it is realistic and fair—and therefore has a reasonable chance of being implemented. There is no gain for the environment from an agreement which is not worth the paper it's written on because the commitments are not credible and the burden of efforts and cost is not equitably distributed. The bottom line is that an unrealistic and unfair agreement will not work. That is not in the interests of the island countries any more than it is in Australia's.

We firmly believe that any agreement has to provide the basis for involving the developing countries. Everyone who contributes to the problem has to contribute to the solution—and developing countries will account for nearly half of global emissions by 2010, compared with less than a third today.

In order to achieve a realistic, fair and environmentally effective agreement, Australia is arguing for different targets for different countries, taking into account each country's circumstances. That is what the Europeans have arranged for themselves in their `bubble'—we are asking only that the same principle be applied to the other countries, including Australia.

We are prepared to play our part in addressing this global problem. We are working to reduce greenhouse gas emissions in Australia, including through the Greenhouse Challenge programme. We are also providing climate‐change related support through our aid programme—with projects worth $45 million in the South Pacific. But we will not accept the economic burden of targets which mean Australia is required to shoulder a disproportionate part of the effort—and that Australians pay a greater cost than others for doing so.

The uniform reduction targets being called for—15 per cent from 1990 levels by 2010 in the case of the Europeans, and 20 per cent by 2005 from the Alliance of Small Island States—would have a dramatic impact on the Australian economy and people.

We would be penalised for being an efficient producer of energy and emission‐intensive goods—most of which we export to other countries that need the products for their economic growth. The impact on our energy intensive and resource processing industries would devastate parts of regional Australia. The job losses and dislocation of peoples' lives would be immense, including in the Illawarra and the Hunter valley in New South Wales, Geelong and the Latrobe Valley in Victoria, the Bowen Basin and Gladstone in Queensland, Port Pirie in South Australia and the Kwinana and north west regions of Western Australia.

New investment in energy intensive industry would be threatened, risking the potential in some estimates for up to 90,000 new long‐term jobs. According to ABARE, if Australia returned to 1990 levels of greenhouse emissions by 2010, it could involve an increase in petrol prices of up to 70 cents a litre, a similar increase in diesel prices, an increase in natural gas prices of up to 40 cents a litre and an increase in average electricity prices of up to 100 per cent.

And what would this destructive result for Australia achieve for the environment? The answer is: very little. Australia contributes only 1.4 per cent of global emissions. Even if we closed down every emissions‐producing industry, it would have virtually no impact on global emissions growth. Many emissions‐producing industries would simply move off‐shore. Australia's role as an efficient supplier of energy would be taken by others whose controls and technology are not as good as ours.

Our differentiation approach would also provide a fair basis for the future involvement of developing countries. The only way to bring them on board is to identify different targets, taking account of their different stages of development and their capacity to contribute.

This was an important element in the Forum statement on climate change. The need to involve developing countries was recognised by all Forum leaders. The Forum statement's call for the Kyoto outcome to provide procedures and time frames for drawing in significant developing country emitters in the future is a major step forward in the negotiations leading up to Kyoto. It is the first time that developed and developing countries have joined forces in this way.

On another issue of significance to the region's environment, I announced at the Forum that Australia is prepared to make a significant contribution to the building in Samoa of a new headquarters for the South Pacific Regional Environment Programme (SPREP), the design for which we have already funded.

SPREP has an important role to play on a wide range of regional environmental issues and Forum leaders are in agreement that it needs new headquarters to carry out its tasks effectively. We will also talk to the government of Japan about joining us and New Zealand—and other Forum countries which may wish to contribute—in putting together the necessary funds to ensure that the new headquarters are built as soon as possible.

We also discussed at the Forum the main challenges to the security of regional countries—especially their vulnerability to increasing trans-national criminal activity, including drug-trafficking. The outcome of our discussions was the `Aitutaki Declaration on Regional Security Cooperation' which provides for the enhancement of existing consultation and coordination arrangements to respond to these challenges.

Australia is already working constructively with regional countries to address these issues. In regard to the particular threat posed by drug‐trafficking, I hope that some of the work being done by the recently established Drugs Task Force will be relevant to the needs of the island countries—we would be happy to share the results of that work with them.

For almost a decade now the conflict in Bougainville has been a major security concern in the region. Forum leaders therefore warmly welcomed the recent progress made in restoring peace to Bougainville and noted the appreciation of the PNG government for the assistance of Australia and New Zealand which is hosting peace talks.

In my discussions at the Forum with the prime minister of Papua New Guinea, Mr Skate, I was greatly impressed by his determination to achieve a peaceful settlement of this long-running and debilitating conflict. I assured Mr Skate of Australia's readiness to support his government's efforts and facilitate the peace process. At Mr Skate's request, we have transported PNG government and Bougainvillean participants to the second round of talks in New Zealand. We hope that the outcome of the talks is another step towards peace for the people of Bougainville.

The Forum also expressed its support for the readmission of Fiji to the Commonwealth following the recent successful conclusion of its constitutional review. In my meeting with Fiji's prime minister, Mr Rabuka, I congratulated him on his leadership in achieving an outcome acceptable to all Fiji's communities. The news earlier this week of Fiji's readmission to the Commonwealth is very welcome.

One of the common interests which draws together the people of the Forum member countries is sport. Australians' love of sport, as both participants and spectators, is matched by the enthusiasm of the people of the island countries. The value attached to it is expressed in the declaration on sport and development adopted by the Forum.

I was pleased to announce in Rarotonga that Australia will underwrite the journey of the Olympic torch, on its way to Australia for the Sydney 2000 Olympic Games, through all those Pacific countries which are members of the Olympic movement. This will complement the work Australia is already doing under its South Pacific 2000 programme to assist the development of the region's sportspeople and maximise their participation in the Olympic and Paralympic games.

The Government has made every effort to include Australia's South Pacific neighbours in Sydney's hosting of the Olympics. The torch's journey through the region will provide an excellent opportunity for the island countries to take advantage of being in the world spotlight and boost their tourist flows.

The Forum also commended to its members Canada's candidature for the UN Security Council and appointed Mr Noel Levi, the former head of Papua New Guinea's Prime Minister's Department, as the next secretary‐general of the Forum's Secretariat. The Australian Government wishes Mr Levi every success in his new position.

In conclusion, I would like to record my appreciation of the excellent arrangements made by the Cook Islands government in hosting the Forum and for the skilful chairmanship of the Cooks Islands prime minister, Sir Geoffrey Henry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.
I wish to comment on the statement made by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard).

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you read the statement?

—Yes, I am familiar with the statement; it has been circulated before. I understand that the Prime Minister is due to leave later today for the CHOGM conference and will be away from the parliament for about nine days. CHOGM is a major international event and Australia should be represented by the Prime Minister; it is appropriate that he attend that international forum.

SPEECH.PARA: If he needs to take an extra day, then he ought to do so and visit Kuala Lumpur on his way back to meet with Prime Minister Mahathir. Last week there was an announcement in Malaysia that the Transfield bid for the patrol boat contract was lost and there were reflections as to the cause of this. I think all those reflections are essentially idle, but the Prime Minister, at a prime minister‐to‐prime minister diplomacy level, should certainly exercise the option of giving respect to the invitation from Malaysia and meet with Prime Minister Mahathir. I say that because I do not want any criticism levelled at the opposition that we do not think the Prime Minister has an important international role. We do think that.

In the globalised economy, it is very important that the Prime Minister, on behalf of this nation, exercises what commercial leverage he possibly can for the advantage of Australian companies to win key contracts overseas and for us to sell Australian built goods and services in foreign markets. This statement, however, relates to his visit to the South Pacific on 17 to 19 September 1997.

I was asked recently: why is it, when Australia must survive in an increasingly competitive international marketplace, that we do not have an internationally competitive Prime Minister? I think that is a fair question. We have a Prime Minister who falls well short of what one would expect in the tough bargaining of that international marketplace. I do not think it is possible to improve on the newspaper headline dealing with the trip to the South Pacific which said `Travelling PM on the last train to Klutzville'. That was the headline he got out of his famous cricketing trip to Britain in which he enjoyed afternoon tea with the Queen and morning tea with former Prime Minister Thatcher.

When he was in the South Pacific the Prime Minister was hardly able to be soothed over the leaking in July of the infamous FEMM report—a report which contained extremely condescending and offensive comments about South Pacific leaders. We only need to cast our minds back to the leaking of what was quite sensitive intelligence documents from within Australia to understand why.

Among some of the choice excerpts contained in that infamous leaked document was one which described a minister for foreign affairs of a neighbouring nation as a `compromised lame duck'. There was another which described an island state, one of our near neighbours, as having `ingrained bad habits'. The deputy prime minister of another of our neighbouring countries in the South Pacific was described as `an old radical on the make' and the prime minister of another of our Pacific neighbours was described in this report as `boastful and vain' and `drinking heavily'. The deputy prime minister of a principal neighbour of Australia was described in the report as `ever an opportunist' and as `a Methodist by upbringing who does not practise and enjoys late hours in nightclubs'. To complete the list, a deputy prime minister of another of our Pacific island nation neighbours was dismissed, in the terms of this report, as a `lickspittle'.

This piece of incompetence—the leaking of this document—was blamed on junior offi cials with no questions asked about the ministers to whom those officials report and who allowed the report to be circulated in the first place. This was a question of blaming the staff rather than accepting responsibility at ministerial level. If this was to be dismissed as the condescending attitude of faceless bureaucrats, it was just a foretaste of the condescending attitude of the Prime Minister when he got to the South Pacific on this trip in September.

The main feature of this prime ministerial visit to the South Pacific Forum was, of course, debate about the greenhouse effect on the South Pacific island nations, the island states of that region of the world. The Prime Minister waded into the South Pacific, I have to say, as an ugly Australian—bullying and insensitive.

We do have a legitimate position on the greenhouse issue to argue in international forums. It is appropriate that Australia be given some separate differential recognition for the huge contribution that we make through our use of fossil fuels. It is proper that Australia continue to make the point about a particular responsibility of developing countries to contribute to the greenhouse emissions problem.

But we do not advance that cause by not arguing with any degree of competence or sophistication for specific targets that would be appropriate for us as compared to the rest of the world. And we do not advance that cause by stomping on the heads of our Pacific island neighbours and generally behaving like the ugly Australian.

The Prime Minister used the $450 million Australian aid package to the South Pacific to bully the South Pacific nations into a Pyrrhic victory for Australia. The Prime Minister of Tuvalu, characterising the dilemma he was placed in by Australia, said:
Australia is a very important partner and we respect them . . . But being small, we depend on them so much we had to give in . . . there was no compromise. It was just `No, no, no, no, no'.

The Prime Minister had to play the spoiling game, because we have no alibi on greenhouse gas emissions any more. Prior to this government gutting them, we had real strat egies. We had good research on alternative energy sources and good research on how you become more greenhouse gas efficient. This is gone; all we have is the big stick.

The international consensus on greenhouse is moving towards mandatory targets. It is a critical moment for Australia. We cannot afford to be a rogue and stand outside an international consensus. Now is the moment of decision, and we should have been in a position to say, `These are the differential targets that are fair and just to Australia. You should take account of the fact that we save other people enormous amounts of emissions by producing alumina, for example, here in Australia and we ought to be allowed a differential regime and the regime should look like this.' Instead, Australia's reputation in the Pacific is damaged in the same way it is damaged around the world.

We are a nation that once stood proud and tall in this region around us. We had a government that was respectable and respected. Now we look like a bunch of amateurs. We send the village idiot in the form of the foreign minister all around the world to embarrass us and, when countries finally get a look at the Prime Minister, what do they get?

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. I ask that that reference to the Minister for Foreign Affairs be withdrawn. It is unparliamentary.

—I withdraw. In Jakarta, we get repeated 16 times the argument that Australia is not Asian. In Beijing we get bowing and scraping on human rights. In the United States and the United Kingdom they get a Prime Minister fresh off the last train from Klutzville.

SPEECH.PARA: We also now have an example of where the Prime Minister has not accepted an invitation to Malaysia, which, many think, has commercially hurt Australia. The coverage emerging from the South Pacific summit has been no kinder. Geoffrey Barker has provided some flavour of the trip which is becoming painfully familiar to those who follow press coverage of John Howard overseas. I quote from what Geoffrey Barker said in the Australian Financial Review:

BREAK.PARA: At social and group functions involving the leaders, he [Howard] sometimes seemed churlish . . . Howard appeared to prefer the company of his own staff and officials when attending public functions with other leaders, and seemed a diminished figure as [NZ Prime Minister Jim] Bolger assumed the role of the Big Man and peacemaker.

Then we had the much publicised side-trip to Tahiti to find accommodation better befitting the entourage, adding an additional $60,000 to the total trip costs overall. This occurred just the week before the government ran into its own problems on travel costs and in the context of constant carping about social security fraud.

There is another trip that the Prime Minister should make and make quickly—a trip to honour the retiring President of the Philippines, Fidel Ramos, when he steps down early next year. He is in his last term. Australia has major commercial contracts in the Philippines. The Prime Minister should visit. That will underpin our efforts on trade in that region.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Acting Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —We at last have an opportunity in this place, a month after this visit occurred, to look at and discuss the statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and to look at what actually happened during his visit, which I would categorise as perhaps one of the most unsuccessful visits that a Prime Minister of this country has ever been undertaken.

SPEECH.PARA: Many words have been used in the press to describe the impression that his foray into the South Pacific has left with us. From memory, words like `embarrassing', `inept', `bullying' and `ham‐fisted' were used. In terms of coverage, I think it was some of the most negative reporting that any Prime Minister has had to face back here in Australia after a visit. Indeed, if you pulled out a thesaurus and looked up the word `fiasco', I think you would come pretty close to summing up the occasion.

We believe that the entire exercise was not only an embarrassment but that it lacked the sort of diplomacy that one would have expected from a leader—in particular, from a leader at an international conference. I wonder what type of instructions are being given to those who are going to Kyoto. Will we see another bullying performance like the one in the South Pacific?

I think we should have recognised quite some months ago that Australia's standing in the South Pacific was considerably damaged by the leaking of the Treasury's so-called intelligence document—a document that should never have existed, let alone have been circulated and left in a place that meant it could be publicised. But how do you maintain harmonious relations with your neighbours—I will not do all of this; it has been done by the previous speaker, Senator Cook—after calling partners `lickspittle', which is one of the memories I have of that document?

Let us look at the South Pacific Forum, where things did not exactly get off to a good start. I begin by quoting the Prime Minister's words from a press conference of 17 September when Mr Howard told journalists:

There is nonetheless quite a bit of debate about the science, so far as greenhouse effects are concerned, and it's not all one way. It is not all—how should one put it—the apocalyptic view of the world and of life.

Here we have a Prime Minister, our nation's chief, on his very first day at an international forum, disputing solid science and putting himself at odds with every other leader of every other developed country in the world. He put himself at odds not only with them but also with his colleague Senator Hill, who in this place has acknowledged that we do have something in front of us that is of major significance.

It only got worse as the conference went on. Mr Howard could, I think, have been best described as `The Solitary Man' as he went into intimidation mode. He told the people in the countries perhaps most at threat—the South Pacific is, indeed, at the cutting edge of the greenhouse effect—`Sorry, you have to play it Australia's way or else.' We do not know exactly what his words were, but we suspect his pressure had something to do with Australia's aid or trade. He ignored the island nations' greenhouse concerns, their genuine concerns for their survival, and peddled out, yet again, his flawed figures from that famous ABARE model—the model that was paid for by those who are most interested in Australia and, indeed, the world doing nothing.

Our coal industry will be just as hard‐hit by the changes if the world signs up. Regardless of what Australia does, the coal industry will still be hard‐hit if the amount of coal the world is using is reduced. If Australia sits on its hands and says, `Sorry, we're not playing. We're not doing anything,' our coal industry will need to look seriously at restructuring. As some of our oil producing companies have done, it will have to look at divesting, reinvesting and changing direction. It will have to look at alternative energy sources. But none of these issues were raised. Mr Howard just came back with the ABARE model. Basically, he followed Brian Fisher's line. Mr Fisher has been quoted as saying that it would be better if we let the island nations sink and relocated their populations as refugees rather than Australia getting involved.

But let us look at the Prime Minister's statement—this catalogue I would describe as absolute nonsense—we finally got to look at officially today. No wonder it has taken so long for us to get it. I quote again:
We have a shared interest in the region's stability and wellbeing of its people.
Shared interest? There is absolutely no interest in these nations' most critical issue—the one they raised with our Prime Minister—no interest at all. The Prime Minister went on to say:
Australia has always been there to help in times of difficulty.

Aren't the threats that they are facing from increased and more regular storms, increased storm surges and urban flooding difficulties? Aren't they facing times of difficulty? While they are facing times of difficulty we want to increase our greenhouse gas emissions! Mr Howard said:
A visit to the region makes one conscious of the sense of vulnerability that the very small island states feel to the potential impact of climate change and rising sea levels.

Obviously Mr Howard is aware of the problem. Why doesn't his government give a damn about it? Why was he prepared to go to the forum and use bullyboy tactics to stop any consensus—indeed, any decision or statement at all—that had greenhouse gas emissions as part of it?

Let us look at some of the nonsense from ABARE. The modelling assumes there are no technological changes that can be put in place to encourage energy efficiency; that there can be no switching to renewable energy sources and that there can be no growth in employment in the sustainable energy industry. ABARE leaves all that out of the model very conveniently. The ABARE model assumes that carbon emissions can be cut solely by the blunt instrument of a massive carbon tax with no other tax changes. The massive amount of money which will be raised will simply be put into someone's back pocket or a black hole somewhere, and that will be the end of it.

Indeed, ABARE goes so far as to claim that a carbon tax of $900 per tonne of carbon would be needed to take us down below the 1990 levels. No‐one else in the world is using figures even vaguely like these. They are so unreasonable that we will be a laughing‐stock if we go over to Kyoto and trot them out yet again. Mr Howard enthused about the Sydney 2000 Olympics. He said:
I was pleased to announce Australia will underwrite the journey of the Olympic torch through all those Pacific countries which are members of the Olympic movement.

All I could think of while I was reading that statement was the torch slowly glugging its way across the Pacific and not burning very brightly once it got to Australia. As I read this report of the visit all I can think of is that Australia can best be categorised as the neighbour from hell. I offer this quote:

There will be a lot of anger in the Australian community, right across the political spectrum, of this extremely self‐interested, selfish act which is a blatant indifference to the concerns of people who live in the South Pacific.

Where did these words come from? These are the words of John Howard, then in opposition, condemning nuclear testing in the Pacific. Somebody should tell Mr Howard that there is a lot of anger in the Australian community and, indeed, amongst the nations of the South Pacific over his totally irresponsible, flawed and dangerous greenhouse gas position.

BREAK.PARA: Will we go to Kyoto with the research we are using presently and try to hang onto the claim that for some reason we need to be treated as a special case? Will we ignore the fact that the 1990 figure we will be asked to get back to, or even five or 10 per cent below, is also very bad on the world scale? Back in 1990 we were one of the worst polluters. It is not as if we will suddenly be asked to reduce to the emission levels of Luxembourg or Japan; we are being asked to go back to what was already quite a poor position. But we do not hear any of that.

If we go to Kyoto ignoring all the new jobs that are waiting to be created, waiting to be done—whether it is insulating homes or whether it is research into new technology—we really will be a laughing‐stock. If we expect differentiation we could end up with a tougher target than everybody else. If we keep pushing the line that some nations are special cases and that all should be considered on their merits, Australia could very well end up in a lot tougher position and have a lot tougher target to meet than any other country. I condemn the Howard government's arrogant and irresponsible approach to climate change negotiations, and I condemn its indifference to our South Pacific neighbours.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —The statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) is most remarkable for what it does not contain—that is, an analysis of his shortcomings in the interests of Australia when he went to the South Pacific Forum. He let down our Pacific neighbours, as earlier speakers have outlined, and he let down this nation at the same time.

SPEECH.PARA: In particular, the Prime Minister let down future generations of Australians because, when we are talking about global warming, we are not talking about ourselves. We are talking in the main about the interests of the next half dozen generations of people on this planet, and that includes every Australian born in this country now or in centuries to come in the succeeding generations. They are being affected by our decisions on whether to curtail or at least curb greenhouse gas emissions.

BREAK.PARA: There is some debate about whether Australians per head of population are the worst polluters of greenhouse gases on the planet. Certainly, we are amongst the worst three polluting countries on the planet. So we have a very real domestic need to head the world innovation and turn around this phenomenon. But instead of that, we have a government, and in particular a Prime Minister, which is unable to take the wise counsel of the now thousands of the world's most eminent scientists and has instead opted for the counsel of a very constricted section of the business community—in particular, the coal and aluminium industries in Australia.

The argument those industries have put is that it will affect investment and in particular jobs in Australia. The argument they cannot refute is that not getting into energy alternatives—in particular, sun based alternatives for the future—is losing far more jobs out of Australia to other more innovative countries and is losing more investment than their investments will ever account for. So the first thing that needs to be said is that we need to be an innovative, far‐thinking society instead of a society—as represented by our Prime Minister and the industries he is taking heed of—that is blinkered, small‐minded and cuts the ground from under future generations.

When the Prime Minister went to the South Pacific, he diminished this country almost every day of his stay. The nadir of his visit was when he indicated to the South Pacific nations that, in effect, they could sink before he would cut across the interests of the coal and aluminium industries in this country. They could go under; it was thumbs down to those tiny nations.

One would have thought that the way you treat your nearest—your neighbours—ultimately says how you will treat yourself in the long run. On this occasion, we had a Prime Minister and a delegation to the South Pacific that came nowhere near the mark. It was an embarrassment. It was a denouement for Australian diplomacy.

It is notable that, at about the same time, New Zealand was taking the lead in negotiations for a settlement in Bougainville—a major and prolonged dispute in our neigh bourhood that Australia should have been acting on in a more equitable fashion long ago. Japan has also taken the initiative.

In the wake of this disastrous visit to the South Pacific by John Howard representing Australia, Japan has had the welcome mat out to the same nations at a particularly accommodating meeting in Japan. Who can blame the South Pacific nations if they think New Zealand and Japan are acting in their interests? They would just have to think of the selfishness displayed by Prime Minister Howard during his visit to the South Pacific Forum.

It is a notable shortcoming of this Prime Minister that he cannot understand the long term. It is a notable shortcoming that he is unable to relate to the plight of other people. When he is unable to relate to the plight of people in the South Pacific nations—who are faced with the end of their nations as they know them as a result of global warming—you have to fear for his ability to relate to the Australian people themselves. That is a matter coming under increasing question. That is a matter that is going to come under very harsh judgment in the coming 18 months or so in the run to the next election.

I have to say—and I know many Green voters felt this way—that it was a matter of acute embarrassment to have Prime Minister Howard failing to relate to our long-term neighbours, our long-term friends and the long‐term interests of our friends in the South Pacific. It was a very sad period in Australian diplomacy, and one cannot expect that pattern is going to change.

I must add that, from a very small position in this Senate, I have been able to bring forward from the Greens one positive alternative to the polluting fossil fuel industry of the past—that is, the Sun Fund Bill 1997 , which is before the Senate now. It has been before a committee and we await its report. If, from the meagre resources of the Greens, we can come forward with a positive and attractive idea like that—to not only stimulate alternative energy but to stimulate thousands of jobs in this country through a small change in the way the government allocates finances for the production of energy—why can't the government do far better still?

The government has had very well thought out submissions from Greenpeace, the Australian Conservation Foundation, the Democrats, the Greens and a very impressive array of scientists in this country and internationally. The problem is the mind-set of the Prime Minister, his advisers, his colleagues and his cabinet. The government is not open. It is not accommodating to new ideas. Sadly, it is not even accommodating to the exigencies of nations which fear for their very existence because of the failure of countries like Australia to be good international citizens and, in particular, to be citizens who have their mind on the interests of future generations.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade: Joint

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon, Sen David

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, I present the following reports of the committee, together with minutes of proceedings: Sharpening the focus , a report on a seminar on the Simons committee report, 11 July 1997, Canberra, and From empire to partnership , a report on a seminar on the Commonwealth of Nations, 20 August 1997, Canberra. I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the reports.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the reports.

I have great pleasure today in tabling two reports by the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. Both of these reports are the result of seminars held by the joint standing committee on these specific topics over the winter period.

The seminars are a very useful way to look at a foreign policy or defence issue in a timely fashion. While it certainly does not permit the same level of detailed scrutiny as a full inquiry, the seminar process does allow the committee to gather together a diverse range of individuals and groups to discuss a particular issue. The dialogue between all of the participants is extremely constructive, and one of the major benefits at each of the seminars was the interchange of ideas between people from quite different backgrounds and points of view. The committee has held a number of these seminars since July 1996, and we have had very considerable positive feedback on the format and the processes they follow.

On behalf of the committee, I would like to thank all of the government officials, members of the diplomatic corps, business representatives, academics, members of the NGO community, members of parliament and members of the general community who attended these seminars and contributed so much to their success. My thanks go also to those members of the joint standing committee who participated in these seminars. I would like to make some brief comments about each of the reports today and hopefully expand on these in the main committee at a future date.

The first seminar during the recent winter break dealt with a review of the Australian aid program. The seminar was held at the request of the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Downer), who asked the committee to conduct a seminar on the report of a review committee chaired by Mr Paul Simons. That report was released in early May and the minister undertook that there would be a period of wide public consultation before the report was considered by government. Our seminar was one of a number of seminars and conferences held around the country dealing with aspects of the Simons report.

The committee was very pleased to have all of the members of the Simons committee present at the seminar—Paul Simons, Gaye Hart and Cliff Walsh—and also the Director‐ General of AusAID, Trevor Kanaley, and a significant number of his staff. We were also pleased that the head of the Development Assistance Committee of the OECD, Mr James Michel, who was visiting Australia at the time, was able to join us for some of the discussions.

The Simons review is the first major review of the development assistance program since the Jackson report of the early 1980s. It was the general feeling that reviews of this kind need to be done somewhat more regularly—a 13‐year gap is too great. One of the recommendations of the Simons committee endorsed by the joint standing committee was for the establishment of an advisory board to assist AusAID management in the direction of the development assistance program. Hopefully, with such input, the process of finetuning the aid program will be simplified for all involved.

The seminar did not set out to cover all aspects of the Simons report. Anyone who has examined that report will know that it is an extremely comprehensive examination of the aid program. However, the seminar did look at issues such as overseas trends in development assistance; refocusing the aid program, taking into account geographic and sectoral factors; soft loans and concessional financing; the question of whether Australian aid should be untied; and the whole issue of NGOs and the Australian aid program.

The Simons committee's report carries the title, One clear objective: poverty reduction through sustainable development. The joint committee supports the concept that the prime motivation for a development assistance program is humanitarian. The committee did have some concerns, however, that too narrow a definition of poverty may be adopted. Development assistance encompasses a range of activities designed to improve the standard of living of people in developing countries whether through infrastructure projects, educational activities, assistance to micro enterprises as well as immediate assistance to those suffering from hunger and homelessness. The committee agrees that assistance should be through sustainable development activities. The committee also acknowledges that other policy objectives may be met through the aid program without detracting from its fundamental purpose.

The joint standing committee has made 15 recommendations in all regarding the Simons review and the general running of the aid program. The committee remains concerned about the obvious resource implications for AusAID—both staffing and budgetary—should all of the recommendations of the Simons review be instituted. This will obviously be a matter of great importance for the government at this time of budgetary restrictions, but it will have to be addressed if Australia is to maximise the impact of its aid budget.

The second report being tabled today concerns the Commonwealth of Nations and, given the imminent Commonwealth Heads of Government meeting in Edinburgh, it is particularly relevant and timely. The committee was interested in examining whether the Commonwealth remains relevant in the post‐Cold War period, and indeed whether it is of even more relevance given the momentous changes in the international arena that have occurred over the last decade. The Commonwealth has changed in many ways since the days when it was the British Commonwealth, and it was quickly apparent to the committee that a number of misconceptions still exist about its organisation.

The seminar covered topics such as the role of CHOGM and other meetings; public perceptions of the Commonwealth; the `unofficial Commonwealth', that is, the vast number of non‐government organisations that exist among Commonwealth countries; the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association; trade and investment issues; and human rights and the Commonwealth. Time does not permit me to go into any depth on these issues here today, but I would recommend the report and the transcript of the seminar to all who have an interest in the Commonwealth and the remarkably diverse benefits that flow from it to Australia.

I would like to conclude my remarks today by once again thanking all who gave of their time to participate in these seminars. The committee found the seminar process to be a most useful means of exploring issues in a comparatively short time frame and believes the reports contain a number of issues that merit consideration by government. I commend the two reports to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Conroy, Sen Stephen

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, I present its report on an inquiry into the role of the Australian Electoral Commission in conducting industrial elections, together with extracts of minutes and a transcript of evidence.
—by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

I would initially like to thank the committee staff who did an excellent job in preparing this report, and in particular David Dick who was seconded across to work on this report and who was dropped into the middle of what at times were very lively committee meetings and public hearings.

This report puts forward a number of recommendations, in particular to do with union election balloting procedures. It makes a number of recommendations to do with the style of envelope which, while it may seem a very small issue to the majority of Australians listening today, is important for the integrity processes in such ballots.

It also makes a series of recommendations to do with the access to the rolls in union elections, the quality of the rolls, the access that the returning officer has to a roll, and the access that a returning officer has to deal with what is potentially a roll with many addresses that are missing. This is something that is not uncommon in a union election because members tend to move—from my own experience, many times—during the two or three years in between elections taking place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is this a preselection?

—A preselection? Senator Ellison, I wouldn't start! One of the hard things that the committee had to grapple with was wanting to balance the rights of members to have access to the roll, so that the democratic process of conducting an election could take place, with the capacity not to disenfranchise members of the union in terms of having a say. The committee tossed that around a bit and came to quite a balanced outcome in the end for both democratic process and voter eligibility.

SPEECH.PARA: We recommend that a set of model rules be developed on balloting procedures, that it not be mandatory for unions to adopt it, but that unions be encouraged to move to the model rules. That would certainly see a cost saving for the AEC if that were to be adopted. We received much evidence about the excellent job that has been done by the Electoral Commission, over many years and in sometimes quite trying circumstances, and because of that I think the committee members were swayed into supporting the AEC's ongoing participation.

There was discussion at various times about whether or not the AEC should charge unions for use of AEC resources, but on balance it was felt that the role that they provide and the excellent service was balanced by the need to maintain as much democratic process as possible for the unions, so that people were sure that the integrity of the process was being adhered to.

Probably the most significant recommendation that we are making is for the AEC to be able to be involved in non‐industrial elections. That means that an organisation like the NRMA, which recently had a bit of a hiccup with one of its ballots, would be able to approach the AEC and ask it to conduct its elections on a fee for service basis. The AEC could then charge them a fee. Everybody would be happy that the integrity of the AEC could be put to work in an NRMA ballot or one for a similar non‐industrial organisation. I think that is an excellent recommendation and I hope that the government moves as quickly as the legislative program allows and that we see legislation some time over the next 12 months to allow the AEC to work on those matters. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the request of Senator Abetz, for the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties, I present the committee's 10th report, together with submissions, transcripts of evidence and minutes of proceedings, and I seek leave to move a motion in relation to this report and to have my tabling statement incorporated in Hansard .

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows—

The report I have just tabled deals with two treaties which were tabled on 17 June 1997, and all but two of the treaties tabled on 26 August 1997. The latter will be the subject of later reports: the Australia‐Indonesia Maritime Delimitation Treaty, and the economic and commercial cooperation agreement with Kazakhstan. As none of the treaties dealt with in this report raised particular issues of concern to the committee, in each case we have recommended ratification as proposed.

However they do raise a more general issue for the committee and for the parliament, one to which frustratingly we seem to refer at the tabling of each report. In his statement to the house on 2 May 1996 about the reforms to the treaty‐making process, the Minister for Foreign Affairs said in part (and I quote):
"They will . . . ensure that every Australian individual and interest group with a concern about treaty issues has the opportunity to make that concern known. Consultation will be the key word."
The committee agrees with the minister but takes a strong view that consultation is not simply a word but a meaningful process.

In this tenth report, we considered eleven treaties. In all cases, information about these treaties was provided to the states and territories through the Standing Committee on Treaties process of officials. In a number of cases this was the only `consultation' which took place, in spite of the fact that there are well‐known bodies which should have been given the opportunity to put their views forward.

This is simply not good enough. Either the minister's words mean what they say, or they don't. Some of the more cynical individuals and non government organisations making submissions to the committee over recent months have suggested that we are both a mouth‐piece of government and a ratification rubber stamp.
Let me assure the senate that we are neither and that we will continue to explore the issues objectively and independently. I feel sure that ministers and the parliament would want it no other way.

On 25 August 1997, my colleague in the other place, the honourable member for Moreton, referred to a perceived difficulty in changing the narrow view of consultation that exists in several departments and agencies. That situation persists.

Clearly, it is in the unambiguous interest of the executive and the parliament to enhance the process of consultation if the government's commendable and ground‐breaking initiatives in treaty making are to be maintained. I hope that every effort will be made to that end.
Once again, the chairman would like to thank all of his colleagues, in both houses and in all parties, for their assistance with a heavy, but worthwhile, workload. I commend the report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Extradition (Hong Kong) Regulations, as contained in Statutory Rules 1997 No. 123 and made under the Extradition Act 1988, be disallowed.

The regulations before the Senate seek to endorse the Australian government's move to establish an extradition treaty between Australia and part of China—namely, Hong Kong. It is a very unusual move because, as a sovereign nation, we are used to entering into treaties with other sovereign nations not parts of, provinces of or so‐called administrative regions of other countries. If you can reverse the situation, this is somewhat akin to China entering into an extradition arrangement with Tasmania. It seems very odd indeed.

The progress towards this treaty was set in train before the reversion of Hong Kong to China earlier this year. However, that event changes greatly the arrangement between Australia and China—namely, the part of China called Hong Kong. We no longer have a Hong Kong region which is either a colony of Britain and therefore subject, to some degree, to the rule of law as we understand it or an independent nation able to determine for itself its own laws. What we have is an administrative region of China which is totally at the mercy of China and the Chinese government.

What does that mean? It means that Chinese rule of law is essentially able to be imposed on Hong Kong despite the current differences arising from Hong Hong's colonial history. It will be argued that if that is the case an extradition treaty between Australia and Hong Kong provides for the treaty to be made null and void by either side within six months of their displeasure at events. The question I put is: what happens to those citizens caught in the trap in the intervening six months? You can guarantee that if there is to be a change to this extraordinary treaty between Australia and Hong Kong that change will only come as a result of uproar because a citizen or citizens have come to grief as a result of the Chinese government changing the situation in Hong Kong.

BREAK.PARA: Will the Chinese government change the situation in Hong Kong? The answer is yes it will, according to its own needs. Is there a precedent? Yes, there is. China, you may recall, entered into an arrangement with Great Britain to have a change of rule in Hong Kong on 1 July this year. Part of that arrangement was for a legislative council to be established under the previous colonial British government. That legislative council, contrary to the provisions of that change of aegis, has been abolished and replaced by a non‐democratically appointed legislative council under the aegis of the Chinese government.

Have I got other concerns about this treaty? Yes, I have. The Greens, as with many Australian citizens, are only too aware of the facts about the Chinese legal system. There are thousands of executions per annum. If you peruse the international press you find that almost daily there is another figure put on the list of so-called criminals who are executed in China. It has by far the greatest execution rate in the world, and that is saying something when you look at the rising rate of executions in the United States. They number in the thousands. One estimate is 6,000 in the last year for which figures were kept. That is contrary to the Australian situation.

Moreover, we know that China is a country which denies its citizens basic civil rights and freedoms which we take for granted in this country, not least of which is democracy itself, but of course the right to speak out about the actions of government and to vent different opinions. However, those opinions might not be liked by the powers that be. We know that there are hundreds, if not thousands, of people in Chinese prisons because they have a different point of view from the Chinese government in Beijing. We know that, for example, one of the new laws being brought into Hong Kong is the potential of three years imprisonment for defacing or defiling the Chinese flag. It would be a great worry if we had a similar penalty here in Australia.

But let me take a case in point where China itself is not only a country with a different set of laws and a very frightening set of laws for citizens compared with Australia but also a country that is prepared to break international law. I speak about Mr James Peng, who, as we know, was abducted from Macao into China, tried in China in a court situation which can only be seen as failing the basic tenets of justice as we know it and is enduring 18 years imprisonment as a result. There have been protests from at least two Australian governments about Mr Peng's situation but here we are entering into an agreement essentially with the same government which kidnapped and tried, under abhorrent conditions, Mr Peng, who, as we know, came from this country. I find that a very worrying set of circumstances. But it is not just me.
Janet Hunt, the Executive Director of the Australian Council for Overseas Aid, has said:

ACFOA is gravely concerned that signing a treaty with Hong Kong undermines Australia's long practice of not signing extradition treaties with countries that have a record of human rights abuses. This treaty is of particular concern because the People's Republic of China practices the death penalty.
David Bitel, the Secretary‐General of the Australian Section of the International Commission of Jurists, said:

The issue was discussed at the meeting of the ICJ Council on 16 June 1997 and it was agreed that it was inappropriate for Australia to enter into such a Treaty with a country which does not adhere to the rule of law, which applies the death penalty and where there is no certainty that people would receive a fair trial.

Of course what applies to China applies specifically to Hong Kong. So there are enormous concerns about this proposed treaty. I will quote from another legal source. Lindsay Houghton from Deacons Graham & James, a firm of lawyers in Australia, summarised a very erudite statement of concern by saying:

. . . in our opinion, it is of concern that a country such as Australia that has often protested the human rights abuses in China (particularly in relation to James Peng) and who has already witnessed China fail to honour one of its obligations under the Joint Declaration (the abolishment of the provisional legislature set up by the British), is willing to surrender its own citizens under an agreement which in no way whatsoever provides "watertight" protection of their human rights once they are surrendered to the HKSAR.

I understand that the opposition of the Australian Greens to this regulation and therefore this treaty with China to allow extradition of Australians to Hong Kong and vice versa is going to fail to get the support of the government, the opposition and the Democrats. Be that as it may, I have nevertheless thoroughly gone through the quite complex arguments in this situation.

I am afraid for those people who will be extradited to Hong Kong. I am concerned that they are being handed to the Chinese government. I am concerned that, notwithstanding the differences between Hong Kong and the rest of China, ultimately it is the Chinese authorities we have to keep our eyes on. I am concerned about the precedents that have been set not least of which by the criminal behaviour of the Chinese government in the case of James Peng.

I am concerned that there is the potential for Australian citizens or citizens of other countries handed over to the Chinese authorities to be unfairly tried and sentenced to spend years in prison as a result of activities which would not entertain the same penalties here in Australia, or to face the death penalty. I know the argument opposite will be, `We have put arguments to you in writing,' or `You have not given us the opportunity to negotiate this.' But here I am as one senator covering a whole range of issues.

I have taken those government arguments in their written form and I have listened to the wise counsel of those people in our community who are concerned about this treaty, concerned for civil rights, concerned for the rule of law as we know it, concerned that we do not make mistakes or deliver up people to a system which is abhorrent to the Australian sense of justice and concerned that we do not put ourselves in a situation where we will say, `That was bad luck. Too bad for those citizens. Within six months we will withdraw from this bilateral arrangement.'

That is not good enough. The Chinese government's record—look at Tibet, for goodness sake!—is not good enough. We ought not be entering into an arrangement which I understand has been held up in the United States Senate because of concerns very similar to those that I have put forward. It may be that the United States has proceeded in recent months, for reasons of its own, to an arrangement with China. Nevertheless, for the reasons I have put forward, we should not be proceeding. The precautionary principle at least should be intervening here to ensure justice for people on our shores.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on this disallowance motion and, in doing so, I would like to put on the record the opposition's views—both concern and attitude. We will not be supporting Senator Brown this afternoon. Senator Brown has raised a matter of concern, a matter which should be acknowledged in this place. It does give rise to considerations of issues such as the status of Hong Kong, the status of the rights of people of Hong Kong, the relationship of Hong Kong with the PRC on an ongoing basis and all issues of rights which flow from that relationship.

SPEECH.PARA: The opposition has been a party to a process in this parliament which has seen it consider the treaty at a number of different levels and, of course, now the regulations that are before us. The Joint Standing Committee on Treaties, for instance, had the agreement before it. The committee came to the position that the arrangements with Hong Kong should be pursued and should be allowed to flow through.

As well as that, I think a lot of the discussion in respect of this arrangement happened before the change of government. What has obviously changed since that change of government has been the status of Hong Kong. I think Senator Brown is right to raise issues of human rights but also issues of legality. These are issues which, for instance, go to the question of whether, under the government's empowering legislation, an arrangement such as this could be entered into with Hong Kong when Hong Kong may not, in fact, satisfy the needs of that legislation in that it is not a country for the purposes of such legislation. I think there are other such issues that also will be brought to light as cases which are currently pending before courts on issues such as these continue to proceed and develop.

BREAK.PARA: The opposition has been involved in terms of parliamentary scrutiny through the treaties committee, and that committee gave a tick to the agreements in place. The opposition has also been involved at other levels, as I mentioned earlier.

Our position is not to support Senator Brown on this particular occasion, but we do give notice to the government that we are going to be keeping a very close eye on the operation of the treaty. We will primarily keep a very close eye on court proceedings pending at the moment to see how the courts come down as to the legality of the treaty that is involved. We will also keep a close eye on how the rights of the people of Hong Kong and the rights of the people who may be sent back to Hong Kong are maintained and protected when those people do go back or when those people are considered by the mechanisms of the authority in place in Hong Kong.

So I do not think there is much more that I need to say at this particular stage, other than to say once again to Senator Brown: I do appreciate your raising this matter. I understand that it is a matter of concern to you and should be of continuing concern to this parliament. It is a matter that we on this side of the parliament will keep a very close eye on in the ways that I have mentioned. This will ensure that the concerns that you have do not materialise. To the extent that any concerns do develop and emerge, we will be looking to take whatever action might be appropriate to ensure that those concerns do not have a life of their own and the issues that you raise do not develop into major ones.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne, Sen Vicki

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Brown has mentioned, the Democrats will not be supporting this disallowance motion, which I have already told him about. We heard from Senator Brown earlier about the Chinese legal system. As somebody who has been to China twice to study the legal system—it was for only two weeks on each occasion, but it was very intense—I cannot agree with him more. The legal system in China is very basic, and its study of human rights is incredibly basic. China has not even signed the ICCPR or the ICESCR, although I do understand that they have plans to sign both of those international covenants next year. I hope that does happen. Of course, they do subscribe to the United Nations Universal Declaration of Human Rights, but they do not do it particularly well.

SPEECH.PARA: The point is that I have also been to Hong Kong and just participated in the writing of a report on the current system in Hong Kong. It is very different from the system in China. For a start, the death penalty does not exist and, interestingly, Mr C.H. Tung, the Chief Executive of Hong Kong, has said that he does not believe the death penalty is something that is appropriate in Hong Kong. He would not have said that if he had not discussed that with the Chinese authorities, because that is the way things happen in China and that is the way things happen in Hong Kong now. So I do not believe that we will see the death penalty in Hong Kong for a very long time, if we see it at all.

It is the case that Hong Kong has a very different legal system from China. The legal system in Hong Kong is really a subsystem of the legal system in Britain. It is a common law system. In fact, I understand that invitations have been sent to two very senior Australian judges to participate as common law judges in the final court of appeal in the legal system in Hong Kong. That would definitely be a step forward.

The arguments are complex, and I have gone through them as well. At the moment, the Democrats agree that the extradition treaty should go ahead because the legal system has not changed in Hong Kong. We are assured through the basic law and the joint declaration that it will not. It is set out in both of those documents that it will be a common law system and that it will be maintained in the way that we expect.

I, too, did not believe that nothing would change with the handover of sovereignty from the UK to China. Things have changed subtly, but not to an enormous extent yet. It is still possible for people to exercise their basic rights of disagreement with the government, and that is excellent. Things are subtly changing, but they have not changed to the Chinese legal system and I do not think they will because the Hong Kong legal system is far more advanced, organised and studied for than the Chinese legal system is. If anything is going to happen, it will be that the Hong Kong legal system will maintain itself. I do not think it will just suddenly turn into the Chinese system, where there is an incredible lack of education for the roles which people are called upon to assume. I do not think that will happen.

I would like to mention a couple of things in the extradition treaty. I am sure Senator Brown has read articles 3 and 4.
