Article 4 is about the death penalty; if anything does look like it is going to attract the death penalty, you do not have to hand people over. I have had assurances from the department that that would be case; if it looked like the death penalty were going to be introduced in Hong Kong, no‐one would be handed over. The government of Australia does reserve the right under article 3 to refuse the surrender of its nationals.

Senator Brown also brought up the matter of James Peng. It is a good point. In fact, I raised that with the department as well. James Peng was kidnapped, as Senator Brown said, from the Portuguese colony of Macau and taken to China. He almost got out, according to newspaper articles. He was almost thrown out of China and sent back to Australia, but not quite. I live in hope that that will happen very soon and that he will not have another 17 years in a Chinese gaol.

I have been into Chinese gaols, but I have been into only the best ones, the showcase ones, and they really are not terribly pleasant. I imagine the others are a lot less pleasant. They are not particularly pleasant places for anybody at all, particularly if the person is not well—and I understand Mr Peng is not. I hope that we will see him back in Australia soon.

We are going to vote in favour of this extradition treaty going ahead because the legal system in Hong Kong is very different from the legal system in China. I hope and I believe that it will remain very different from the legal system in China. I do believe that the death penalty will not be brought in in Hong Kong. I certainly hope that any changes to the legal system in Hong Kong will not encompass it becoming anything less than it is at the moment. But if that does happen, if the legal system starts to deteriorate in Hong Kong and if the death penalty is brought in, then we have every right to get out of this extradition treaty because it is based on the basic law and the joint declaration. If those two documents are not carried out in regard to the legal system, then that will mean that we will have the right—and I would take that right up immediately—to get out of this extradition treaty. I hope that is what would happen.

Like Senator Bolkus, we will be certainly watching what happens in Hong Kong and recommending that, if anything untoward does happen, we immediately take up article 3 and not send anybody else back and also take up that last article which allows us to get right of out the treaty altogether with six months notice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is very dangerous for Australia to enter into agreements on the basis that things might be okay and, if they are not working out okay, we might be able to get out of them in the longer term. I believe that both of the major parties tend to have a one‐China policy—and the government is free to disabuse me if that is not the case.

SPEECH.PARA: If Hong Kong took on more elements of the rest of China law, then what would be the basis on which the Australian government would make representations? If it has not done that already on the basis of this treaty, then that becomes very difficult. If it is taken up on an individual case by case basis, then that is still not necessarily a basis for withdrawing from the treaty. I think that is a concern for a lot of people who may already be, or could potentially be, in a situation where their lives might be at risk or their freedom might be at risk.

I do not believe it is the kind of treaty we should jump into if there is not a clear line or a clear basis upon which Australia has previously entered into treaties with parts of countries. That is another thing the government might like to respond to. Is it normal for Australia to enter into agreements with parts of countries? Has Australia done that before? What does that mean in terms of the status of the treaty or the future of the treaty if changes occur?

Various parts of China have different status. There is the Tibet autonomous region, the Xianjiang province and other provinces, and people in those provinces might not think their special treatment is particularly special or laudable. In this particular instance, I will heed the calls of those groups in the community who are saying that this is the wrong way to go for Australia to leap into this treaty agreement. It may well be seen to be good for trade but it might not be good for the messages we are giving on human rights.

Senator Harradine has asked me to apologise that he is unable to be involved in this debate because he has commitments in a committee. But he has asked me to indicate that he is supportive of the disallowance motion. It is a pity that we have not seen Senator O'Chee respond in the chamber—perhaps he might come in later—because from time to time he has been very strong on the issue of Chinese human rights and has raised the issue of James Peng to the chamber on more than one occasion. I would be very keen to see what he personally believes in relation to Australia entering into this treaty and the impact it is likely to have on such people now or in the future. I will be supporting the motion and I urge other honourable senators to do the same.

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would just like to indicate the government's appreciation for the support of the opposition and the Democrats. I appreciate in general the concerns that have been raised; I simply say that they are misplaced concerns, which material available makes clear. This is a matter with Hong Kong—not with China. There are opportunities to get out. No-one is going to turn a blind eye and ignore any possible changes that might come. Any one of us in this chamber would have those concerns. As Senator Bourne rightly outlined, there are opportunities to take action if that happens. But, as it stands, this is an appropriate treaty to make and I thank senators for their participation in the debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been a good debate. I am glad to have had the opportunity to express my concerns. However, I will go away from this debate with those concerns still felt. I think there is the grave possibility of miscarriage of justice when we are exchanging citizens—albeit through the Hong Kongese front door—with a country renowned around the world for its failure to abide by basic human rights and for its awesome retribution on large numbers of citizens through the death penalty.

SPEECH.PARA: I note that there are checks and balances in place here. But, as I have said earlier, we run the great risk that people will get caught up. It will only be at the expense of people who come to grief under this extradition treaty that at some future day it will be reconsidered and withdrawn, if the need for that arises.

I hope, as do other senators, that that situation will not arise. But we have to do better than hope. We have to look at the reality not only of the Chinese system applying everywhere else except Hong Kong but also of the famous ability of China to change tack—with massive changes in the way it structures its society—on an average of once every decade since 1949. From this we know what a danger it is to be entering into an agreement with a provincial part of China, which is essentially signed by the government in Hong Kong because nothing gets signed in Hong Kong without the authority of the government. It is a treaty arrangement that is fraught with danger.

However, that said, I appreciate the taking of that point of view by Senator Margetts and Senator Harradine. I live in the hope that the confidence of the government, the Democrats and the Labor Party is borne out in the future.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the motion (Senator Brown's ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

TITLE.XREF: VOCATIONAL EDUCATION AND TRAINING FUNDING AMENDMENT BILL 1997

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mackay, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —The Vocational Education and Training Funding Amendment Bill 1997 will cut vital funding from the vocational education and training portfolio. This bill is a travesty. It is short‐sighted, and it is yet another indictment of this government's myopia with regard to the future of education and the future of the economy.

SPEECH.PARA: The 1997 budget announced a cut to Commonwealth vocational education and training grants to states and territories of $20 million per calendar year, beginning next year. This bill will implement this budget cut. It will cut $14.3 million from vocational education and training and another $72 million from education and training grants to the states. That means that a total of $86.3 million will be slashed from vocational education and training.

The 1996‐97 budget saw the government confirm its slash and burn approach to most portfolios which are vital to Australians. The 1996‐97 budget saw Dr Kemp slash $183 million from the vocational education and training budget. Over the last two budgets, around $270 million has been withdrawn from vocational education and training. This is a portfolio which provides training, education and industry skills to a range of Australians looking to get ahead in what is a harsh world of stagnant employment growth.

Training is fundamental to the job success of every Australian. Whilst it is vital for potential job seekers, it is also vital for a healthy economy. Any cut to funding will be devastating for Australian training and, ultimately, will not provide young Australians with the level of industry training which they so desperately require. Without an adequately and properly funded apprenticeship and traineeship program, Australia will continue to go down the path of having a disproportionately low‐skilled, low‐wage work force.

This is a disaster for our economy, our industry investment prospects and, ultimately, it will destroy any chance we have of creating an environment which will realise the full potential of our industry, our workers and our economy. It is yet another example of this government, when faced with the high‐wage, high‐skill, high‐employment route, taking the low path and saying, as I think the Australian Business Foundation so eloquently put it, `Okay, what we'll do is organise some Mc‐training for you and you might end up with a Mc‐job.' I think it is a real shame that we are going down the low path with regard to industry policy and the economy, and this is an example of that.

If this bill is passed, we will be locked into a level of basic funding that will be inad equate and appalling. We are already considered to be not up to international standard. How can we be up to international standard? When you look at the funding cuts and an expanded VET sector, which includes the so‐called new apprenticeships, there are simply not enough funds. As Senator Carr has pointed out, this seems to be the ploy of the government. This government institutes arrangements that slash and burn portfolios, therefore placing added constraints and imposts on departments.

All this to provide for a so‐called efficient and effective system. But for whom? It is certainly not efficient and effective for the people of Australia. It is certainly not efficient and effective for young people who are desperate to get adequate and proper training in order to get jobs. Who is it for? It is for the government. It is about the budget bottom line. It is about fiscal policy before social, economic and industry policy.

From a fiscal perspective, it will be efficient and effective for the government. They will not have to deal with the consequences of their slash and burn mentality in their pursuit of the budget bottom line. They will not have to deal with the consequences at the coalface.

It is interesting to see that the states and territories have been ignored—this bill is clear evidence of that. The states and territories have been protesting against Dr Kemp's so‐called `efficiency targets'. I hardly think that this budget measure, which will be implemented with this bill, is an `incentive', to use the word used by Senator Brownhill in the second reading debate.

About one month ago, as has already been stated by a number of senators, Dr Kemp threatened to withdraw an offer of $4.5 billion for TAFE funding over the next five years if the states did not accept the vocational education and training deal. Let us have a look at what the deal was.

The states had to find 500,000 additional training places over the term of the deal without extra funding. A government source is quoted in the Courier‐Mail of 20 September 1997 as saying that Dr Kemp's position of being a bully, effectively `throws cooperative federalism out the door'. He was joined in throwing effective federalism out the door by Peter Costello who, I think, for the first time, aborted a COAG meeting where there was no agreement with states with regard to cuts to funding.

The reluctant agreement by the states—I stress the word `reluctant'; probably `extorted agreement' may be a better term for it—has locked them into finding $286 million a year of operating efficiencies to help fund the equivalent of 40,000 additional full‐time TAFE places. In a leaked ANTA briefing paper, there is clear and damning evidence that Dr Kemp's efficiency drive is simply not going to work. ANTA said that Australia has fallen behind in best practice in participation, the conversion of participation into tangible qualifications and in the qualifications themselves.

To make Dr Kemp's case even more intellectually moribund, the briefing paper by ANTA is critical of the government's attempt to squeeze additional places out of the TAFE system through efficiency. As ANTA said:
The capacity of the states and territories to deliver efficiency gains of this order within a single calendar year is problematic.

That is probably the understatement of the century! In the minority report from the Senate Employment, Education and Training Legislation Committee, Labor and the Democrats both state on page 20 that:

State efficiency gains of the magnitude proposed by the Commonwealth are unrealistic and unachievable. The states have achieved, on average, around one per cent per annum base line efficiency improvements over the last five years. This national, average efficiency growth would fund only between nine per cent and twenty per cent of the required growth in VET clients.

When this is taken into account, with the other demands upon states, the additional impost that this government has placed on states and the TAFE system itself, is it any wonder that state education ministers were screaming? As has been previously indicated, for example, the Victorian training minister, Mr Honeywood is quoted in the Age as saying that:
Dr Kemp's arrogance has no bounds . . . It is unfortunate that Minister Kemp is acting like an endangered species who will say anything to protect his hide.

I understand that Premier Kennett had similarly favourable things to say about the Prime Minister around about that time with regard to the results of the COAG negotiations. Dr Kemp is doing his government and his party no favours with his inept public relations and policy directives. No wonder the Commonwealth and state relationships are fragmenting and the schism is widening.

This bill does not even take into account the ability of states or territories to fund additional VET growth from efficiencies. I know that states have agreed to allow efficiencies to be negotiated with ANTA, but it still remains to be seen how the states and territories manage their efficiencies. Also highlighted in the minority report are concerns from states—and that includes my own state of Tasmania that:
. . . the Commonwealth is not providing funding to support new apprenticeships and common youth allowance initiatives, and that young people are having their expectations raised unrealistically.
That is from page 23 of the minority report.

I have read all the supposed good news stories regarding the new apprenticeship scheme. In fact, in Tasmania we were honoured by a flying visit from the good doctor, when he came down to allegedly give Tasmania another 3,000 new apprenticeships. However, like every other Liberal government, the state Liberal government was not conned by that.

Sue Napier, who is the Deputy Premier, said that this was a publicity stunt, a marketing ploy, a public relations exercise and a con. It was a repackaging of the traditional apprenticeships scheme. That was the reality. She knew it; we knew it; everybody knows it—there was no new money. It was Dr Spin all over again. There is no new money. It was bad for Tasmania and it was bad for Australia. She said so publicly very quickly, might I say, along with many other Liberal governments we have talked about.

Dr Kemp must believe that state and territory ministers came down in the last shower if he thinks that they are going to cop such outrageous nonsense and that you can fly into a state—he did the same thing in Victoria and other states—re-announce an existing program, provide no new money and then fly out again. It is just as well he left the next day, because there was an absolute furore in the media in relation to it. It was exposed as being fallacious and the con that it was.

There is no new funding for this scheme. Indeed, how can there be with the magnitude of the cuts to VET that we are talking about? When Senator Vanstone was questioned back in April about the KPMG consultants' report Costing and resourcing of new apprenticeships, she was unable to respond. This report was very clear in its statement that resources must be lifted from the current 20 per cent to 30 per cent and 40 per cent of the vocation education budget. This means that an increase of $400 million to $500 million would be needed to fund the government's new scheme.

I know that Dr Kemp made a splash in the media about $550 million for at least 220,000 apprenticeships and traineeships in the next two years—Dr Spin again. Whilst nobody in this chamber would disagree with promoting new apprenticeships in areas such as information technology and multi media, as well as more traditional areas—everybody agrees with that—there are two basic problems with what Dr Kemp is proposing.

The first thing is that there is no underpinning industry policy to drive that. There is no direction there to say which way our economy should be going. In fact, you have to look at this in terms of the cuts there have been to industry policies and also with regard to the dismantling of labour market programs and so on. But also—I ask again—where is the money? It is not there. Again we have an example of an ephemeral PR stunt from Dr Kemp. He has attempted to portray the government as providing more money for training. This is conning the general public as well as young Australians. That is the real tragedy of it. This bill is very clear: there is a cut. Funds for vocational education and training are reduced, not increased.

Let us look at Dr Kemp's assertion that apprenticeships and traineeships have increased under this government. Despite the rhetoric that this is a new apprenticeships scheme, it is just the continuation, as everybody here knows, of annual commencements. The number of traditional four‐year trade apprenticeships have fallen, not risen. Dr Kemp's own department has confirmed this. In the last round of Senate estimates, the number of apprenticeships in 1996‐97 was down 2,000 on 1995‐96 figures. Independent officers in DEETYA confirmed that 46,000 apprenticeships are the 1996‐97 figure, down from 48,000 apprenticeships in 1995‐96.

The rate of growth of traineeships has slowed to a snail's pace under this government. It has gone from 117 per cent in Labor's last year of office to at best 44 per cent in the last year—with no growth predicted for the next year. Why? Because Dr Kemp and John Howard, in the first two budgets, have cut vocational education and training by nearly $270 million.

The consequences of this utter devastation of the sector have been fewer apprenticeships and a deceleration of traineeship take‐ups. Therefore, is it any wonder that there is an increase in youth unemployment and in unemployment more generally? The youth unemployment rate has in fact risen over the term of this government from 26.8 per cent in February 1996 to 27.3 per cent. The unemployment rate, of course, is rising. Last month we saw for the first time in Australia's history—as has been indicated in this chamber before—a negative growth in employment in a non‐recessionary period in Australia. Obviously, things have picked up a little since then, but the problem is that there is no plan and no strategy. So the sorts of things that the government talks about are simply not enough.

The government is self‐defeating. It chases the fiscal and budget bottom line whilst dismantling labour market programs and cutting funds to VET. Yet the Howard government fails to factor in the real cost of unemployment, which is extremely serious, in terms of the human cost of unemployment. But if you are all about the budget bottom line—which this government is—you have to look at, from their perspective, how much unemployment costs the taxpayer. Unemployment is estimated to cost Australia up to $40 billion in economic terms alone. That obviously includes multipliers as well as direct costs and so. That is horrendous—and there are the human costs which are tragic.

Encapsulated in this new apprenticeships and traineeships scheme is the user choice funding aspect. Whilst the minority report acknowledges that the bill does not explicitly provide for user choice mechanisms, it says:
The entire bill assumes operation of user choice approach to delivering training.

Indeed, Senator Brownhill referred to this in his speech during the second reading debate. As of I January 1998 TAFE colleges will be competing with around 2,500 private training providers for a share of $500 million.

This user choice model channels public money via employers and industry to training providers who contract to provide specific training services over a specific period. As the Australian Education Union submission eloquently argued:

User choice funding, where the public money for new apprenticeships and traineeships goes to the employer who then chooses the provider of choice from a range of public and private providers in the so called competitive training market, takes the notion of competitive funding practices even further than competitive tendering. It is intended to give this country an employer led VET system, as distinct from an industry led system.
There is a very important distinction there. In a submission to the committee, the Building and Construction Council of New South Wales said:
A "demand driven training system" will concentrate on the short term needs of the employer and apprentices whilst ignoring the long term requirements of the industry.
Therefore, we have what is really an artificial training market that does not relate to anything—industry policy, needs or employment generation.

This user choice funding, along with an artificial training market, raises concerns over the level of skills achieved. In this brave new world of the new industrial relations environment, the welfare of apprentices and trainees is paramount. I will not repeat it at the same level it was repeated last week, I just remind this chamber that a number of government ministers and backbenchers have come out and said we actually need, as Senator Vanstone put it, `a freer labour market and lessened job security'.

One can only speculate—you would not have to speculate too hard—about what will happen to young people, apprentices and trainees under the current industrial relations system that this government instituted, never mind a second‐wave industrial relations system. There is immense internal pressure within the Liberal Party to institute a second‐wave system. To quote the Australian Education Union submission again, they said:
Young people will be guinea pigs for a new industrial relations system, and will be forced into an Australian Workplace Agreement (AWA) as a condition of receiving education and training.
Correct.

Under the new apprenticeship system, the employer and employee and union negotiated training and employment arrangements should then go together to choose the best provider for the training. No body believes that the practice will be anything like this. Unfortunately, young people are not in an equal relationship with their prospective employers and employer's choice of training provider may not be made on a basis of quality.

The other implications of this system which are implicit within this bill are that unemployed people or people with low skilled jobs wishing to change career direction and enhance their employment chances will be denied access to vocational training of certain kinds. As the submission by the National Tertiary Education Industry Union said:
It means, also, that employees could only enter into such training with express support and approach of their employers. Thus access is reduced and in a fundamental way individual rights are denied.
I thought this government was about choice, but individual rights are denied.

Another curious factor is the minister's comment that the government will be committing new funds to enable an additional 18,000 young people to take up apprenticeships and traineeships at school. However, during the same Senate estimates hearing, the department admitted that only 900 young people would start apprenticeships and traineeships at school. These are the sorts of inconsistencies that this bill emphasises.

BREAK.PARA: The combination of the cuts this bill seeks to implement and the implicit assumptions about the user choice model and training provisions leads me to question the government's commitment to vocational education and training, to say the least. I believe that this government is selling Australians short. There is no way that Australia will live up to its potential under this government with these sorts of initiatives.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank senators for their contributions to this matter. At the outset, let me dispel one aspect of the debate and that is in relation to the position of the states and territories on the new funding level, and that growth will be derived from efficiencies. In fact, I think it was a point overlooked by Senator Stott Despoja and opposition senators.

SPEECH.PARA: In the communique dated 25 September 1997, the state and territory ministers said they were pleased that the Commonwealth government had recognised the need to apply some of the immediate gains from efficiencies to improvement and restructuring the system, which would enhance the prospects of further efficiency gains in the medium term to pay increases and other programs to support the national training framework. In fact, in that communique you can see that the state and territory ministers agreed with the Commonwealth, and agreement was reached. It was not a question of any sort of extortion. It was agreed that the states' and territories' individual circumstances would be taken into account and that there would be an agreed process to develop efficiency plans.

In relation to Senator Carr's comments, I say at the outset that Victoria's cost benchmarks will not be imposed. The question of funding cuts has been the subject of comment. The government disputes that there have been the huge cuts in TAFE funding as outlined by Senator Carr. In fact, funding to the states and territories has increased in real terms every year up to and including 1997. In 1997‐1998, total Commonwealth funding for vocational education and training—not just for the states and territories—has increased by some $144 million over the last financial year of the former government. The government has given a commitment to maintain 1998 funding in real terms for three years up to the year 2000.

In relation to the question of the funding cuts reducing the quality to such a base that it would not compare internationally, I looked to the dissenting report of the Senate Employment, Education and Training Legislation Committee which dealt with this bill. I note that the dissenting senators agreed that Australia's participation rate for 15‐ to 17‐year‐olds is close to world's best practice. In fact, the situation with vocational education and training in Australia is very high indeed when one looks at it from an international perspective. The government is, of course, concerned with quality. Its prime aim is to look at quality in training in this area.

With respect to the privatisation aspect, it is a shared objective of the Commonwealth, the states and the territories to develop the training market. This means a strong TAFE system that will operate alongside and in competition with other providers. There is no reason that cannot happen.

All the states and territories—except New South Wales, which has reserved its position—have agreed to implement user choice for apprenticeship and traineeship training from the beginning of 1998. User choice, after all, is about improving the quality of training, not reducing it as claimed by the opposition.

Employers acting jointly with their apprentices and trainees will be able to choose the best provider to deliver the training, and that could be either a TAFE or another provider. I might say that the provider in any event will have to meet the state and territory requirements for registration and deliver training that leads to a nationally recognised qualification.

The drive for efficiencies, which the states and territories have accepted, is not about cost cutting or reducing quality. It is about making better use of the substantial contribution taxpayers make to supporting vocational education and training. It is about creating additional quality training places, especially for young people. The communique dated 20 September this year that I mentioned outlines that very point. I think that agreement reached in September of this year is an aspect Senator Stott Despoja failed to grasp.

In relation to the question of Victorian TAFE mergers, Mr Honeywood, the minister in that state, is on the record as saying that the proposed mergers are to better position TAFE services to industry and students, that efficiencies are a secondary concern and that any efficiencies derived are to be ploughed back into the TAFE system. I do not see any problem at all in a statement of that sort. The opposition and the Democrats are merely trying to beat this up, trying to create some division which does not exist. The TAFE system is not under any cloud at all. It is simply a question of the TAFEs operating with other providers in a competitive environment.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Carr's ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: (Senator Ferguson did not vote, to compensate for the vacancy caused by the resignation of Senator Kernot.)

SPEECH.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Original question, as amended, resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr, Sen Kim

TALK.START.PARA: —May I take this opportunity to thank the Senate for their support of that second reading amendment. I would also take this opportunity to draw something to the attention of the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Senator Ellison), given his remarks in the second reading debate suggesting that the Labor Party's position on world's best practice with regard to TAFE was mistaken. Might I ask you directly, Minister, was it not the case that, in a briefing note to Minister Kemp, ANTA advised that:

SPEECH.PARA: While education and training participation rates for population aged 15 to 17 is close to world's best practice, there are opportunities to expand participation for persons aged 18 to 24 to be at world's best practice.

In fact, Minister, was it not the case that, with regard to the cohorts aged 18, Australia's participation rate would require an increase of some 27.8 per cent to be at world's best practice; for 19-year-olds, 29.9 per cent; for 20-year-olds, 32.2 per cent; for 21-year-olds, 40.3 per cent; for 22-year-olds, 84 per cent; for 23-year-olds, 86.3 per cent; and, for 24-year-olds, 75.8 per cent? Minister, is it not the case that your own department has advised you—and is it not also the case, Minister, that your advisers sitting in the box know this to be the case—that you should not put to the Senate a proposition which is not consistent with the advice that you have actually been given?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I just say to Senator Carr that I made that statement in the context of Senator Mackay's comments that there was such a cut to funding that the base was reduced to an extent where the standard was internationally poor and that, overall, there was this situation that our standard in Australia would not accord with, or come anywhere near to, international best practice. I pointed out simply that, in the dissenting report, the dissenting senators had said for 15 to 17 it was close to international best practice. That is all I was doing. I was clarifying a statement that was made by Senator Mackay.

SPEECH.PARA: The figures that Senator Carr mentions, I am advised, appear to be correct, and that was the advice. But ANTA is not my department. It is an independent body. It is not my department as such, so we need to clarify that. It is, indeed, a body which deals with the ministerial council and serves both the states and the Commonwealth. So, when you say that I am not following the advice of my department in that regard, I just wish to place on record that that is not correct. I highlighted that question of 15 to 17 because it was to clarify and to correct any impression that Australia's standard of training was totally poor compared to international practice, and, as we know, international statistics are notoriously open to correction.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, on that matter, does your department accept the accuracy of the advice provided by ANTA to Minister Kemp?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that the department has had some queries in rela tion to this advice and has taken up those queries with ANTA.
—If the department has concerns about the advice, what is the nature of those concerns?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, the first query that was taken up with ANTA was the question of how you go about comparing one country with another when there are different environments and situations? Also raised was the question of benchmarks, looking at the top of the assessment, or the best performance, and whether you take into account other factors lower down on the scale. I understand that they were two concerns raised.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr, Sen Kim

TALK.START.PARA: —I further draw your attention to the statements you made regarding the reductions in resourcing by this government to ANTA and VET education. Minister, you would be aware that budget cuts over the last two budgets have, in fact, substantially reduced funding to TAFEs. TAFE institutes have had to bear the cost of reductions in funding to the general FAGS, which has an impact on the amounts of money available to the states. Not only have there been cuts through the labour market programs; there have been direct cuts as a result of efficiency dividends required by the VET component of the department of employment, education and training.

SPEECH.PARA: Minister, specifically, you refer to the memorandum of understanding between the ministers for education and training of 25 September where they indicated:

Ministers note that decisions already in train which will impose costs are: (i) additional VET places; (ii) youth allowance; (iii) additional new apprenticeships; (iv) national training packages; and (v) VET in schools.
Minister, can you please advise the Senate as to what is the impact of those costs which are specified in this memorandum of understanding?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a number of questions that Senator Carr raises. Firstly, whilst it is conceded that there are cuts in relation to forward estimates, there was a query as to the extent of those cuts and Senator Carr indicated that these huge cuts to TAFE were a problem in providing the training needed. The query I raised was the question of the extent of those cuts, which relate to forward estimates, I understand. However, in real terms, I stated that in fact funding had gone up.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the communique—I referred to the communique itself and not to the memorandum of understanding—perhaps I can take that question on notice for the moment and deal with it in the committee stage. I will take up any other queries that Senator Carr might have in the meantime.

TALK.START.PARA: —Speaking of the efficiency gains that are required to fund the government's new VET policies, ANTA has advised the department that if growth in VET is to be funded by efficiency alone, which appears to be the basis of this agreement in the memorandum of understanding, in clause 1, reductions in the average recurrent expenditure per annum on curriculum of between 3.8 per cent and 7.9 per cent would be required. Do you agree with that, Minister?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset, I cannot say that those figures are accurate. The situation is that Dr Kemp did not stipulate to the states the amount of growth that would be funded or supported by the efficiencies; that is something which has been worked out with the states. I cannot say that I agree with that because that is still to be worked out.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the other question of costs, the part of the memorandum of understanding that Senator Carr referred to states:
Ministers note that decisions already in train which will impose costs are:
. . . additional VET places;
It goes on to mention the others. Those are not yet tested and again will have to be subject to bilateral consultation with the states.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr, Sen Kim

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, I think this very much goes to the heart of the problem. You have the Commonwealth asking the states to fund its initiatives. You once had a joint arrangement between the states and the Commonwealth in regard to the ANTA agreement where the Commonwealth committed growth funding to the tune of some $70 million a year.

SPEECH.PARA: You now have acknowledged that you do not know what the costs are of Commonwealth initiatives in regard to these areas: additional VET places; youth allowance; additional new apprenticeships; national training packages; and VET in schools. I find it an extraordinary proposition, Minister, that you would ask the states to basically buy a pig in a poke. You are asking the states essentially to fund your initiatives without, of course, any commitment from the Commonwealth to additional resources.

Your advice from ANTA has been that since growth levels may vary between states and territories, the required reductions in unit expenditure at the state and territory level will vary widely. Given that there is a commitment under this government to actually force down the unit price for TAFE programs, can you assure the committee that there will not be any corresponding drop in the quality of vocational education and training packages actually offered by TAFE colleges? How can the 84 TAFE colleges across this country undertake the training of 1.3 million Australians, on current figures, with unit cost reductions in the range of 3.8 to 7.9 per cent, according to your own advice, but probably more for other states—for instance, in the Northern Territory or in Western Australia? Will you assure the committee that there will not be any reduction in the quality of programs offered?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I stated earlier, there was agreement that the individual circumstances of the states and territories would be taken into account. There are some states where the growth factor would be greater than others. There are states which have had more cutbacks than others. That is what places this in the situation in which it is in. You are not dealing with a uniform situation. You are dealing with two territories and six states with different situations.

SPEECH.PARA: That is why we cannot come up with a definite figure as to growth. That is why Dr Kemp did not say to the states, `This is the figure that you will have to meet.' That could not be done because we have to work through it with the states. That is precisely what we are doing. There is nothing unusual in that. The Commonwealth does that in a great many cases. The fact is that we are working with the states in developing this ANTA agreement. We have the ministerial council, which will no doubt resolve matters on 14 November.

TALK.START.PARA: —You would presumably acknowledge that growth estimates are in fact demand driven. If that is the presumption on which this government is still operating, is it not the case that the efficiency targets for states and territories are not necessarily related to their current relative efficiency?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure that growth is entirely demand driven. It is perhaps a major factor, but I think it is simplistic to say that it is entirely demand driven. On that premise, perhaps Senator Carr might want to rephrase his question.

—All I can do if that is the case is refer you directly to the briefing note that we have been fortunate enough to have a look at where it says that similarly since growth estimates are demand driven the efficiency target for states and territories is not necessarily related to their current relative efficiency. Is that a true or false statement?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —Again, that may well be the view of ANTA, which is not my department. I would put it to you that saying that it is only demand driven is simplistic and may not be as comprehensive as it might be.
—I will ask a simple one then. What will be the expected waiting list at the end of this three‐year period?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Carr, that is really a question along the lines of how long is a piece of string. It is crystal ball stuff to say what the waiting list would be in three years time. For me to hazard a guess would be entirely inappropriate.
—You would acknowledge that the unmet demand for this financial year is some 60,000. Has not the minister in the past acknowledged that figure of 60,000?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, per calendar year.
—If you know what the present waiting list is, what will it be in a year's time?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no basis on which the government would expect that to increase. If you are alluding to the fact that this is going to blow‐out, it is the government's view that it would not.

—I would be interested to know on what basis that calculation is made. If you are saying you do not know what it is going to be like in X years time, how do know what it is going to be like in a year's time? I put it to you that there is a requirement for the TAFE sector to provide these additional services as a direct result of the policies pursued by your government. You are calling for additional VET places. You are calling for youth allowances. You are calling for additional new apprenticeships. You are calling for new national training packages. You are calling for new VET programs in schools. You are saying that the TAFE system has to do that with a lower per capita cost. How is it going to do that without increasing waiting lists?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —The states have said in the communique that I have referred to that there are efficiencies to contribute to the growth. It would appear that they are of the view that there can be this contribution without increasing waiting lists or without the reduction in services and that it can come from efficiencies. That is what would appear from the communique itself.

—I thank you for that answer, Minister. It is now a question of having a look at that. On 14 November I will be very interested to see which states identify what efficiencies without the reduction in services or quality of services. Are you familiar with the Phillips Curran report concerning the attitudes of CEOs to the VET system which was given to the department in February of this year?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that that was a document prepared for ANTA, which I am not personally familiar with but I understand the department is.

—This may be a little unfair, Minister, but given that you have been in the job a little while now—and, as you know, I am well known for my fairness when it comes to dealing with tory ministers—I might quote from the report to establish what is current government policy, given the context of this bill. The report of the views of the TAFE CEOs indicated that there was a view that the current policy on training associated with employment contracts and, for example, modulisation and customisation of training to suit specific enterprises had the potential to shift the direction and balance of policy away from lifelong learning and away from appropriate integration of general education with VET. One characterised it as losing sight of the `E' in VET. Minister, do you agree?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that was a report which related to industry needs. The question here is not one of taking out the `E' being for education; it is one which relates to applying or having training which is appropriate to meet the demands of industry so that people who are receiving this training can be employed and will be readily employed.

SPEECH.PARA: As far as that is concerned, the government is keen to see that training does suit the requirements of industry in the marketplace because that, after all, is what gets people employed and that is what you have to keep your eye on. I would point out to Senator Carr that I am not a tory minister; I am a minister in the Liberal‐National coalition government, which is very different from being a tory minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —I look forward to seeing you fulfil that commitment, Minister. Given your answer to that previous question and given the report also indicated that some CEOs noted there was an impression that, while only 20 per cent of VET effort nationally is associated with training under contracts of employment, the 20 per cent tail seems to be wagging 80 per cent of the dog, at least in policy terms. Do you agree with that?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —If you are referring to the question of the apprenticeship and training for younger people being the 20 per cent tail that wags the dog, I can say that the government is of the view that apprenticeships have to have high priority because it is at that end of the market that we are going to remedy the question of youth unemployment, the unemployment of young people. That has to have high priority and that is part of the government's policy.

—That is the government's policy and various Minco decisions have addressed that. The KPMG report called for an increase in funding for new apprenticeships from a present rate of about 24 per cent to up to 40 per cent of total VET funding. Therefore, it would seem, given what we have seen in recent times and given the issues that have been raised in regard to the present dispute with the states, that there will be substantial under funding for the new apprenticeships scheme. Have you been advised that that is in fact the case, that there is underfunding for the new apprenticeships scheme and therefore the demand will not be able to be met?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —My advice is that the KPMG report canvassed a number of ways matters could be addressed and that funding was not quite put like that. If you can find in the report where it actually says that it was purely a question of funding, perhaps you could refer me to that. I understood that the report canvassed a number of ways matters could be addressed. KPMG just did not come out and say, `You have to increase funding for apprenticeships. That is the only way to go.' KPMG canvassed a number of options.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr, Sen Kim

TALK.START.PARA: —There were about four of five options canvassed by KPMG consultancy, predicated on the assumption that there was an underfunding of the new apprenticeship arrangements, that there needed to be a substantial increase in the level of resourcing. One of those options canvassed was the attempt to increase the level of efficiency—that is, make the states pay.

SPEECH.PARA: Other options included increasing user charges to employers, which I understand this government has rejected out of hand, and increasing fees to students, which this government has danced around on—that is, the introduction of a HECS‐style scheme for TAFE. We have not had a definitive answer from this government or rejection of this proposal. We have had a dispute about whether the matter has been considered within the government.

Other options included, as I say, the increase in additional funding. Clearly, the government has rejected that option. The government was left with this one—that is, to increase the level of efficiencies in the states; in other words, to make the states pay. I put it to you, Minister, that you have been advised that there is insufficient resourcing to meet the demand for new apprenticeships. Is that not the case?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset let me say that there is no proposal for any sort of HECS‐type fee for TAFE. I correct that error if there is any inference that there might be. In relation to the underfunding, my understanding is that it was predicated on the need for growth. That is a motherhood statement. There is always need for growth in this area. It was predicated on that and not that there was an underfunded situation. Maybe we are coming at this from two different angles, but that is how I understood the report to be framed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr, Sen Kim

TALK.START.PARA: —On the question of user choice, the Curran report indicated that the stated objective of user choice reported to the ANTA ministerial council and the implementation of user choice is to increase the responsiveness of vocational education and training—

PARA.EMPHASIS: Sitting suspended from 6.30 p.m. to 7.30 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension I was discussing the Phillips Curran report and the government's attitude towards user choice. I might indicate to you that, based on advice from the TAFE CEOs, the Phillips Curran report indicated:

SPEECH.PARA: There was a related concern about the trends in the work force which also work in this direction, specifically the growth in outsourcing and the use of contractors and temporary employment agencies. While these moves may be rational in the short term for individual employers, collectively in the longer term they may lead to deskilling of the work force because individuals and temporary employment agencies may not have the incentives or resources to engage in an optimal depth and breadth of training.

Minister, is the government concerned about the impact of user choice in regard to small employers undertaking specialised training without regard to the overall needs of industry? Isn't there a danger in the present policies being pursued by the government that you will see a deskilling of the work force, a narrowing of options for workers and an undermining of the transferability of credentials and qualifications? Minister, do you agree that there is, in fact, a danger under these arrangements that the overall needs of a particular industry and the economy will be neglected by these policies?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, the providers will be registered and there will be in that registration a quality control. It is certainly the government's objective that there should be no narrowing of the training afforded. In fact, the aim here is that, by having the choice, it will open up the training available. So certainly it is not the government's aim to see any narrowing in training at all, and it does not envisage that that would be happening. If the service is not delivered, the provider will not be used. In any event, there is the quality control through registration.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr, Sen Kim

TALK.START.PARA: —The problem that arises in that context, as revealed by the Senate inquiry, is that quite often industries—the building industry is an example—involve very large numbers of small companies. For instance, I think some 95 per cent of the building industry involves companies which employ less than 20 people. Employers themselves have expressed the concern that a move to user choice will lead to much more highly specialised training provided for the individual needs of individual firms. However, the overall interests of a particular industry and the economy will not be met.

SPEECH.PARA: After all, Minister, is it not the case that an individual firm's commitment is to its own bottom line, not to the needs of industry as a whole and not to the needs of the economy? You could understand employers being interested in their specific concerns, but they do not have a responsibility to provide industry needs as a whole. Isn't that the role of government? Doesn't the government have a responsibility to ensure that the economy is properly catered for and that individual workers are properly catered for so that their skills are not narrowly based and they are transferable, so that specialisation does not occur to the extent that they are only used in any particular firm?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government recognises that there are instances where you can have smaller companies or sole traders which provide a certain aspect of experience or training. Therefore, the government has, in its plans, the expansion of group training; that is, you could have someone who is being trained by more than one person and thereby getting exposed to a wider aspect of training than they otherwise would be. So they do not just attach to one person; they attach to perhaps several. They get the broader experience that way.

—The difficulty with that approach is that the group training schemes constitute a very small proportion of the VET system. Furthermore, the government has, in fact, reduced assistance for individual apprenticeship increases and has, in fact, reduced it substantially in terms of the CRAFT scheme. Is that not a fact?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —My advice is that the group training scheme is the largest employer of apprentices. So, when you say it is small, I fail to see how you can say that it is a very small proportion.

—It is a small proportion of the total training provided under the VET scheme. The group training companies do not provide a majority of training currently undertaken. I ask the minister: is it also the case that the government has actually reduced assistance to individual apprentices and employees under the CRAFT scheme?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, Senator Carr, we are planning to expand the group training schemes, not reduce funding. I think it is fair to compare that with the apprentices who are employed in the area, not the total vocational education and training scenario.

—Finally, Minister, I ask you to comment on this proposition. According to the Curran report, the stated objectives of user choice in the report to the ANTA ministerial council on the implementation of user choice is to `increase the responsiveness of the vocational education and training scheme to the needs of clients'.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, while there is no dispute amongst CEOs as to the validity of this objective, there are circumstances in which the unconstrained operation of user choice will not achieve this objective and may, in fact, work directly against it. For example, if a training program of a regional provider becomes non-viable as a consequence of major enterprises electing to train its apprentices in-house, then, while the scheme has been responsive to the needs of that particular client, it has lost all capacity to be responsive to the needs of other enterprises wishing to use the program. In net terms, the scheme has become less, not more, responsive. Do you agree?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I do not. I think that the government has in hand adequate provision for situations such as a thin market, which has been referred to and I think was referred to in the Senate committee that inquired into this. Provisions can be made for that. The government is after a more flexible situation which sees provision for apprenticeships and traineeships. That, of course, provides more flexibility. Where there is a thin market, then provisions can be made.

—Minister, I look forward to seeing what those provisions are that you are proposing be made as we watch this scheme being implemented. I look forward to the response of the states at the Minco meeting on 14 November. The opposition will be supporting the third reading of this bill simply because we do not want to see this $890 million withdrawn from the VET system in this country. However, we maintain our very strong reservations about the directions of the government's policy in this regard. We have deep concern as to the impact that these policies will have on the regions in terms of the provision of programs by regional TAFEs, which are extremely important in each of our major regional centres. TAFE colleges provide an extremely important service to that region.

BREAK.PARA: We are also concerned about the impact of these changes on individual workers in terms of the impact that the new apprenticeship scheme may well have. Given the appalling condition of the preparation for the introduction of that scheme with so many of the packages yet uncredentialled and the validation processes so far from being complete, we are very concerned about the deskilling of workers as a result of the decline in the quality provided by these packages. We are also very concerned that the government's push to reduce the unit costs for TAFE colleges will lead to a further reduction in the quality provided by TAFE in this country.

We are also very concerned about the effects it has on individual workers in terms of undertaking credentials which are of a lesser value in terms of the traineeships versus the traditional apprenticeships. We notice in the growth forecasts that the government is predicating its budget on the assumption that the growth rates in the three- and four-year trainees will be next to non-existent. So we are concerned about the impact it will have both at a macro level and at an individual level.

Notwithstanding all of that, we understand that the struggle with the states will continue. I am very concerned about the effects it will have. We have instances in Victoria where employers are indicating a decreasing lack of confidence in the quality of the system provided as budget cuts are forced on the operations of TAFE. We are, nonetheless, obviously committed to ensure that these moneys are spent. We will be pursuing these issues through all the relevant forums of this parliament in an attempt to get this government to appreciate that what it is doing to vocational education and training in this country is disastrous.
Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Senator Ellison) read a third time.
Motion (by Senator Carr) agreed to:

BREAK.PARA: That the amendment carried to the motion for the second reading of the bill (see entry no. 7 ), be communicated by message to the House of Representatives for concurrence.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Ellison) agreed to:
That intervening business be postponed till after consideration of government business order of the day No. 4, Health Insurance Commission (Reform and Separation of Functions) Bill 1997.

TITLE.XREF: HEALTH INSURANCE COMMISSION (REFORM AND SEPARATION OF FUNCTIONS) BILL 1997

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 30 September, on motion by Senator Ian Campbell:
That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —The Health Insurance Commission (Reform and Separation of Functions) Bill 1997 has two purposes. The main purpose of the bill is the separation of Medibank Private from the Health Insurance Commission and the consequential corporatisation of Medibank Private. The other purpose of the bill is a rather minor one: to expand the role of the Health Insurance Commission to enable it to expand its range of services to the public.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not intend to deal with the second aspect of the legislation because the ALP is not opposed to the expansion of the role of the HIC in regard to some of those additional services that it will be able to provide in future. That aspect is of a minor nature compared with the primary purpose for which this legislation is brought before the parliament; that is, to separate out Medibank Private from the Health Insurance Commission and to corporatise it. The ALP is strongly opposed to this action and is strongly opposed to this bill. We will be opposing the bill when it comes time for the second reading vote.

We note that the Australian Democrats have indicated in the report produced by the Senate Community Affairs Legislation Committee that they will support this legislation. I also understand that the government intends to move a minor amendment to the legislation relating to the period of time to be allowed for transfers of public servants between the Health Insurance Commission and the new corporatised body, and I will deal with that in due course.

We are very disappointed that the Democrats will be agreeing with the government on this occasion, because this legislation—make no doubt!—will lead to the eventual full divesting of Medibank Private from public ownership; in other words, Medibank Private will be privatised. I expect that the government will get up in due course and say, `No, that's not going to happen. All we're doing here is separating out Medibank Private from the Health Insurance Commission and corporatising it. We will give you a guarantee that it won't be privatised in the future.' As I will demonstrate shortly, you just cannot believe them—when and if they actually say that.

Whilst it is clear that, at least in this initial stage, the newly corporatised Medibank Private will still be 100 per cent government owned, this is the first and the major step on the road to full privatisation. Not that much more will have to happen down the track—if this bill goes through as it appears likely to. And that will be unfortunate. It will be a great shame because Medibank Private, along with Medicare, is now enshrined in the fabric of this country as being a government owned facility that ordinary Australians can join to take out private health insurance. Indeed, Medibank Private provides an excellent level of service and leadership to the rest of the private health insurance industry.

Whilst we may not always agree that increasing the charges is necessarily something that should happen; nevertheless, there is no doubt that, on any yardstick, Medibank Private has led the way in private health insurance for a long time in this country. It has also acted as an influence on the rest of the industry in its introduction of new products and in the provision of health cover for those wishing to take out health insurance. This legislation is unnecessary. There are no good and cogent reasons for it: none were put during the debate in the other place and none were put in the proceedings before the Senate committee.

Medibank Private currently is the largest health insurance fund in Australia. It has approximately two million members or 27 per cent of the market. As I said, it is providing competition in the health insurance industry and it has not suffered from any restrictions under its current structure. You have to ask yourself, `Well, why change it?' As we so often hear the government say, `If it ain't broke, why fix it?' That adage certainly applies in the case of Medibank Private.

The real reason for this legislation put forward by the government is that there is a perception that somehow Medibank Private gains an unfair advantage from being within the Health Insurance Commission. In the second reading speech the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Mr Abbott) said:

Through the separation, the government will ensure that Medibank Private cannot be perceived to have any competitive advantage over other private health funds through its association with Medicare or other government program functions of the HIC. It reinforces the government's commitment to the principle of competitive neutrality.

So it is a perception. I would suggest to this Senate that the government should think long and hard about bringing forward a bill that is based essentially on a perception. This line of argument was repeated by departmental representatives before the Senate inquiry. In its report on page 12 the committee quotes Dr Loy, appearing on behalf of the department:

The aim of the government in putting forward the bill to separate Medibank Private and the Health Insurance Commission was, as has been mentioned several times during the hearing today, to address the issue of the perception and reality of competitive neutrality, first.

This perception that somehow Medibank Private derives some unfair advantage in competition with the privately run health funds was also reiterated by the representative from the Australian Health Insurance Association—that is, a representative for the other health funds. But absolutely no evidence was provided to the committee as to how Medibank Private gains some unfair advantage. There was no evidence whatsoever which showed there was any cross‐subsidisation that benefited Medibank Private to the disadvantage of the other private health funds.

Indeed, while the government is saying that this legislation is based upon removing a perception, removing a concern that exists amongst the other private health funds, the government representative made it clear to the committee that that was not a genuine concern at all. Dr Loy said:

That is not to say that the government accepted that there was any real cause for concern. The arrangements that were made between the government programs side of the Health Insurance Commission and Medibank Private were as sensible and robust as could be desired. Nonetheless, there was a perception and a reality of being able to establish Medibank Private on a competitively neutral basis with other funds.

Some senators may recall—and it was certainly pointed out in the report of the Senate committee—that back in 1992 this issue was addressed by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts when it looked at whether or not Medibank Private gained some unfair advantage. The committee found that there was no real evidence of any cross‐subsidisation. It found that the operations of Medibank Private were carried out in such a way that it was able to compete on a level playing field—to use the common terminology—with the other private health funds.

Mr Schneider, who represented the health funds in the Senate inquiry, was at no stage ever able to say, `Look, here is a situation where our funds have been disadvantaged.' Indeed, he even went so far as to say that in the marketplace, once you separate Medibank Private from the Health Insurance Commission, once you move Medibank Private out of the Medicare offices and make them stand alone, it is not going to alter things very much in terms of the other private health funds.

What we have here, first and foremost, is this government caving in to the whingeing and carping of the private health funds. They have been doing it for years. They have been complaining about Medibank Private being a government‐owned health fund. They do not like it and they have never liked it. They have been trying their hardest to get the government to dismantle it or to separate it, and to put it in a position whereby it would eventually be privatised. If they could see a way to weaken Medibank Private and thereby, hopefully, benefit themselves, then they would try.

The private health funds have managed to convince this government to bring in this legislation, as I said, in their own words `to fix up a perception'—to get rid of a mirage. What sort of a basis for legislation is that? That is an irresponsible approach to legislation in a very important and critical area—the area of health care and giving the opportunity to Australians who so wish to take out private health insurance.

The government says, `It is still going to remain in government ownership. We are not going to privatise it, so you do not need to worry about what we are doing here.' It is interesting to read the Hansard in which, at the outset, Senator Knowles, who chaired the legislation committee, stated:

I understand that there has been some confusion over comments made about the bill being deferred. For the committee's information, the bill is only being delayed by one week in the House of Representatives to enable further consideration on tightening the provisions which would prevent any possible future privatisation of Medibank Private without necessary parliamentary approval. Any further questions on this aspect can be directed to the departmental officials later in the hearing.

The chair of the committee, Senator Knowles, told the committee and the witnesses on 4 September that the government was going to amend the legislation in the House of Representatives to make it legislatively certain that Medibank Private could not be privatised in the future without parliamentary approval.

When the witness for the union, Mr McKenna, appeared to give his evidence, he expressed the concerns that he and his members had about the potential privatisation of Medibank Private once you got down to this stage of corporatisation and the concern that he had about potential redundancies and loss of employment. Senator Knowles got stuck into him. She harangued him. She asked him questions. She said:

BREAK.PARA: You talked about your concern about the possible privatisation. Are you aware of what I was saying earlier—that the bill has been delayed for one week in the House of Representatives to tighten the provisions against privatisation?
Mr McKenna said:
I was not aware of that.
The chair continued:
Are you also aware that Medibank Private could have been privatised under the previous government or by this government under the current legislation as it stands at the moment?
Mr McKenna replied:
No, I was not aware of that.
The chair then said:
. . . the government is actually doing what has not been done in the past—that is, tightening up that loophole to prevent that.
That is, to prevent privatisation. She went on to ask him:

I am interested to know, from your point of view, which party or parties you see would be the advocates of privatisation, given that it is the coalition government that is actually amending the legislation that way?

I have not got time to read the rest of the Hansard , but Senator Knowles, as chair of the committee, was getting stuck into the witness representing the union and saying, `You've got these unfounded fears about privatisation in the future. You are wrong, because the coalition is going to amend this legislation'—and that was why it was being delayed in the House of Representatives—`to make sure that does not happen.'

Guess what? No such amendment was ever moved in the House of Representatives. No such amendment is before this chamber. The quite vicious attack by Senator Knowles upon this witness, trying to put him in his place and suggesting to him that this coalition government was going to ensure that Medibank Private would never be privatised, her attack on a representative of the union movement who was expressing the concerns of his members, was shown to be hollow and totally erroneous. There has been no such amendment.

Why not? Having gone to all this trouble making this grandiose statement at the start of the Senate committee's hearing about what the government was going to do to ensure no privatisation in the future, when it came to the crunch, they did not do it. Senator Knowles stands condemned for the way in which she sought, in my opinion, to harangue a witness. In the end, she has been shown to be the one who got it wrong.

As I have said, this legislation has been brought before this chamber to do the bidding of the private health insurance industry—that is, to remove Medibank Private from the HIC. That is something they always wanted and that I believe will ultimately be damaging to the interests of Medibank Private members.

What other things are going to happen as a result of this? Currently, there are 270 Medicare offices throughout Australia and, by virtue of earlier legislation and the budget process, we know that 44 of those will be closed. But the remaining 226 Medicare offices currently providing Medibank Private services are going to lose those services. Medibank Private is going to be totally separated from Medicare. In future, there will be no Medicare offices providing Medibank Private services. That will be a major change in the level of service to members of Medibank Private. Some two million people will no longer be able to access Medibank Private through their local Medicare office.

What is going to happen in its place? The proposal is to open 70 Medibank Private offices. There will be a reduction from 270 down to 70 of outlets providing services for Medibank Private members. No‐one in their right mind would try to argue that that is not a huge reduction in the service available to Medibank Private members. They are going to be severely disadvantaged, particularly in rural and regional areas. I am sure my colleague Senator West will take up that issue in greater detail.

Think about the impact that this will have upon the elderly, they are not the only ones who will be affected. There are a substantial number of people who have long had the opportunity, as Medibank Private members, to visit their local Medicare office to lodge claims for Medicare and Medibank Private. In the future that service will be gone. What does this government say will replace it? It says that people will be able to use fax machines in pharmacies or lodge claims over the telephone.

One final matter relates to the impact of these changes upon employees, particularly the proposal that there be only a 12‐month period available to employees to elect for a transfer between the HIC and Medibank Private. That is something that we will get to when we deal with the amendments specifically in the committee stage. This legislation is totally unnecessary; it is potentially damaging to the industry and we oppose it entirely. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with a great deal of concern that I rise to speak on the Health Insurance Commission (Reform and Separation of Functions) Bill 1997 . I particularly want to address how the issues, as I foresee them, will impact upon rural and regional areas of Australia, particularly those in New South Wales because that is the area I know best. We know, from answers given in estimates, of a claim that there will be no reduction in the number of staff supporting Medicare. We know that Medibank Private already contribute significant funds to the operation of the joint network of the offices. These funds will be allocated to establish a separate network.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no additional allocation of funding to run two separate networks. Therefore, the networks will have to be reduced in size. The question which immediately comes to mind is: where would you reduce the networks in size? Given they have to be separate, you then have to look from a hard, economic rationalist point of view at what would be the most cost‐effective way, bearing in mind all the principles of competition and level playing fields—when you are 200 kilometres west of the Great Dividing Range, the playing field is not too level.

When I look at previous answers given at estimates to questions that we asked over 12 months ago seeking details of staffing levels within the HIC out at the shopfronts, I can tell you that Medicare offices—Medicare and Medibank Private combined—in New South Wales with fewer than three full‐time staff equivalents are Cowra, Lithgow, Parkes, Young, Mudgee—Alice Springs popped in there for some reason or other; I am not quite sure why—Gunnedah, Inverell, Kempsey, Moree, Narrabri, Batemans Bay, Narooma, Ulladulla, Merimbula and Erskine Street.

If you go a little further to fewer than four full‐time staff equivalents, you then have Katoomba, Springwood, Ballina, Casino, Belmont, Macksville, Cessnock, Muswellbrook, Raymond Terrace, Singleton, Toronto, Wallsend, Cooma, Queanbeyan, Bega and Corrimal. From recollection, Corrimal has gone and maybe Belmont went as well in the previous change‐around.
