But it is interesting that all of the offices with low staff numbers, with the exception of Erskine Street, are outside the capital city of New South Wales in rural, regional and provincial places.

I want the department and the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) to tell me how they are going to separate out staff numbers like that. You cannot take a Medicare office down to fewer than two staff full-time equivalents. Not one of them has that under the previous working scenarios.

I cannot see a Medibank Private office being left with one person to run it. I cannot see that the HIC will be having two offices in country towns like this. So it is quite clear that those of us in country areas are going to suffer a reduction in services. That is what this government have been all about since March of 1996—cutting things in the government areas. If they think the country is going to continue to cop this and not complain, they are very wrong.

The government are undertaking a multimillion‐dollar program to encourage people to take out private health insurance. And what are they doing with this legislation? The fall‐out has to be that they will be reducing the availability and access that a lot of country people will have to one of the major—in New South Wales it is the major—private health funds. It just seems to me that this is totally at odds with the logic behind the government's idea and program of encouraging people into private health insurance.

One of the reasons people in country areas get upset and complain is that they do not have access. If you remove the availability of these centres, of these offices, you must reduce the number of people who take up health insurance with Medibank Private. There will be no office as there is now.

I can only assume also—and it is pretty obvious—that the Medicare offices will be going as well. We know that they are trialling easy claim—the fax machine in the corner. I know from discussions I have had in places that have easy claim—and these easy claim offices are in centres that have never had a Medicare office; they have never had the luxury of presenting a doctor's bill after it has been paid and getting money back—that people say it is great because they get their money back in four days or so, if it is a simple claim. The government are going to be asking people who have already got Medicare offices to accept a lesser service. For people in rural areas of Australia that is not acceptable.

We fought hard to maintain the Medicare office in Lithgow when it was one of the ones that were originally slated for closure. But I do not know how hard we can fight to maintain a Medibank Private office and a Medicare office in Lithgow—or, for that matter, in Cowra, Parkes and Young. People in their thousands signed petitions in those communities. In less than a week in Cowra the mayor was able to get a petition of well over 1,000 signatures to present to the local member, protesting against the possible closure of the Medicare office there. Those people have not forgotten the threat that was held over them once. They have proved once that they can fight. They will have to fight again, because there is no way that the minister can tell me that this legislation is not going to lead to the closure of Medicare offices and Medicare Private access.

If the government have some wonderful way that they are going to introduce agencies, then they should have been telling us about it, because they are not going to contribute additional funds. They say that Medibank Private already contributes significant funds to the joint network. With the withdrawal of the Medibank Private funds from the operation of the joint network, what happens to the Medicare network? They cannot and will not answer.
In answer to a question that Senator Faulkner asked on 19 August, the department replied:

Separation of the HIC from Medibank Private will be undertaken without additional costs to the Commonwealth budget. The HIC will manage any changes in costs within its current budget allocation over the period of the forward estimates. This will necessitate managing priorities.
The expansion—
and here it comes—

of electronic commerce initiatives, as announced in the 1997 Budget, is a key initiative in managing existing funding. Staff are highly committed to the task of ensuring that both organisations emerge as strong and viable entities.

I am sure that the staff who are out there in the small offices do not feel quite the same way. They can see that their jobs are under threat. They know that the electronic easy claims have been introduced in areas that do not currently have access to Medicare, and they know that the same amount of funding is available to run both entities. They are not silly. They can add up—two and two makes four. In this case, when the budget is still only three, it does not equal the same number of jobs. It is a real concern to people living in country areas. As I said earlier, the government wants to increase the amount of private health insurance that we have across this country. This is not the way to go about it.

Another answer was given to us in the estimates hearings regarding the estimated populations serviced by a number of these offices. The Gunnedah office is estimated to serve a population of 36,857. The Lithgow office services a population of 37,118. The Young office services a population of 40,413. Cowra services an estimated population of 41,194. Armidale services an estimated population of 43,708. Moree services 4,576. Mudgee services 44,443. Bathurst services 45,616.

These are the sorts of population areas that will be at risk. I would not think Bathurst would be at risk because it is a much larger centre. Again, Dubbo is probably not at risk, but it services a population of 75,709; Grif fith, 76,923; Orange, 78,000; Tamworth, 85,000. These are the sorts of populations which are faced with significant changes and reductions in services. Let me tell you that those people do not like what is being planned for them. It is amazing: people in country areas with less access to private hospitals take out a lot of private health insurance, and they want to continue with it. It is often the elderly in those communities who try to keep their private health insurance. But, if the government makes it harder for them, it will disenchant them, it will disenfranchise them.

That is what this is all about. It is all very well to say, `Oh, we want to remove the perceptions. We want to have a major advantage.' It strikes me that, given all the material that the government has been talking about and given the need to have private health insurance, the government would not want to do anything that would impact on people's ability to take out private health insurance. But that is precisely what the government is doing.

The union says that the number of offices will be reduced from 270 to 70. I think it is pretty clear from the figures that I gave you previously that that is the sort of thing that logically follows. There has to be a reduction in the number of places left open because there is no way that the same amount of administration money can afford to keep open double the number of offices and employ an increased number of staff. That is what would have to happen to keep the Medicare and Medibank Private offices running with staff levels that would ensure the security and the safety of the personnel working there.

I have some very grave concerns about this. I see this as nothing more than an attack on and a reduction in the services that are available to people in rural Australia—rural New South Wales in particular. It is typical of this government that they continue to take no cognisance of the needs of people in rural areas and reduce the level and standard of services that are available in rural areas. At the next election this government will stand condemned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Acting Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Health Insurance Commission (Reform and Separation of Functions) Bill 1997 separates Medibank Private from the Health Insurance Commission and creates a new Medibank Private corporation. At the same time it widens the role of the Health Insurance Commission, allowing the commission to take on some new functions.

SPEECH.PARA: It was the Democrats who referred this bill to the Senate Community Affairs Legislation Committee. We did that because we had some concerns about the impact on Medibank Private customers, particularly in rural areas. We also had some concerns about the impact on employees of what is, in effect, the corporatisation of Medibank Private.

Most of these concerns were addressed to our satisfaction in the committee's hearings on the bill, which were conducted on 4 September. I have to say that I find the Australian Labor Party's approach to this legislation pretty extraordinary, given their record on corporatisation and privatisation when they were in government.I find it astonishing that they can choose to make a stand on corporatising Medibank Private, having had no qualms about selling the Commonwealth Bank, Qantas, the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories and the uranium stockpile, among other things. I have to say that I for one feel a lot less relaxed about selling off the uranium stockpile than I would if we had a proposal before us tonight to sell off Medibank Private.

It is no secret that the Democrats do not support tax breaks or subsidies from the taxpayer to private health insurers. As such, we start from the premise that we are not particularly strong advocates of the government owning a private health insurance fund. We are well and truly on the record as saying we want to see Medicare become the national insurer, covering both public and private hospitals. So it would be very hypocritical of me to stand here tonight and say that I think it is a great thing for the government to be in the private health insurance business.

It is important to remember that Medibank Private was started by the Fraser government in 1976 to fill part of the gap left by the dismantling of Medibank—which had, of course, been set up by the Whitlam government. Once the Hawke government restored a national universal health program in the form of Medicare, Medibank Private really became a bit of an anomaly and has remained in that rather ambiguous position ever since. I do find it a bit bizarre that today the Labor opposition is defending a publicly owned enterprise set up by the coalition government when that same opposition spent most of its time in government selling off publicly owned enterprises.

Be that as it may, the Democrats did not make lightly the decision to support the corporatisation of Medibank Private from the Health Insurance Commission. We do not care much for unnecessary corporatisations or privatisations, and we do not think much of the so‐called principle of competitive neutrality. However, we do support improved accountability in statutory bodies, and that is one of the reasons the Democrats will be supporting this bill.

I do not believe Medibank Private enjoys a significant competitive advantage within the private health insurance industry—I think that was highlighted during the committee process—but I think it certainly does get some advantage. It obviously functions effectively where it is: as part of the Health Insurance Commission. But that does not mean that it could not function more effectively and with greater accountability—I stress that—as a separate corporation. Equally importantly, the Health Insurance Commission itself may function more effectively without having the administration of Medibank Private to worry about.

Here we come to the core reason the Democrats are supporting this legislation. In the end, the Democrats were persuaded that both organisations are likely to benefit from the separation. I was particularly impressed by the evidence given to the committee by Dr John Loy, first assistant secretary of the health services development division of the department. Although you will find the full text of what Dr Loy said before the committee, I will just quote him briefly. He said:

BREAK.PARA: Medibank Private and the Health Insurance Commission face significant challenges and opportunities and they were seen to be best addressed by being the focus of single organisations, single managements and single boards—
He went on to say:

The challenges of running a private health insurance organisation business these days are clear enough . . . but it is also important to reflect on the directions that the Health Insurance Commission is likely to take over the next few years.

The government sees significant future directions for the Health Insurance Commission as an information, data and payments agency, in a wider way than it is now in relation to Medicare and PBS programs—
I will finish with this last section, where he said:

So we were very concerned to see that the focus on the Health Insurance Commission as a separate business with a significant and developing role had the full attention of a single board and management.

In those committee hearings, it was Dr Loy who put the strongest case for separation of the two organisations. Mr Ken MacDougall, the managing director of Medibank Private, also put a strong case for these two bodies to be under separate management. We found that those arguments were more than reasonable.

One issue that came up in committee hearings that was of concern to us was the needs of the staff, and I am very pleased to say that we were able to convince the government that a greater mobility period was needed. The government will be moving an amendment to take that out to 18 months. Given there was six months notice already as to what was going to happen, we are looking at a period of two years. We believe that is a reasonable time to give people the opportunity to know which body they wish to be with—whether they want to transfer back to the Health Insurance Commission if they chose to go to Medibank Private to begin with. So it is that reasonable period and not any ambit claim we will be supporting tonight.

In conclusion, I want to say that there are many more issues in health care in this country that are far more important than this one for the opposition to get steamed up about. It is all very well for opposition sena tors to get up in here tonight and go on about the government caving into the private health insurance industry, but let us remember perhaps the biggest cave in ever—when the Labor Party decided to hand $1.7 billion over to the private health insurance industry. I stand here tonight and say that the Democrats, as the only ones who opposed that, have been proven right. We have had virtually no results from the handover of that vast sum of money which was agreed to by the opposition. The Labor Party, I would suggest, would be much better off making sure it never backs that sort of waste of taxpayers' money again, rather than opposing something as comparatively innocuous as this measure before us tonight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Quirke, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —Just before I get into the main substance of the Health Insurance Commission (Reform and Separation of Functions) Bill 1997 , I want to make a couple of comments on the record about what we have just heard from the Australian Democrats. Recently, there was an election campaign in South Australia, and on every Stobie pole in the state was a green sticker—
—I am glad you saw it.

—I could not help but see it. The good senator said that it was very good that I saw those stickers. They were stuck everywhere. They said, `Don't sell South Australia short.' It was the usual, trite Democrat sort of statement.

SPEECH.PARA: But at the end of the day, the Democrats fleshed it out a bit with a few TV ads, a couple of radio ads and a couple of newspaper advertisements. Those ads said that the other people—namely, the Liberal Party and the Labor Party—had sold too many things off: that during the federal Labor government a large number of things were sold off. We heard that a moment ago. We were told that a surplus amount of uranium was sold and the good senator was very concerned about that, but the fact is that a couple of million people who decided to put their private health insurance into this agency are about to be screwed up and turned upside down and have their organisation sold from under them—and sold deliberately at the behest of the rest of the competitors out there.

BREAK.PARA: I have to say to the government that, if they get this legislation through here—and I have no doubt they have already made that arrangement; we could see a wink and a nod between the government and the Democrats on this issue—they will probably get a pretty good price for this thing because there are a lot of people out there who want to get hold of it and screw it. They do not want to pick it up and see that there was a membership bank of two million people who, for whatever reason, put their health insurance funds into this agency. What is going to happen to it is as plain as day—a whole series of other private insurers out there will welcome this agency going to the auction block. Indeed, they will pay a good price to dismantle this organisation because they know it has been a thorn in their side for many years.

One of the reasons the Fraser government set this thing up was, dare I say it in here, to keep the bastards honest. We have all heard that before. What you find is that the people who use those sorts of arguments are the ones you have to watch.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yeah, they join the Labor Party.

—What we got over here was an explanation from the Democrats that this one did not matter but a few other things of a rather rare obscurity do. That tells you a lot more about the Democrats than it does about the major parties around here.

BREAK.PARA: Senator O'Chee made the comment that the person concerned joined the Labor Party. I have to tell Senator O'Chee that I have been around for a while and I remember a lot of them making the `keeping the bastards honest' statement. It goes back a lot of years—well before the days of the previous Leader of the Australian Democrats. It goes back a long way.

Unfortunately, in every instance, I found that the Democrats were knocking on the same sullied doors as everyone else in political life, but somehow or other they managed to get away with that slogan for many years. In South Australia, they said they were not into privatisation. At the end of the day, they said the electors were going to vote for them and they were going to vote for them because they were the party of purity and they would not do these sorts of things. We found out here tonight that they are capable of sinning as well, and that is what this arrangement is all about.

As I understand it, this legislation has two principal components. The first one is to invigorate and strengthen the Health Insurance Commission, which, as I understand from our shadow minister's address here, we do not have any great qualms about. We are concerned about the implications of the rest of the legislation—that is, taking Medibank Private out there and just cutting it to the quick in a whole range of different areas, reducing its availability of direct services to large numbers of Australians, particularly those in regional centres, by a dramatic reduction in shopfronts for this particular government agency. As I understand it, the figure is that it will be reduced to something in the order of 25 per cent of offices that before serviced a public out there of something like two million across the whole of Australia.

I do not know what other senators think about this, but I must say that it seems to me that, once you start reducing the shopfront services, it is not long before people take their business elsewhere. It is not long before they make other arrangements. If you do have to go to the local chemist, if you do have to use the fax, if you do have to do all this, that and the other, it is far easier to go and join one of the other insurance providers and get your medical insurance needs fixed up there.

In many respects it is a pity that we did not see that amendment that was meant to have been run down in the lower house because then we would be much less cynical about where this is going, and we would be much less cynical about the obvious arrangements that we can see across the chamber here of a wink and a nod from the Democrats to the government. At the end of the day, I reckon this organisation will be at the auction block before not too much longer.

The challenge ought to be thrown out to the government: if they are going to get up in here and tell us that this thing is not going to be sold off, that it is not going to go, the amendment that was foreshadowed by Senator Knowles on the committee should be proceeded with here tonight. That amendment ought to be brought down here so that everyone can see that the government is about restructuring, not about destroying and selling off this particular agency.

TALK.START.PARA: —That would keep the bastards honest.

—As Senator Forshaw says, that would keep the bastards honest but, somehow or other, I do not think this is going to happen. I could be a bit cynical about it, but I do not think it is going to happen tonight. If it manages to be delayed until the committee stage sometime later this week or next week, I do not think it is going to happen then either. Somehow I do not think it is ever going to happen because I do suspect what this restructuring is all about.

BREAK.PARA: At the end of the day, health insurance is a very important thing for many Australians. It has to be said that the industry has had a pretty rough and rocky road for quite a number of years now. Years ago, the Fraser government established this particular agency for a very good reason. It was not only to influence the other insurance providers out there but also to set a corporate example. It was to go out there and provide services and to ensure, through active competition in the marketplace, that other insurance providers would in fact do the right thing.

For all sorts of reasons and over many years it has been a very well‐supported agency. Somebody mentioned the figure here before that 27 per cent of all health insurance is actually conducted through Medibank Private. That is a very large market share. I do hope the government gets this right because restructuring is one thing. The closing of many offices, particularly in large parts of regional Australia, is in my view going to make it very difficult for that market share to be maintained.

In fact, where Medibank Private is concerned, I would suggest that the government must have a series of other stages for this. I suspect that it will be sold off before this happens. It will either be sold to some other agency that wants to come in or, as I suspect and said earlier, it will probably be sold off to the existing industry out there.

There is another issue that the minister might want to raise here tonight. He might want to give us some assurances that this particular agency is not going to be sold off to some existing players so that in fact we can seek a much greater concentration in the marketplace of the other non-Medibank Private players. I would suggest that, in his address here tonight, he could go a long way to allaying some of the suspicions that are circling this particular issue.

It is a fact that a large number of Australians have, for whatever reason, pulled out of private health insurance over the years. The last figures that I saw in my home state showed that something in the order of 34 per cent of persons were privately insured. One of the reasons for that is that, as I understand it, an average premium for a family is somewhere in the order of $45 to $50 a week, and there aren't too many families that have that level of disposable income.

Those people who are still in private health insurance, or whatever policies they hold and with whichever company, in many instances are reliant on the private health system in Australia. They have made the decision that that is where they want to allocate a significant part of their family income. I just hope that the government gets this right, and I hope that we really do not have ulterior motives here. If that is not the case, a lot of people who are particularly vulnerable—and we had from Senator West a list of places in rural New South Wales, and I am sure it is the same in every other state—are going to be on the receiving end of this.

I want to conclude my remarks here tonight by saying that it seems to me that this particular issue has been shrouded in a degree of secrecy. We are told that certain amendments are going to be passed, that those amendments are going to be put up and are going to strengthen the public ownership of this particular agency, but then we do not see them. Then we are told that they are not going to be necessary. Then we have the icing on the cake when the Democrats tell us that we sold off too many things, so they are going to happily let the government do this one.

At the end of the day, I suspect this agency is being prepared for sale. The corporatisation of this agency is like many of the corporatisations that I have seen before in state agencies, and all they always lead in the one direction—that is, they lead to the auction block; they lead to sale.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I find it almost laughable that the opposition should shed crocodile tears about private health insurance when they deliberately set out to destroy the private health insurance industry. Under their direction, the private health insurance coverage in this country went down from 70 per cent of the population to only 31.9 per cent now. Nothing had changed until we introduced the changes at the end of July.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to reassure Senator Lees. She made the only constructive comment and asked the only constructive question during her presentation because she has a much greater understanding and knowledge than those opposite about the health insurance industry. She made the comment that private health insurance incentives had not worked. Senator Lees, it is still early; the figures will not be out for another month as to whether they have worked or not. I certainly believe that the figures will plateau because that is the experience of most countries where subsidies have occurred.

With respect, Senator Lees, it is a bit early to say that the incentives have not worked. They have not had time to work yet and it will be another month before we know. Experience has shown in Queensland that the figures have plateaued and that there is an irreducible figure which varies around 30 per cent. For something like nine years now 30 per cent of the population have maintained their private health insurance and I assume that the subsidy will boost that somewhat in my own state.

Apart from that, there were the statements from the other side, such as Senator West's statement. Really! She was saying that the network would be reduced in size. Yet there are already 100 additional rural Medicare facilities available as a result of the changes that we have brought in.

I can understand Senator Forshaw, Senator Quirke and Senator West because they are locked into the politics and rhetoric of socialism. They believe that unless something is run by the government it does not work. When you understand that, you appreciate their statements.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are saying Medibank Private doesn't work?

—Unshackling Medibank Private from Medicare is a win‐win situation. It lets both market towards their customers because, although overlapping, they have a different customer base. By keeping them together we would shackle them with the constraints that government control inevitably brings about. Under the opposition's previous control, they were stuck together irretrievably and could not make separate market decisions, whereas the separation of Medibank Private will allow it to have a competitive advantage over what it has now. That is, it can approach its market and allow itself to get into situations where it can compete with the private health insurance industry. It has been the leader and it has the majority of the privately insured population in this country, but it is constrained by being intimately involved with and connected to Medicare.
—How? How?

—Because it has a different customer base, Senator Forshaw. You very proudly quoted Dr Loy. What Dr Loy spoke about was the perception and the reality of competitive neutrality. Senator Forshaw just neglected to emphasise the reality; he talked about the perception. Dr Loy also said that Commonwealth ownership is embedded in legislation. We have been up‐front. For example, we said that we would sell one‐third of Telstra. We had that in our policy. Again I can understand the opposition saying there is some conspiracy. They are great conspiracy theorists—`This is the first step'—because that is the way that they function. Remember the Commonwealth Bank? Senator Lees referred to that. The Labor Party were not going to sell the Commonwealth Bank. They were not going to sell Qantas.

SPEECH.PARA: We have been up‐front. We said we would sell one‐third of Telstra, and you can see the overwhelming public response that has occurred to that sale. We were up‐front. We said what we were going to do. If you accept that we said that, you should also accept the statement of the minister when he said that we are not going to sell Medibank Private. That assurance has already been given, Senator Forshaw, so it is no good Senator Quirke coming in here and saying, `There is a conspiracy on; there is some great plot that is going to occur where it is going to be sold.'

There are advantages of separating the two. The government is proceeding with that. We have taken the Democrat amendment, as Senator Lees said, to extend it out to make it 18 months rather than six, so effectively it will be two years. I commend the bill to the house. I believe that it is in the best interests of both Medicare and Medibank Private, and to the advantage of the Australian public, that this should occur.

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition is pleased to see that at least the government—and apparently the Democrats are supporting this amendment—has recognised the concerns that have been expressed by the employees of Medi bank Private and the HIC. SPEECH.PARA: The opposition's view is that the period should be three years, or 36 months, consistent with what is the standard within the Australian Public Service for similar situations of people moving from the Public Service to be employed by a Commonwealth owned statutory authority. Mr McKenna gave evidence to that effect before the committee, which I will read into the record, from page 8 of the Hansard. He stated:

The second major concern we have in relation to the industrial aspects of the legislation is the 12‐month mobility right. I must say that it is not often—in fact I cannot recall one instance to date—that this government actually listens to the arguments put by union representatives and then takes them on board and sees some merit in them, but on this occasion it has. The government has clearly recognised that the period which was specified in the bill was too short and it has proposed to extend the period to 18 months.

We in the opposition believe, as I said, that the period should be 36 months. We do not think that will make any difference to what will now clearly occur with respect to the separation aspect itself, but it will certainly provide more appropriate security for the employees, who clearly will be affected by these changes—the sorts of changes that were pointed out in your own speech, Chairman West—where Medibank Private facilities will be closed down in Medicare offices and new offices will apparently be opened.

This will clearly impact upon those employees in a way that is not yet really clear, but certainly one can anticipate employees' concerns about whether or not they would wish to remain within the HIC, whether or not they are able to transfer to a new corporate entity, Medibank Private Ltd, and whether or not they can, in due course, return if that is their desire. I move:
Omit "18" (wherever occurring), substitute "36".

I want to make some further comments which again go to the legislation. We are concerned, but unfortunately this is not a matter that can be fixed by way of an amendment to the legislation, with the huge reduction in the availability of shopfront services. The Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Senator Herron) treated that rather lightly, as usual going off on one of his tangents talking about socialism and so forth. I am sure some of his National Party agrarian socialist colleagues will be concerned when there are no longer Medibank Private services in the Medicare offices in regional and rural areas.

It is interesting that the Minister for Social Security (Senator Newman) is in the chamber at the moment because she has made great play of what this government is endeavouring to do with the establishment of one‐stop shops: `Let us not have different government agencies such as in Social Security, DEET, CES or whatever. Let us get them all into the one location where people who need access to these various government services can do it all in the one location.' What have we got here? We have the complete reverse. The minister says that this is going to be an improvement. He says that you have to separate Medibank Private and Medicare offices somehow so they both can grow.

Minister, you cannot have it both ways. If ever there has been a classic example of a one‐stop shop that has existed and worked exceedingly well for years ever since Malcolm Fraser's government established it, in terms of Medibank Private and then subse quently with the reintroduction of Medicare, it has been the co‐location of Medibank Private and Medicare, and those offices have provided other services as well such as in regard to child care and family assistance.

The fact of the matter is that every member of Medibank Private is a client of Medicare. They have to be because every single person in the country is ultimately a client of Medicare. I fail to see how you can argue that that will actually improve the efficiency of what, in your own words, will continue to be the delivery of services which are completely owned by the government—on the one hand, the services in the future through Medicare and, on the other hand, the services in the future with a separately corporatised Medibank Private.

Minister, you might care to respond to that during the committee stage because, frankly, you cannot give us all this rhetoric about bringing about efficiency in government agencies with the creation of one-stop shops, which I think is a great idea, when in this situation, for no good purpose whatsoever, you are going to remove the same thing which has been in existence for many years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not misunderstand it at all. Minister, I recall prior to the last election representing the then minister at the opening of a new office that was, from memory, at Nambucca Heads in New South Wales. PARA.EMPHASIS: REVIEW DATA ON PUBLIC HOUSING SUB-TENANTS

SPEECH.PARA: In researching costing of new proposals, the Department of Social Security must work within the parameters defined by privacy legislation. The broad impact of this legislation is that the Department cannot require information from customers before the purpose has been supported by legislation. Where the information is not already available, therefore, the Department prepares estimates on the best information available to it. To gain an overview picture of the situation of public housing tenants, major use was made of computer matching of addresses. The Department also drew heavily on the views of experienced staff. Some detailed data on a small group of 60 sub-tenancy cases in one geographic region was also available. This had been produced as a by-product of a review to detect principal tenants in public housing who were incorrectly receiving rent assistance.

The sample was not large enough to be considered representative but, as the best detailed information available, served as a useful supplement to the views of staff and the computer matching. All figures for averages have been rounded downwards. Figures cited for State Housing Authority rents represent the most common outcomes in the State involved but may not apply in all situations.

The distribution and amounts of the rent paid by sub-tenants in the sample are broadly similar to that of rent assistance recipients as a whole. The amount of rent assistance received by these customers ranged from a low of $3.25 per week for a single unemployed customer to $49.20 per week (the maximum rate of rent assistance for a sole parent with three or more children paying more than $112.50 per week in rent). The average rent claimed was $74 a week The average rent assistance paid was $23 per week

50 per cent of customers were recorded as paying `board and lodging" —that is their payments included money for meals as well as rent. Amounts claimed for board and lodging ranged from $60 to $200 per week with an average payment of $92 per week. The average rent component of the board and lodging payment was $61 a weekly

50 per cent of customers were recorded as renters or lodgers— that is meals were not included in the arrangement. The amounts recorded ranged from $50 to $155 per week. The average rent payment claimed in this group was $84 per week. At the time, a principal tenant who was a member of a pensioner or unemployed couple would have had to pay approximately $58 a week to the State Housing Authority (SHA). The amount of additional rent for the sub-tenant required by the State Housing Authority (assuming the sub-tenant had no other income) would have been $29 for each member of a couple and between $32 and $34 for single people. The average rent paid at the time by rent assistance customers in non-metropolitan areas of the particular State where the review was conducted was $99.

The majority of rent assistance recipients (76 per cent) were single people without dependents. Twelve per cent were sole parents and 12 per cent of cases were couples. In most cases (72 per cent), the principal tenant and the sub-tenant receiving rent assistance were closely related—ie. parent, sibling or children).

PARA.EMPHASIS: DOUBLE SUBSIDIES AND SUB-TENANTS IN PUBLIC HOUSING

SPEECH.PARA: 1. General Background
The Commonwealth provides subsidies for low income renters through two main systems:
. funding for public housing; and
. Rent Assistance—paid to income support recipients who rent in the private market.
Both systems provide subsidies to a large number of people (although individuals receiving subsidy through the public housing stream generally do better than those receiving Rent Assistance).

There is a long-standing policy view that individuals should not benefit from subsidies from both systems. In addition to being inequitable, the system would not be sustainable if there were extensive double dipping. Rent Assistance, therefore, is not payable to public housing tenants.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 2. The Anomaly of Public Housing Sub-Tenants

SPEECH.PARA: Sub-tenants in public housing have not been considered as "public housing renters" because they have no direct relationship with a State Housing Authority (SHA). They can, therefore, receive Rent Assistance. However, the SHAs generally extend to them much the same benefits as to principal tenants. When a sub-tenant is notified to the SHA, the rent is increased by a proportion of the sub-tenant's income—usually between 10 and 25% (although higher in some cases)—far less than usually paid in the private rental market.

Exact numbers of sub-tenants receiving Rent Assistance will not be known until matching has been completed with data from SHAs. However, address matching in different locations appears to indicate that $57 million of Rent Assistance may be "leaking" to people already effectively receiving subsidies through the public housing system.

Levels of rent charged by SHAs vary greatly both between States and within States for different groups of tenants. Nevertheless, the variations are mainly at the margin and the examples given are broadly illustrative of the situation.

SPEECH.PARA: While there is no double subsidy in this example, in some circumstances some SHAs charge an additional amount of rent in relation to a sub-tenant which would entitle the person to a low level of Rent Assistance. The maximum amount in such cases would be around $10pw and in most cases considerably less.

The major scope for leakage of Rent Assistance is to households where the sub-tenant is paying rent that is greater than the extra rent charged by the SHA. In these cases, the taxpayer through Rent Assistance, makes a substantial contribution to windfall gains by the principal tenant or household, who is, in effect, doubly subsidised—through the public housing rent subsidy and RA.

SPEECH.PARA: It is difficult to justify subsidising such gains to public housing tenants and/or sub-tenants who already benefit from living in often heavily subsidised dwellings. There are also a number of reasons for believing that the removal of the double subsidy may not impact substantially on the sub-tenants who are apparently paying higher than justified rents. Anecdotal and review evidence suggest that most sub-tenants are family or friends of the principal tenant. In this generally non-commercial setting, rent levels may be reasonably sensitive to views about what the sub-tenant can afford to pay or what assistance can be claimed.

TALK.START.PARA: —There has already been quite a lot of debate on this issue. I remind the Senate that, on the last occasion, Senator Newman claimed that some material would be available to show the abuse of this situation, but on closer examination it was found to be not exactly as had been asserted.

SPEECH.PARA: Ms Macklin's office has prepared another example as a response to the examples already provided by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Newman). A single parent, 45 years old, on the newstart allowance maximum rate, which is $321.50 a fortnight, lives in public housing. Under the existing arrangement, the second sister would be eligible for $12.23 a fortnight in rent assistance. This would also be the case if she were living in private rental accommodation with her sister or another person and paying the same amount of rent. Under the proposed arrangements, the second sister would not be eligible for rent assistance and the household would be $12.23 a fortnight worse off, despite the fact that the second sister is paying $87.90 a fortnight rent and despite total rent for the premises remaining at $152.20 a fortnight.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Social Security (Senator Newman) for the information we received some days ago, but it has not changed the Democrats' view of the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment (Family and Other Measures) Bill since the last sitting. BREAK.PARA: The departmental data suggests that only those tenants who are paying rent above the additional rent amount set by the state housing authorities are eligible for rent assistance and they would, therefore, be receiving the so‐called double subsidy. We also know that it is up to the principal tenant to determine how much rent will be charged to the subtenant, who can then apply for rent assistance. As I understand it, this process is not expected to be completed before 1 January 1998, the date on which the measure is due to commence. TALK.START.PARA: —I understand the Minister for Social Security, Senator Newman, has indicated that we have gone over the course. There is no point in delaying this much further. TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators for their contributions. I am disappointed in the approach which they are taking. TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the second reading of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1997. This bill, which is the fourth omnibus taxation bill for 1997, covers a variety of issues which can be grouped into anti‐avoidance measures, amendments to the new simplified 1997 assessment act aligning it with the former 1936 assessment act, and a collection of other unrelated matters.

SPEECH.PARA: I start by turning to the anti‐avoidance measures. I wish to indicate that the opposi tion supports these proposals in principle. However, we do have some questions about the precise impact of the proposals, and we will be seeking to have these explained by the minister or the parliamentary secretary—whoever is handling this bill in the chamber for the government.

The first anti‐avoidance measure involves tightening the thin capitalisation provisions. These provisions, which of course were introduced by Labor, limit the amount of interest deductions allowed to firms with foreign debt to ensure the integrity of the Australian company tax base. The bill is proposing change in a number of respects to the thin capitalisation regime. Specifically, the general gearing—that is, the debt equity ratio—is to be reduced from three to one to two to one for non‐financial institutions. The definition of foreign debt is to be broadened; the rules for trusts and partnerships are to be tightened; and the specific anti‐avoidance provisions are to be repealed.

As I stated previously, we support these changes in principle. But we are concerned that the rules may have some unintended consequences for some important investments. The opposition hopes that the Senate, in its proper role of close examination of legislation, will amend the law to lower the impact on some investments in regional areas which suffer from high levels of unemployment. I will discuss those issues in more detail during the committee stage of this debate.

The second anti‐avoidance measure in the bill is aimed at stopping abuse of finance share provisions. Australian financial institutions—we do not know how many—have apparently been abusing the concessions available to so‐called eligible finance shares, EFS, and widely distributed finance shares, WDFS, by converting payments which are in effect interest into dividends in order to qualify for a tax exemption and for underlying foreign tax credits paid in other jurisdictions.

The opposition strongly supports this measure and we question whether the proposal is in fact adequate, given the magnitude of the problem. The explanatory memorandum lists the savings from these proposals at around $130 million per year. Presumably, this rort has been costing Australian taxpayers around $130 million per year for some considerable period of time.

Honourable senators would be aware that over the last few years these financial institutions, these banks, have generally been reaping huge profits, have produced huge increases in their share value for their investors, and have massively increased the level of fees and charges levied on ordinary customers. We now find out that some of these financial institutions have apparently also been rorting the tax system to the tune of $130 million per year. This is the kind of blatant sham arrangement that should be shut down, and we will be supporting the passage of these provisions.

But I also ask the parliamentary secretary or the minister who is in charge of this legislation to detail to the Senate what action the Taxation Office has taken in attempting to collect this tax for the period prior to 4 February 1997. For example, has the issue been taken to the courts to see if the schemes are legally bulletproof? If so, what was the reaction of the courts? Would the general anti-avoidance provisions of part IVA not operate to strike down an arrangement which is merely converting income from one form to another for taxation purposes? And, if the anti-avoidance provisions do not cover arrangements like these, does this not suggest that there is a need to review and possibly strengthen these anti‐avoidance provisions? I have to say they are three very important questions which I hope the government will take note of and reply to in detail.

Our society functions because of voluntary compliance with our taxation laws. Ordinary taxpayers pay their share because they acknowledge that this is the price of a decent society, and that decent public services cost money which must be provided by taxpayers. They pay their fair share because they know that business is also supposed to pay its fair share. The schemes dealt with in this bill are examples of enormous businesses which have not been paying their fair share. Such examples tend to undermine the vital system of voluntary compliance because people think, `Why should I pay tax when I'm struggling to make ends meet if major transnational financial institutions can get away with rorting the system?' As I have said, Labor supports clamping down on these shonky financing schemes, but we are keen to know whether the offenders will be able to get away with the enormous tax benefits of previous years.

The final anti‐avoidance measure proposes addressing tax avoidance which has been occurring through tax exempt entities distributing funds offshore. The bill proposes that the existing exemption for foreign located charitable trusts be terminated. The exemption provided to charitable trusts established in Australia is restricted. The exemption is removed for certain organisations—for example, trade unions and religious and educational bodies which do not operate principally in Australia—and the exemption for non‐resident interest, dividend and royalty withholding tax is also removed for certain organisations located offshore.

The mere thought of tax exempt entities being used for tax avoidance is an unpleasant one. These are bodies which have been ostensibly set up for public benefit, be it a charity, a sporting organisation, an educational organisation, a trade union, an employer body, et cetera. In recognition of the important roles played by these bodies, this parliament has provided tax exemption for the income of these bodies to enable their important work to be undertaken without tax penalty. It is despicable that some fancy accountants and/or lawyers have abused this system to enable tax exempt bodies to be conduits either knowingly or unwittingly for tax avoidance purposes.

A rort is a rort, and it should be stamped out irrespective of the players involved. All that said, when fixing a problem it is incumbent upon the government to ensure that no damage is done to genuine tax exempt bodies in the process of sorting out the cheats. On this score the government has failed miserably.

Every member of this Senate has probably received correspondence from alarmed groups, including religious groups, sporting groups and educational groups, after they saw the initial draft of this legislation earlier this year. That draft legislation proposed to penalise those groups which had virtually any offshore connection or activity. The proposed penalty was not minor or trivial, but rather involved the loss of their income tax exemption. So, clearly, many legitimate bodies would have been significantly affected by the original proposals of the government.

It is true that, because of the outcry over the original clumsy approach to addressing this problem, the government has backed down. However, there is some considerable doubt about the extent of the redrafted provision. In particular, the education and training industry is concerned about the possible effects of the redrafted legislation. For example, International Training Australia, ITA, has written to the opposition expressing their concerns about the bill that is now before us. ITA is a private company whose shareholding is comprised solely of Victorian government enterprises. It was established to combine and coordinate the training and education capabilities of the Victorian TAFE system in large‐scale overseas projects. ITA is very concerned that the provisions in this bill will impact on its members' current drive to increase the export of Australian educational services.

These Australian educational institutions, for commercial reasons, often have to establish foreign subsidiaries or Australian subsidiaries which do not operate principally in Australia. These bodies are not engaged in tax avoidance but they may be caught by this legislation and hence lose their tax exempt status.
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to bring to the attention of the Senate an event which is of great importance to my constituents in western Sydney and, indeed, to the larger Sydney community. Friday, 26 September marked the commencement of active competition in a significant sporting event for the people of greater western Sydney known as the Greater West Games. For a region even now preparing for the 2000 Olympics, the Greater West Games are an invaluable precursor.

SPEECH.PARA: The games were born of a strong team of members of the western Sydney community who pooled their numerous skills together with a sense of purpose, energy and incredible commitment to achieve this remarkable event.

At last year's inaugural games there was a total of 26 sports involving over 6,500 competitors. The games were an enormous success in both sporting and community terms, generating energy, expectation and anticipation. This year the organisers have achieved even bigger and better things.

This year's games have 50 diverse sporting competitions which cover 13 local government areas, with a conservative estimate of 13,000 expected competitors. The games range from swimming, athletics and shooting to bocce, speed skating, gymnastics and lawn bowls. There is something for everyone—I think the organisers would suggest even for me.

This year the games embrace a wealth of new sports and incorporate five state championships, including the state badminton championships, a national trampoline sports competition and major competitions in many others.

For the equestrian pursuers, 1997 heralded the introduction of five equestrian disciplines, bringing together both elite and up‐and‐coming riders from across NSW and indeed all of Australia in prestige competitions. Events included the horse trials competition—a very important event based on the international success Australia has had in recent years with gold medals in the three‐day equestrian competition at both the Seoul and Atlanta Olympic Games. The dressage event was judged as a state championship in New South Wales, but for the younger people who wanted to participate for the spirit, the pony clubs' mounted games were also included.

BREAK.PARA: The organisers thought of everybody, they assure me, including those who prefer to ride in a gig rather than the saddle, introducing a carriage driving competition at the historic Elizabeth Macarthur Institute. Showjumping and the grand prix and junior rider championships were also included on the program.

Highlighting the geographically diverse region of greater western Sydney, the games incorporate a unique regatta held at the Sydney International Regatta Centre. Possibly for the first time in the world, there were five sports included on the regatta program—rowing, canoeing, dragon boats, surf lifesaving and a wheelchair triathlon. It was a commendable achievement to bring all those events together.

Another spectacular event was the Shell lifesaving challenge, where surfboats, rubber ducks and surf skis battled for supremacy in a 20‐kilometre relay up the Parramatta River from the Harbour Bridge to Parramatta. A road cycling program was held in Parramatta Park, and a mountain bike competition was included in the games. It was identified as a good warm up for Olympic organisers, as this competition has also been included on the Sydney Olympic program. This not only offered an elite competition for our finest sports people; it gave everyone with a mountain bike the chance to ride the course and find out more about the sport.

The young men and women of the region were involved in special school holiday junior competitions in most sports, with particular team competitions in the most popular of softball, hockey, netball and water polo. Up‐and‐coming Karrie Webbs and Greg Normans played alongside pros at the junior pro-am and all golfers joined in the Greater Western Sydney Open being played in beautiful Camden.
One of the games' objectives is to market the diverse region of greater western Sydney; another is to encourage participation. Three special events focused specifically on these dual objectives.

For families and those interested in the amazing history of the greater western Sydney region, the Hawkesbury Inheritance was organised as a three‐day bike tour from Sydney to Brooklyn following the Hawkesbury River. More a tour than a race, the event visited a number of significant historical and tourist attractions en route, stopping overnight at Richmond and Wiseman's Ferry and providing an opportunity to see the region from a different perspective.

The great kayaking event known as the Hawkesbury Classic is another event held under the umbrella of this year's games. Almost 600 competitors started in the event, the 21st running of the 111‐kilometre overnight paddle from Windsor to Brooklyn.

Described as a new and exciting event on this year's program was the Daily Telegraph Trifecta. That is not quite what it sounds, but rather an event limited—limited, they say—to 1,600 competitors and involving one-lap dashes at Rosehill Gardens, Warwick Farm and Hawkesbury racecourses. Not only did this event traverse a significant part of the region of greater western Sydney, it was reported as a great family day and an event in which three generations participated together.

Over the October long weekend, they held a sailing competition on scenic Chipping Norton Lakes. The regatta involved a wealth of local talent in the junior boat classes who do not often get the chance to try their very professional skills.

The Greater West Games are games for everybody. Events for athletes with a disability were included in the athletics, swimming, rowing, tennis and shooting competitions, while there were also special wheelchair competitions in triathlon and basketball.

The games are only made possible by the enormous support and energy of the sponsors and supporters and the involvement of the many competitors. The chief executive of the Greater West Games, Mr Chris Cunliffe-Jones, has expressed his thanks to the former Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government, Warwick Smith, for providing financial assistance under the recently launched Active Australia Program.

The games bring something very special to greater western Sydney and provide us with an opportunity to showcase the many assets that our region has to offer the state and Australia as a whole. They provide us with an opportunity to do more in the way of preparation for the Sydney 2000 Olympics.
Mr Cunliffe-Jones summed up the driving force behind these games by reiterating the immortal words of the founder of the modern Olympics, Baron Pierre de Coubertin, spoken over 200 years ago:
The important thing in the Olympic Games is not to win, but to take part. Just as the important thing in life is not the triumph but the struggle.

These Greater West Games have generated that spirit of participation, collaboration and cooperation. I am proud to be involved in the region that has supported them. I congratulate all those involved in the organisation of the Greater West Games.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I wish to raise an issue that has not been addressed by this parliament previously, but I think it is one that will require attention in the near future. It is in relation to predictive DNA testing in the context of privacy.

SPEECH.PARA: Predictive DNA testing is now a reality for many people. These tests are able to examine in fine detail the very basis of our heredity and provide insight into what diseases may be in store for the future of the individual and their family members. A person's genetic make‐up is a part of the information about that person.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have they found an explanation for the Democrats yet?

—Senator O'Chee may choose to be very glib about this issue, but it is actually a very serious one. The issues are probably best illustrated by a number of examples, but the one I shall use is the example of the hunt for the breast cancer gene called BRCA1.

SPEECH.PARA: Following a diagnosis of breast cancer in 1986, Kay Dickersin and her three sisters submitted themselves to DNA testing in Mary-Claire King's laboratory in Los Angeles. Through analysis of the sisters' DNA, the laboratory and other collaborating laboratories identified a region of DNA which carried the undiscovered BRCA1 gene. This achievement was lauded in the media, resulting in considerable celebrity status for the researchers. That is, the possibility of identifying a gene through a simple blood test that causes cancer promised a readily available `molecular mammogram'.

Since then, the gene has been cloned and the predictive DNA test is available. This test identifies the nature of a specific gene in an individual, and that is among the most personal of information for that particular person. The issue for the community is, of course, how to ensure that this test and others like it are applied so that the basic privacy of individuals is adequately protected.

The scientific approach of dissecting large problems into small sections is a powerful approach to problem solving. Without this approach, the present genetic technology may not have been discovered or developed. However, this approach does not incorporate limits to discovery, provide an insight into the long‐term consequences of those discoveries or place biological causes in their environmental and social contexts. That, of course, is our task.

This is not a negative assessment, or not meant to be a negative assessment, of the possibilities of genetic technology as many of the modern achievements in medicine have been assisted by technological developments. For example, the ability to control women's fertility remains a significant milestone. However, there is a need for debate about what we want and what we expect from genetic technology as the latest revolutionary technology.

It has almost been presented in science fiction terms with the overuse of superlatives and many grand ideas promising complete and specific cures. I certainly hope that genetic technology has not been used as a grand scam, if you like, to generate wealth and laurels for a select few at the expense of other more relevant and achievable research directions.

For example, Mary-Claire King has estimated that a woman carrying the BRCA1 gene will have an 83 per cent chance of getting breast cancer by the time she reaches the age of 70. This means the ability to detect the gene is merely an early detection mechanism and only adds to the range of other early detection mechanisms already available, such as X-ray mammograms. This one may be easier to administer, with fewer side effects and have a greater accuracy, but it is not a cure.

These statistics also mean that there are a cohort of carriers of the BRCA1 gene who will not develop breast cancer. Added to this statistical `chance', there are also a cohort who do not carry the BRCA1 gene and who will develop breast cancer. The causes for these other breast cancers include other genes, such as the p53, and other unexplained `sporadic' breast cancers which have no hereditary components. Once the predictive testing has been carried out and a patient has been identified as carrying the gene, the choices available to that patient remain the same. So predictive testing does nothing for treatment and prevention.

BREAK.PARA: In Kay Dickersin's case she had three sisters, two of whom also developed breast cancer at the age of 38. With three of the four sisters developing breast cancer before menopause and the youngest sister aged 35 and free of breast cancer, this represented, if you like, a pretty good bet for an inherited breast cancer gene. If a predictive test had been available at that time, the issue for the family could have been whether or not to determine which family members carried the BRCA1 gene and whether or not other family members should be tested or offered the test.

This illustrates my central concern about this issue—that is, how should the personal genetic information be collected, stored, collated and disclosed? The information of the older sisters was that they had the BRCA1 gene. This was their information, which was directly relevant to their lives. However, that information was also directly relevant to their youngest sister. She shares genes with her sisters and it was very likely she would have the same BRCA1 gene. But is her sisters' genetic information also her information? What entitlements does she have to that information? Does she have a right to know, for example, that her siblings or relatives carry specific genes?

I understand that there are complex ethical issues associated with the use of test results once they have been obtained and I cannot actually provide an easy answer to the parliament. But this is an important issue that the parliament should be considering and one that has been highlighted by a recent High Court decision, Breen v. Williams. This case does confirm that patients do not have the right of access to inspect or copy their medical records. These are the records that would, in the majority of cases, list the results of predictive tests and the way those tests are carried out.

Naturally I would favour a national and enforceable privacy scheme which applied to predictive testing, with provisions which are enforceable. This, of course, reflects the Democrats' opinion regarding privacy laws generally and, in particular, privacy laws that cover the private sector. I have introduced a private member's bill in that regard.

A privacy scheme directed to predictive testing would need to address, at least, the following matters: a definition of `personal information' which includes genetic test information that may affect or identify another, such as sisters sharing a gene for cancer; the circumstances in which a person may be denied access to their test results, for example, where there may be medical reasons; what controls there should be to ensure that a breach of confidence does not occur, for example, how test materials and results are stored; what complaint, dispute and dispute resolution mechanisms there should be in the event of breaches of confidence, and use or disclosure of test material and results; how test results should be disclosed in cases of adoption, unwanted pregnancy, fostering, et cetera, situations; how long the test laboratory should retain test materials and results, and provide access to those materials and results; and, finally, the test result information disclosed by the test laboratory for purposes other than diagnosis, even with the consent of the patient, for example for research purposes. I also place on record the relationship between privacy and a range of other information issues. Of course, I have spoken at length many times about the information society and its need for privacy infrastructure.

But I would like briefly to address a related issue which deals with access to information in the form of patents. The case of Moore v. Regents of the University of California concerns the ownership of biological materials. John Moore was diagnosed to have hairy cell leukaemia and sought help from Dr David Golde at the UCLA Medical Centre. John's cancerous spleen was removed and Dr Golde and his laboratory cultured cells from the tumour. They discovered unusual proteins in a cell line and they filed a patent. The matter resulted in a dispute, when Dr Golde attempted to get John to sign away his rights, which ended up in court. The court eventually decided that Dr Golde should have revealed his research to John, but it granted the property rights of the cell line for a limited period to the doctor.

The effect of this decision was to say that John did not own his own bodily material. I do not think that seems to be a satisfactory result. By extension it means that bodily material such as blood and DNA used in predictive DNA testing becomes the property of the tester. This is unfair and I believe it should be reviewed, as a patient with their unique biology should not be removed to the status of an interesting source of wealth and their body and its materials should not be owned by another.

I have addressed a part of my concerns about this issue in a private member's bill which is before the parliament. That bill specifically excludes the patenting of genes and gene sequences. But I suggest a future assessment may need to go further and examine patenting of cell lines and a number of other biological materials, as well as the privacy issues raised by predictive testing. The personal information contained in the DNA also needs to be adequately protected.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee, Sen Bill

TALK.START.PARA: —Such is the nature of our work that sometimes we think that we in this place or those in the other place are great people. But the true measure of greatness is the legacy one leaves after one dies. I wish to take a few moments of the Senate's time tonight to speak of a legacy which will endure from a truly great man, the late Professor Douglas Whalan, who was the legal adviser to the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances for some 15 years. Professor Whalan passed away quite recently after a struggle to overcome cancer.

SPEECH.PARA: You, Madam President, will know how brave Professor Whalan was in that struggle as you were kind enough to host a dinner in his honour when we last sat. Indeed, it will come as a shock to many senators that Professor Whalan has passed away so quickly. Fortunately, he was able to maintain his great sense of humour at all times and also his graciousness. I think you will have been touched, as I was, Madam President, by Professor Whalan's being immensely tired at the dinner that we attended but not wanting to leave while other people were telling stories and having a good time. I think that is a mark of a great and truly gracious man.

I was moved to look up Professor Whalan's entry in Who's Who. I know that this entry is not a complete entry because there are things that I know he has done which are not listed here. But it is interesting to note that from humble beginnings in New Zealand—and I always used to say to Professor Whalan, `That is a very humble beginning'—he achieved greatness not only in New Zealand, not only in Australia, but in Papua New Guinea and Canada as well where he made substantial contributions to the legal system in those countries. In his time he was Professor of Law at the University of Queensland and Professor of Law at the ANU. He was a member of the Australasian Law Schools Association and a member of the Alberta Institute for Law Research and Reform. He was, in fact, an organiser of the International Law Conference.

He was also a noted civil libertarian, but a man who was a civil libertarian not out of some ideological drive but out of a sense of decency. I think what drove Professor Whalan in his search for the maintenance of civil liberties was the sense that this was the decent thing to do for one's fellow citizens. He was also a great supporter of Aboriginal people. He was, in fact, the foundation chairman of the Aboriginal Legal Aid Service of Queensland in 1971.

Madam President, it may surprise you and others to know that in his time as legal adviser to the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances Professor Whalan scrutinised over 18,000 items of delegated legislation. Those who have had the good fortune and honour to serve on the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances will know that Professor Whalan not only had a meticulous eye for errors but also had a humorous way of expressing his point.

I think of some of the incredible detail which Professor Whalan could find in a set of regulations. For example, I remember several years ago Professor Whalan finding that the penalty for parking illegally outside the National Maritime Museum was $200 while knowing the penalty for parking on the other side of the street, which was not covered by federal government regulation, was in fact $10. He insisted that this was a matter of great concern and importance to the rights and liberties of individuals, and he was absolutely correct.

I think one of Professor Whalan's proudest achievements on the committee would undoubtedly have been rectifying an anomaly in the regulations that related to unpaid accrued holiday leave for public servants. I remember the great tenacity with which Professor Whalan led us in the fight to rectify the anomaly and the satisfaction he had in knowing that members of the public who had served in the Public Service, many of them some 30 years ago, wrote in saying, `Thank you very much for ensuring that I was paid all of the holiday entitlement that I should have been paid when I retired.' Some people said, `I have been retired for 20, or 30, years and this has made an improvement to my standard of living and has also meant that I finally feel that I have been appreciated and dealt with fairly, honourably and properly.'

That was the basis of Professor Whalan's zeal and his contribution to this committee. There are many members of the committee, past and present, who were touched by his little kindnesses. I know that those who travelled with Professor Whalan to the inaugural conference of Commonwealth legislative scrutiny committees in 1989 would say that, because of Professor Whalan's kindness, it was perhaps the finest overseas trip they had ever undertaken.

I was fortunate to go on a trip with Professor Whalan to New Zealand this year. I thought it was wonderful and incredible the way in which Professor Whalan was held in high regard, not just by Australian scrutiny committee members but also how those of other countries—for example, New Zealand, the United Kingdom and places in Africa—looked up to his erudition.

I also feel that I have lost a friend. Professor Whalan was not only a fine mind but also a great sportsman. He and I on many occa sions had wonderful conversations about the changes in training techniques between his day and today and the sorts of things that he used to do as an international triple jump competitor—or should we say hop, skip and jump competitor, as I think it was in his day. He had a freshness and enthusiasm for life that was undoubtedly contagious. Everybody who knew him loved him and admired him.

He also brought a strange passion to life. Some of his hobbies included bee‐keeping, horses and growing exotic fruit. There is one fruit that Professor Whalan has grown which will continue to flourish—that is, a lust to protect the rights of individuals. I know that this Senate committee, although it has been forced to replace Professor Whalan, will use him as an inspiration for what it does in the future.

I take this opportunity in closing to say that I will be giving notice tomorrow of a general business notice of motion which I will be seeking formality for on Wednesday. As I said, we sometimes think that we are great during the course of our life, but the true measure of greatness is the legacy we leave behind. Professor Whalan leaves behind a legacy for which many untold thousands of Australians will be grateful for many years to come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —When Robin Sharwood watched the 1988 bicentennial Australia Day celebrations of 200 years of European settlement and heard Australia's national anthem sung, it struck him that Peter Dodds McCormick's amended words contained no references to God. Despite Christianity being an intrinsic feature of Australia's history and the fact that our institutions are founded on Christian beliefs, there was no acknowledgment of God in the song which was proclaimed as our national anthem on 19 April 1984.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Sharwood immediately composed an alternative verse and proceeded to obtain official status for it from the Governor‐General. The words were sung with sincerity and spirit at the recent opening of the extensions to the St Brendan‐Shaw College in Devon port, where I was privileged to pull the curtain covering the opening tablet with the Archbishop of Hobart, His Grace the Most Reverend Dr D'Arcy.
Rather than sing the amended words, for the benefit of the Hansard record I will read them. They are:
O God, who made this ancient land
And set it round with sea,
Sustain us all who dwell herein,
One people, strong and free,
Grant we may guard its generous gifts,
Its beauty rich and rare,
In your great name, may we proclaim
`Advance Australia fair'!
With thankful hearts then let us sing,
`Advance Australia fair'!
