QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Family Services, upon notice, on 20 August 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to the transfer or bed licences from Derwent Court Nursing Home to Rosary Gardens Nursing Home, Tasmania.
(1) (a) What is the total number of nursing home bed licences in Tasmania; and (b) how many facilities have them.
(2) Has the total number of bed licences changed over the past 12 months; if so, how.
(3) (a) What is the value of a bed licence in Commonwealth and State subsidies and (b) what is its commercial value.
(4) (a) What is the process for allocating new bed licences or licences that become available through closure of an existing facility; and (b) is the State or the Commonwealth primarily responsible.

(5) (a) How many bed licences does Rosary Gardens currently have; (b) has Rosary Gardens received an additional 50 licences within the past 12 months; and (c) were the licences a direct transfer from Derwent Court.

(6) In relation to Derwent Court: (a) what process was undertaken that led to the closure; (b) by whom was the process instigated; (c) did the doctors who serviced Derwent Court support the closure; (d) what opportunities did the doctors have to make their views known; (e) did the residents of Derwent Court and their families support the closure; (f) what opportunities did the residents and their families have to make their views known; (g) who decided that Derwent Court should be closed and on what grounds; (h) on what date was the decision made; and (i) on what date was it implemented.

(7) In relation to the acquisition of the 50 additional bed licences by Rosary Gardens: (a) on what date were the licences applied for; (b) to whom was the application made; (c) on what date was the decision to grant the licences made and by whom; and (d) was a tender process used; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Family Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) Yes, there has been an increase of 8. This occurred as a result of the usual allocation round and reflects needs based planning guidelines.

(3) (a) The National Health Act 1953 does not "licence" beds, rather it allows the Minister to approve a certain number of places. When an eligible resident is being provided with nursing home care in an approved place, subsidy is paid according to that resident's assessed level of care need.
(b) There is no fixed commercial value attached to an approved place. The transfer of places by sale between approved providers is accorded a value by the parties, not by the Department.

(4) (a) The availability of additional places is determined and gazetted annually by the Minister for Family Services. Acting on advice from State and Territory based advisory committees that the Minister has appointed, applications are then sought from interested parties. Applications are assessed against criteria, and the Minister then approves the issue of new places.

Where a facility is closed voluntarily the places are returned to the pool for allocation through normal planning round. Where a facility is closed through regulatory action, the places again return to the pool, however a delegate of the Minister may allocate places to ensure continuity of care for residents affected by the decision.
(b) The Commonwealth is solely responsible for the allocation of approved places under the National Health Act 1953.
(5) (a) 180 after the allocation of an additional 51 places.
(b) Yes, Southern Cross Homes Inc has been allocated an additional 51 places at Rosary Gardens Nursing Home.

(c) No, there is no provision for direct transfer under the National Health Act 1953. Nevertheless the revocation of the approval of Derwent Court Nursing Home was the basis for the approval of additional places at Rosary Gardens Nursing Home.

(6) (a) Following the recommendation of the Standards Review Panel of Tasmania in December 1996 that Derwent Court Nursing Home be closed without delay an information gathering process was undertaken. That process included:
. a full survey of fire safety by TasFire in February 1997;
. a further full assessment of outcome standards by a standards monitoring team in March 1997;
. an independent assessment and consideration of the proprietor's proposals for improvement by the Standards Review Panel in May 1997; and
. detailed submissions by the proprietor in respect of each report (including the report of the Panel in December 1996).

On 20 July 1997, the Minister's delegate Ms Jane Halton, First Assistant Secretary, Aged and Community Care, signed a notice under section 44(2) of the National Health Act 1953 of her intention to revoke the approval of the nursing home after 14 days because she considered the condition of approval requiring that the standards determined under section 45D of the Act be satisfied had not been complied with. The proprietor made a short submission to Ms Halton. That submission was taken into account when Ms Halton made the decision on 6 August 1997 to revoke the approval of Derwent Court Nursing Home.

(b) Ms Halton, First Assistant Secretary, Aged and Community Care Division, wrote to the directors of the proprietor company on 1 April 1997 outlining the process of information gathering to be conducted by Ms Lisa Paul, Assistant Secretary, Residential Program Management Branch.

(c) The Department has had no direct contact from doctors to indicate whether they support the closure or not. One practitioner had previously contacted the Department about access by monitors and the Standards Review Panel to residents' records as part of the assessments conducted in March and May 1997.

(d) The Department did not seek the opinions of individual medical practitioners on the decision to revoke approval. However, review of nursing home care by the Standards Review Panel of Tasmania in May 1997 was chaired by a medical practitioner with extensive expertise in both clinical gerontology and in delivering nursing home care at a high standard. This review highlighted serious deficiencies across all of the outcome standards, reflecting a failure to understand the complex requirements for providing dementia care. Issues identified included lack of dignity and privacy, failure to maintain mobility and dexterity, very poor continence and pain management practices as well as broader problems relating to fire safety and the general physical environment. General practitioners continue to play a role in the planning and delivery of clinical care at Rosary Gardens to individual residents which they formally visited at Derwent Court.
(e) The Department has heard a range of views from former residents and their families.

(f) Discussions were held with residents and their families during each of the assessments of standards carried out in March and May 1997, and provided an important part of the findings that the standards were not satisfied. The National Health Act 1953 makes it a condition of approval that a nursing home satisfy the Commonwealth standards. When a facility does not, a decision must be made the Minister or delegate about what action is justified in the circumstances.

(g) The delegate of the Minister, Ms Jane Halton, First Assistant Secretary, Aged and Community Care Division, revoked the approval of Derwent Court Nursing Home under Section 44(2) of the National Health Act 1953 because she considered that the condition of approval requiring that the standards determined under section 45D be satisfied had not been complied with.
(h) The decision to issue a notice of intent to revoke the approval of the nursing home was made on 20 July 1997. The decision to revoke the approval of the nursing home was made on 6 August 1997.
(i) The decision to revoke approval was implemented on 7 August 1997.
(b) The State Manager, Department of Health and Family Services, Hobart.

(c) Mr Stephen Dellar, State Manager, Department of Health and Family Services, Tasmania and delegate of the Minister for Family Service decided to allocate 20 places to Southern Cross Homes on 24 July 1997. He allocated a further 31 places on 25 July 1997.

(d) There was no tender process. Advertisements and a full process of evaluating applications against criteria were considered inappropriate in the circumstances. With a risk that the nursing home approval might be revoked, the primary considerations were to ensure continuity of care and significantly better quality of care for residents, whilst maintaining existing family and resident networks to the maximum extent possible.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney‐General, upon notice, on 27 August 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to the answer to Senate question on notice no. 576 (Official Senate Hansard , 28 August 1997, page 6005), and specifically paragraph (5) which reveals that there are presently five matters which have been appealed by the Commonwealth from decisions of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission (HREOC) and that to date $40,634 has been expended by the Commonwealth on matters being appealed by the Commonwealth:
(1) What is the substance of the Commonwealth's appeal in each of these matters.
(2) What question of law is being determined in each case.
(3) In what jurisdiction is each of these cases being appealed.
(4) Why has the Commonwealth appealed each of these cases.
(5) Can a copy be provided of the Commonwealth's submissions in each case.
(6) On whose recommendation and/or advice has the Commonwealth appealed these cases and can a copy of that advice be provided.
(7) How much money has the Commonwealth earmarked for each of these appeals.
(8) Who pays the legal costs where HREOC is a party of these appeals.
(9) Do legal costs come from HREOC's budget; if so, what percentage of HREOC's budget has been spent in defending appeals initiated by the Commonwealth.
(10) What are the grounds of judicial review or policy grounds for appealing each of these cases having regard to the circumstances of each case.
(11) Does the Commonwealth `cap' the money it will spend in appealing cases from HREOC; if so, what is the cap.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney‐General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am advised by the office of the Australian Government Solicitor that only two of the five matters in which the Commonwealth has filed an application for judicial review of HREOC decisions remain current. The following three matters have now been finalised:
(i) Secretary, Department of Defence v HREOC & Messrs Burgess, Collins & Lipping.
(ii) Commonwealth of Australia and Minister for Health v Morrish & Ors.

PARA.TAB: On 18 July 1997, the Commonwealth's appeal was upheld by the Federal Court, and the decision of HREOC set aside. The matter was remitted to a differently constituted Commission, but the complaints have since been withdrawn and the matter finalised.

ANSWER.PARA: (iii) Commonwealth of Australia v HREOC & Aufgang.

PARA.TAB: The appeal to the Federal Court was resolved by consent. The parties agreed to set aside the HREOC decision and remit the matter to a differently constituted Commission for reconsideration.

ANSWER.PARA: The following applications remain current:
(i) Commonwealth of Australia v HREOC & Roger Muller;
(ii) Commonwealth of Australia v HREOC & Jeff Kellan.

These application concern different determinations made under the Public Service Act 1922, but involve the same legal issues. In each case, HREOC found that the current respondents were discriminated against on the ground of sexual preference. The respondents had claimed allowances in respect of their same sex partners. One case involved an overseas living allowance, the other a remote area allowance. The Commonwealth submitted that the respondents were not entitled to the allowances under the relevant determinations, made under the Public Service Act, and the allowances had not been denied on the ground of sexual preference.

(2) The question of law are the same in both cases; first, whether HREOC adopted and applied a construction of the term `spouse' which was inconsistent with the definitions of the term in the relevant determinations; second, whether HREOC misconstrued provisions of the Public Service Act; third, whether HREOC erred in failing to hold that the determinations did not discriminate on the ground of sexual preference; and fourth, whether HREOC erred in finding that the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act 1986 applied to indirect as well as direct discrimination.
(3) Both applications for judicial review were filed in the Federal Court of Australia.

(4) The Commonwealth is seeking judicial review in each case, because the Commission has made, in the view of the Commonwealth, errors of law and its decision has widespread implications for the administration of other Public Service determinations.
(5) The Commonwealth's submissions have not yet been prepared.

(6) I have been advised that the Australian Government Solicitor and Counsel provided advice on whether the decisions contained errors of law and on the prospects of success if an application for judicial review were filed. The advice is subject to legal professional privilege. As with any litigant in the same position, the Commonwealth would claim that waiver of this privilege by release of the advice would risk prejudicing the advancement of its interest in the outstanding case, and therefore declines release.
(7) no specific amount has been earmarked.

(8) In each case, HREOC has only made a `submitting' appearance—that is, at the beginning of the case, the HREOC Commissioner concerned declared that he or she will abide by the Court's decision (whatever that will be), and take no active part in the case. Therefore, any costs incurred by HREOC should be minimal, and would be met by HREOC, for monies appropriated to fund its operations.

(9) As mentioned in answer to Question 8, HREOC would pay any legal costs form monies appropriated to it to fund its operations. Also, as stated in my answer to Question 8, HREOC has submitted to the jurisdiction of the Court in the current cases and, therefore, its costs should be minimal.

(10) The grounds for judicial review in the present case concern the questions of law referred to in answer to Question 2. The policy grounds for instituting these appeals are referred to in answer to Question 4.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business, upon notice, on 29 August 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: Further to the questions on notice submitted by Senator Murray on 12 August 1997 via theSenate Economics Legislation Committee to the Industrial Relations and Small Business Policy programs (program 1.1) of the Industrial Relations Portfolio:

(1) Had any members of the Franchising Code Administration Council (FCAC), as at the date of its entry into administration on 31 December 1996, been appointed to the council by any Minister; if so, when and in what manner, and please indicate who was so appointed.
(2) For such persons so appointed please detail what the Government's role was in the selection and appointment of the former Directors of the council.

(3) Did any Minister ever write to any Member or Director as follows: `I am establishing the FCAC to administer the operations of the Code'; if so, please supply copies of any letter in that or similar vein to any former Director or Member of the council.
(4) Please detail the role of the Australian Government Solicitor in composing the Memorandum and Articles of Association of the FCAC Limited.
(5) Did the Commonwealth Government have the principal, originating and determining role in the establishment of the company.

(6) Did the company have certain reporting and other responsibilities to the Minister responsible, required partly as a result of the Government composing the Memorandum and Articles of the company, and wholly as a result of the Government's intention to set up the company.

(7) Did the Government insert clause 29 into the Articles of Association giving the Minister the right to appoint an observer to the council under such terms and conditions as the Minister sees fit; if so, please detail the process concerned.

(8) Were there any minutes or recorded notes of the FCAC Working Group recording that the Government deliberated on the character of its control over, relationship with, and the position it would hold on the council.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Franchising Code Council Ltd appointed an Administrator (FCC, formerly Franchising Code Administration Council (FCAC)), on 30 January 1997. No member of the company had been appointed by any Minister at that time.

On 30 December 1996 the company decided to cease trading on 31 December 1996, and to hold an Extraordinary General meeting on 30 January 1997. As was the case above, no member of the company had been appointed by any Minister at that time. This reflects the Government's expectation that members would have been elected in accordance with the provisions of the Memorandum and Articles of Association.

Notwithstanding this, on 31 December 1996, when the FCC had ceased trading, I understand that Mr Michael Delaney was a member of the company. Mr Delaney was one of the core members of the FCAC when it was established, and was appointed for a period of two years by the then Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs.

The former Government appointed the initial core members of the Franchising Code Administration Council (FCAC) in 1992. The then Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs, the Hon David Beddall MP, wrote to a range of persons inviting them to be members of the initial core group of members of the FCAC on 22 September 1992. These initial core members were:
Chairman:Mr Robert Fitzgerald
Representing Franchisors:Mr Stephen Penfold; Mr Stephen Jermyn
Representing Franchisees: Mr Michael Delaney; Mr Ron Wilson
Banking Representative: Mr Kevin Guttridge
Other Representative: Mr Michael Ahrens (Baker, McKenzie Solicitors)

Except for Messrs Penfold and Ahrens, each was a member of the Franchising Task Force that produced the report, Franchising Task Force: Final Report (December 1991), that recommended the establishment of the Franchising Code Administration Council (FCAC) to administer the voluntary code.

Mr Tim Garrard, then the Assistant Secretary of the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce, was the Government representative on the initial FCAC. The position of Government representative was as a non‐voting observer only.
The letters inviting the above industry persons to become core members of the FCAC stated that part of their responsibilities would be to
". . . recommend to me both the appointment of the remaining Council members and the basis for future membership appointment."
After the core members were appointed, arrangements were established for the remaining members of the FCAC to be appointed.
The remaining members of the initial FCAC were appointed on the basis of advice provided by the initial core group. For example, one advice to the Minister states:

"The core Council membership sought nominations from the petroleum retailing and new motor vehicle retailing industries in order to ensure that both industries became familiar with the aims and objectives of the Council and to help allay any concerns these industries may otherwise had with the Code. In addition, the very size of both industries, in terms of both turnover and employment, also suggested that both should have representation on the Council. Consequently, Mr Thilo Troschke, National Corporate Affairs and Administration Manager of Honda Motor Vehicles, was nominated by the Federal Chamber of Automotive Industries, and Mr Stuart James, National Reseller Manager of Shell Australia, was nominated by the Australian Institute of Petroleum."
Half of the initial members of the Council were appointed for one year, with the other half being appointed for two years.
Members were thereafter elected by the Council for a two year period.
FCAC members were allowed to serve a maximum of two terms.
Any representatives of franchisors, franchisees and service providers and advisers were able to nominate and stand for election to the FCAC.
New FCAC members were elected by the remaining and outgoing FCAC members.

(2) As noted in question one, the Government did appoint the initial core members of the Franchise Code Administration Council (FCAC). The remaining members of the initial FCAC were appointed on the basis of advice provided by the initial core group of members.

The FCC was an independent company. As half the members were appointed for two years and half for one year, it was the Government's expectation that elections would have occurred in accordance with the Memorandum and Articles of Association and members appointed accordingly. Consequently, after the second year, the Government had no role in the selection and appointment of members of Franchising Code Council Ltd (FCC).

(3) In 1992, the then Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs, the Hon David Beddall MP, wrote to various persons, inviting them to be members of the initial core group of the FCAC. In those letters, the Minister stated:
"Presently, I am establishing the Franchising Code Administration Council to administer the operations of the Code."
Copies of the letters are at Attachment A.

(4) Mr Robert Fitzgerald, who accepted the position as Chair of the FCAC in a letter dated 22 October 1992, wrote to the Deputy Government Solicitor on 26 November 1992, asking him to proceed with the incorporation of the FCAC on the basis of a range of specifications set out in his letter.
This letter specified the company name, the company status, the purpose of the company, procedures on company membership, specifications for committee membership, the quorum and fees.
Mr Fitzgerald's letter stated:
+3. Purpose
The purpose of the Council is set forth in paragraph 1.6 of page 148 of the Franchising Task Force Final Report. . . "
On the basis of this information, the Australian Government Solicitor formulated the Memorandum and Articles of Association.
The letter from Mr Fitzgerald to the Deputy Government Solicitor and paragraph 1.6 of page 148 of Franchising Task Force Final Report are set provided in Attachment B.

A very similar letter was sent, on 2 December 1992, by the then Assistant Secretary of the Services Industries Branch of the then Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce. A copy of this letter is at Attachment C.

(5) The establishment of the FCAC was recommended by the industry‐led Task Force in recommendation 9 of Franchising Task Force: Final Report. The establishment of the FCAC was the culmination of a significant amount of work undertaken primarily by representatives of the industry. A response to an additional question asked by the Senator on 12 August 1997 indicated that this Government did not "set up" the company. However, in 1992, the then Government did play a key role in the establishment of the company, particularly in bringing the parties together to identify and seek solutions to the problems faced by the franchising industry, and facilitating the establishment of the Franchising Code Administration Council, including development of the Memorandum and Articles of Association of the company, appointment of the members of the company (for periods of up to two years) and provision of seed funding.

Both the industry and the then Government recognised that franchising was a large, fast growing and important sector in the economy. The industry had identified constraints to the growth of franchising, which included costly legal disputes between franchisees and franchisors, the threat of legislation and damage done to the reputation of franchising from the existence of a small minority of disreputable franchisors and franchise consultants in the industry.

A Task Force was established to recommend solutions to the problems impeding the growth of the franchise sector. The Terms of Reference asked the Task Force to examine and propose mechanisms for the reduction of barriers and impediments to the efficiency and growth of the franchising sector.

The Task Force was industry led and comprised a small expert group formed from representatives of franchisors, franchisees, the banking sector and academics. Mr Robert Fitzgerald was the Chair of the Task Force. The deputy chair position was held by the then Assistant Secretary of the Service Industries Branch of the then Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce (DITAC). The decision to establish an industry led Task Force recognised that the commitment of the people in the franchising industry was critical for the industry to be reformed.

The Task Force sought solutions that would avoid the situation that had developed in the United States, where the franchise sector was characterised by excessive regulation, exorbitant start‐up costs and costly litigation.

The Task Force received submissions from a wide cross section of the industry including franchisors, franchisees, associations, lawyers, accountants, consultants, bankers, small business organisations and government instrumentalities.
The Task Force concluded:

"The Task Force has walked a delicate line in seeking to protect the interests of all participants in the franchising sector, whilst creating an environment that should enhance the growth and efficiency of the franchising industry in Australia.

"To this end, the Task Force, having carefully examined various options, has determined that a self‐regulatory Code of Practice administered and maintained by a Council of representatives from all areas of the franchising sector to be the most appropriate response." (Franchising Task Force Final Report (December 1991), p.vi)
Recommendation 6 of the Task Force was:

"The Task Force recommends a self‐regulatory Code of Practice be developed which will cover Franchisors, Franchisees, Advisers and specified Service Providers as defined in the Code." (Franchising Task Force Final Report (December 1991), p.xiii)
Recommendation 9 of the Task Force included the following:
"The Task Force recommends the following administrative arrangements for the Code of Practice:
a. The Minister for Small Business, in consultation with the Council of Small Business Ministers, should establish a Franchising Code Administration Council ("the Council").

b. The Council should comprise representatives of Franchisors, Franchisees, Advisers, Associations, Service Providers and at least one government representative. The Council should comprise between 9 and 11 members. . . " (Franchising Task Force Final Report (December 1991), p.xv)
The Task Force also noted:

". . . the Task Force has developed its conclusions and recommendations based on a thorough analysis of submissions presented and of the studies undertaken." (Franchising Task Force Final Report (December 1991), p.vii)

As can be seen from the above, the industry led Task Force recommended that the FCAC be established to administer the self‐regulatory code, on the basis of numerous submissions from industry and Government. It also formulated the initial draft code of practice, which was included in the Franchising Task Force Final Report (December 1991) at pages 148 to 170.

The Government facilitated the establishment of the FCAC by providing the technical services of the Deputy Government Solicitor to draft the Memorandum and Articles of Association of the FCAC in accordance with the specifications set out in the 26 November 1992 letter of the Chair of the FCAC, Mr Robert Fitzgerald.
Once established, the FCAC consulted widely with the industry and government before finalising the code of practice. The FCAC then administered and maintained the code.

The Government played a supporting role in the implementation of the recommendations of the industry‐led Task Force to establish the FCAC. The Government provided seed funding for: the establishment of the Franchising Code Administration Council (FCAC); further development of a code of conduct; and the design and implementation of an appropriate accreditation/registration scheme.

Funding was initially for a two year trial period. One of the objectives of the trial was the attainment of cost recovery for the code's administration by the end of the period. At that time, it was envisaged that Government involvement in the administration of the scheme would be minimal thereafter.

In summary, the Government's primary roles in the establishment of the FCAC were to bring the parties together to address the problems facing the industry, through the establishment of the Task Force, and, following consideration of the Report, to facilitate the establishment of the FCAC, including developing the Memorandum and Articles of Association and providing seed funding.

(6) The reporting and other responsibilities to the Minister responsible, in the Memorandum and Articles of Association, broadly reflect the advice of the Chair of the FCAC to the Deputy Government Solicitor, which, in turn, broadly reflect the pertinent sub‐clauses in clause 1.6 of the Draft Code of Practice set out in Franchising Task Force Final Report (December 1991).

The Chair of the FCAC wrote to the Deputy Government Solicitor on 26 November asking him to draft the Memorandum and Articles of Association according to a range of specifications, including the purpose of the company as set out in section 1.6 of the Draft Code of Practice in Franchising Task Force Final Report (December 1991).
In section 1.6 of the Draft Code of Practice, the industry led Task Force suggested the responsibility the Council would have to the Government. The relevant sub‐clauses of clause 1.6 are as follows:

PARA.TAB: "(b) advise the Minister for Small Business on policy issues relating to Franchising from time to time, and undertake tasks referred to it by the Minister, within the terms of reference to the Council;
(e) report to the Minister for Small Business, and through the Minister, to the Meeting of Small Business Ministers, on an annual basis."
Section 2 of the Memorandum and Articles of Association of the FCAC specified the objects for which the company was established. Section 2 included the following sub‐sections:

"(3) to administer and monitor the implementation of the Code, and provide an annual report to the Commonwealth Minister for Small Business, and through him or her, to the Meeting of Small Business Ministers, on the progress of that implementation, as required by the Code. . . "and

"(7) to provide continuing advice to the Commonwealth Minister for Small Business on policy and other issues relating to franchising, to make recommendations for the enhancement of franchising in Australia and to undertake tasks referred to the Company by the Minister. . . "

ANSWER.PARA: (7) Clause 29 of the Memorandum and Articles of Association is consistent with the letter of 26 November 1996 from Mr Robert Fitzgerald, Chair of the FCAC, to the Deputy Government Solicitor. Clause 29 states:

PARA.TAB: "29. Observer

ANSWER.PARA: 29.1 The Minister may appoint a person to be an observer at all meetings of the Company and the Board during such period as he or she thinks fit.
29.2 An observer is entitled to notice of meetings of the Company and the Board and is entitled to attend, but not vote at, such meetings.
29.3 The observer shall hold office upon such terms and conditions as the Minister thinks fit, and may be removed from office at the Minister's discretion.
29.4 An appointment, or termination of an appointment, of an observer shall be effected by notice in writing signed by the Minister and served on the Company."

The initial core members of the FCAC recommended to the then Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs that there should be one Commonwealth Government representative on the FCAC, which should be appointed as a non‐voting observer.

It was noted above that Mr Robert Fitzgerald wrote to the Deputy Government Solicitor on 26 November 1992, asking him to proceed with the incorporation of the FCAC on the basis of a range of specifications set out in his letter. That letter included specifications on the company's membership. It stated:
". . . [A]t all times the committee membership is to comprise the following:
I. five committee members representing Franchisors;
II. five committee members representing Franchisees;
III. two committee members representing service providers and advisers;
IV. one practising lawyer; and
V. one chairperson.
In addition to the above there will also be one government observer appointed to the Commonwealth Minister for Small Business from time to time. He shall be a non voting observer."

(8) An extensive search was made by officers of the Department of Workplace Relations and Small Business for such minutes or recorded notes. No minutes or recorded notes of the Franchising Code Administration Council Working Group have been found in the files examined by officers of the Department that record that the Government deliberated over the character of its control over, relationship with, and the position it would hold on the Council.

As noted above, the initial core members of the FCAC recommended to the Government that there should be one Commonwealth Government representative on the FCAC, which should be appointed as a non‐voting observer. Mr Robert Fitzgerald, the Chair of the Working Group, also specified that the Deputy Government Solicitor include in the Memorandum and Articles of Association that the Minister could appoint a non‐voting observer to sit in on FCAC meetings.

7. National Library of Australia
(a) What programs/grants administered by the Library provide assistance to Tasmanians?

Under its Act the Library exists to provide services to all the people of Australia. We are charged with ensuring that documentary resources of national significance relating to Australia and Australians are collected, preserved, identifiable and accessible to all Australians.

Over recent years as stated within our Strategic Plan 1993‐98, we have given priority to activities which maximise nationwide access to and awareness of our collections and activities in line with our goal to be the world's leading documentary resource for learning about Australia and Australians.

Tasmanians as with other Australians, benefit from these activities. For example since we launched our World Wide Web site in March 1995, use has increased throughout Australia from 2,190 files accessed daily to a May 1997 increase of 19,500 files daily.

While we do not record individual State figures for Internet use, the fact that we provide approx 2,000 requests per month for Tasmania from our document delivery/interlibrary loan service; that there are 38 Tasmanian participants to our national Australian Bibliographic Network; and that we have 169 Tasmanian addressees on our regular mailing lists to receive information, indicates the level of interest from that State to our services (The mailing list includes a range of state departments, community organisations, libraries, art galleries, schools, museums as well as The Launceston Examiner and Hobart Mercury).

Grants are made to assist in the preservation of material which is of national significance.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Export Finance and Insurance Corporation: Policies

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism, upon notice, on 4 September 1997.

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Export Finance and Insurance Corporation (EFIC) have any policies regarding the necessity for environment, human rights and social issues to be taken into consideration before giving out loans or insurance or investing in mining companies; if so, what are these policies; if not, why not.

(3) Do these policies apply internationally in all countries in which EFIC operates; if not, why not.

(7) During the term of a loan, insurance or investment does EFIC require environmental, human rights and social updates to be done on loans, insurance and investments.

(8) To what extent, and please provide details, does EFIC expect to increase its environment, human rights and social due diligence over the next 3 years in the following areas: (a) monitoring of loans; (b) monitoring of insurance; (c) monitoring of investments; or (d) corrective action programs.
(9) How often does EFIC presently target credit extension, insurance extension or lending activity specifically to the mining industry; please provide details.
(10) To what extent does EFIC expect to increase assets/capital focused on this area (for example, mining, oil and gas industries) in the next 3 years.
(11) In which form does EFIC report its involvement in mining projects to the public.
(12) Does EFIC give public notification of projects and companies to which it is providing loans, insurance or investments; if so, please provide details; if not, why not.

(15) (a) Is EFIC aware of the United Nations Environment Program statement by Banks on the environment and sustainable development of 1 May 1997, which advocates the application of environmental risk assessment, best practice and the precautionary principle; and (b) does EFIC intend to sign this agreement; if so, when; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1), (2), (3): EFIC's policy in respect of all countries is to comply with all applicable international obligations and relevant Australian legislation, including the application of the administrative procedures attaching to the Environmental Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974 (EPIP ACT). Before offering EFIC services, EFIC assesses all relevant factors affecting the risk of loss by EFIC.
EFIC has no investments in mining companies.

(4) EFIC has declined to support transactions in countries which were the subject of Government directives to the Corporation. For example until 1993 EFIC declined all applications for support in South Africa, in compliance with sanctions.

EFIC has also declined to support transactions which involve a degree of risk that the Corporation cannot prudently accept. EFIC has in some cases approved transactions following changes by the applicant which mitigate the risk. Risk factors may include aspects affecting the physical or social environment. In some cases, applicants have amended proposals to take account of views of the Environment Protection Group.
Information relating to specific transactions is commercial‐in‐confidence. Under the EFIC Act officers are subject to strict confidentiality obligations concerning client information.
(5) See (1) above.
(7) EFIC monitors factors affecting its risk exposure during the period of that exposure. Risk factors could include aspects of the physical or social environment.
(8) No changes are planned.

(9) EFIC has no policy of specifically targeting the mining sector. EFIC's mandate is to provide finance and insurance services to help increase Australia's exports. A significant proportion of Australia's exports come from the mining sector.

(10) The extent of EFIC's future exposure to these industries will depend on a number of factors including the success of Australian exporters operating in these industries, the availability of commercial finance and the demand for EFIC's services from mining companies and their financiers, and EFIC's assessment of the risks associated with any potential transactions.

(11) EFIC's Annual Report contains information relating to significant projects it has supported, including all loans made. EFIC publishes in the Commonwealth Gazette information concerning transactions made under the National Interest provisions (Part V) of the EFIC Act.
(12) See answer to question 11.
(13) See answer to question 7.
(14) EFIC in some cases engages consultants to assist with due diligence or monitoring.
(15) (a) Yes. (b) No. See answer to question 1. The parties to the UNEP statement are banks.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 19 September 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the giant African snail represent a quarantine threat to Australia; if so, what is the nature of the threat.
(2) (a) How many giant African snails have been detected in Australia; (b) when and where were they detected; and (c) by whom were they detected.
(3) Have containers always been inspected for the presence of these snails on the wharf before they are moved off site.
(4) Is there a scientific reason for the requirement that this clearance be carried out on the wharf before the container is releases.

(5) Has the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS) reached an agreement with a company, Chief Container Shipping Line, to shift containers inland before any inspection takes place; if so, what is the scientific basis for allowing a departure, in place of the existing requirement that containers not leave the wharf prior to full inspection.
(6) If AQIS is to permit containers to move inland before any inspections take place, what security arrangements will be put in place for the transportation of these containers.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. The Giant African Snail (GAS) is considered by most authorities to be a most damaging land snail if it becomes established. It can forage on over 500 varieties of plants, and can act as a vector of various human diseases. They are not known to exist in Australia.
(2) (a) and (b) AQIS's Pest & Disease Interception (PDI) database records interceptions for GAS for 1996 and 1997 as follows:
* State counts include interceptions only, and not the number of GAS for each interception.
One interception also occurred in January 1996 at Amberley Airbase, Queensland.
(c) All interceptions were detected by AQIS staff.
(3) Containers and freight originating from countries where giant African snails are known to exist are always inspected prior to being transported from the wharf environs.
(4) Inspections are carried out in the wharf environs due to the perceived risk of the snails drop ping off containers whilst in transit through areas where GAS may become established.

(5) No. The agreement between Chief Container Shipping Line and AQIS does not allow uninspected containers to be moved inland. Container movement is clearly defined by AQIS and restricted to within the boundaries of the wharf environs, and remain subject to full inspection.
(6) Container movement is not permitted inland prior to inspection, and is strictly limited to defined wharf environs.
